text: Should be a bit stickier. But pretty good. Clean the surface well before using

Being someone who works on vacuums, I know them well. I have used everything from Rainbow, Kirby, Simplicity, Shark, Dirt Devil, Hoover and many many more. This vacuum has a basic design that has been the same for decades and it works. I have an older model Eureka that's 41yrs old and still works great!  If you truly want to clean your carpet quick and efficient with no bells and whistles, this is the vacuum for you. It's a great cost effective vacuum that will last for years with proper care. If you have hard floors, I recommend a kenmore canister to do these jobs. You can find one for less than $50 and they work great.

I thought I reviewed enough before I bought the shark. I guess I was wrong. As with most of you, the handle is too hot. It has not burned my hand but my hand is red after using for more than an hour. An hour is a standard time for cleaning floors. If you clean your whole house, you will spent more time than 4 hours. (...). I have used it only once because the hose pop off and water did come out. It did not clean a stain that the com. said it would or the stove top. I do not know how you can clean the cabinets with hose so short and the canister does not sit up. It keeps falling over. After reading all 67 reviews, I am going to returned my to the department store and check out the website listed in other reviews. I am back to using the swifter system.
Some of the tape is still sticking to the window seal, about 1/8 of it is not...

I got my first roll on Step 12 of 2012. It lasted for three winters. Just loved it. Right before winter I got two rolls. One for my new green house and one for my older one. Would love to talk to the seller

I tried this product and followed the instructions exactly.  I did not experience any of the pain or irritation reported by other users, but there was no visible whitening of my teeth.  Totally worthless product.  I don't know why I had such bad results when a few others report significant whitening.  Assuming they are not on Rembrandt's payroll, it must be some difference in the type of stains or perhaps mouth chemistry.  Or maybe the goop in my package had broken down chemically, though it was well within its sell-by date.

Working by myself, I needed to raise a 12' long 2' X 6' stud wall that contained 2 doorways.  Since I'm a Senior, I thought it might be better and safer to have some assistance instead of doing my usual clean and jerk by hand.  I was not disappointed.  I bought 2 jacks and placed them about 2 feet apart.  I alternately jacked each one, until the wall was in position.  One jack would have handled this short wall easily, but I used the second jack for safety.  These jacks are heavy duty and easy to operate with a straight 2" X 4".  I blocked the bottom of the 2" X 4", so it couldn't kick out.  I'm very happy I purchased them.

Looking for sand paper to stick to everything? this is it. It has some much adhesive that it ripped off the Porter cable sanding pad on the third sanding cycle. This pad was a Porter-Cable product and brand new. Do not use on or with a sanding pad. Sticks to blocks of wood and metal.
  The Photo is of the 80 grit. Also purchased the 120 grit with the same results. Two pads destroyed with less than 15 sanding cycles.

I brought this product because I was concerned about the flouride in toothpaste. Unfortunately the ingredients are not listed in the product description. I thought Tom's of Maine was a good healthy brand and that's why I was very surprised when I recieved the product and noted that it contained Carrageenan,which is a natural additive used to thicken foods. It is derived from seaweed. The problem is it has been shown to irritate bowel lining in people who have IBS, Crohns disease and Ulcerative Colitis. It can suppress Immune function and cause inflammation. It has also been shown to be a carcinogenic. So do your own research on this substance and be aware before buying products that contain Carageenan.

I didn't really notice a difference after doing the 4 rounds.  I did 2 one night since I was short on time, and everything felt fine.  Then I did the other ones 2 days later.  When I put in the last tray my lower gums stung a little, but I thought it was normal and left them on.  It felt a little tender, but ok.  Now I know that was a big mistake, because the next day I am in agony.  I feel like I got punched in the mouth and when I put some anbesol on my gums they stung like crazy until the numb kicked in and my skin started peeling off.  It feels like I have canker sores all along the bottom of my gums.  I've never had this happen with any other whitening product.  I'm getting married in 3 days, so hopefully this doesn't last long or I will not be smiling in any of my pictures because it hurts to smile!

Hey y'all,

This here is DW from TN and I thought I'd share my experience with this product.  My wife, Bertie Mae has been a suggestin' that I should whiten my tooth and lo and behold I found this here fancy product.  Now I did buy this at a yard sale for .50 cents and I believe most everything was in the box.  The trays had already been molded by the previous owner so I was able to save some time there, and there were 4 of the little tubes in the box, now they'd been opened but the previous owner was nice enough to wrap 'em in a bandaid.  I guess I'm just lucky, or me and the previous owner have about the same shape of mouth because I was able to slide these right in.  It wasn't a real tight custom fit but, heck, what do you expect for .50 cents.

Now I bought this here product to whiten the 1 tooth I have left.  It's on my lower shelf, I call it my snaggle tooth but I don't think that's the real name for it.  Considering the fact I don't need the other tray, if anybody reading this here review wants it, you are welcome to it, just let me know.  My box did not have the instructions so I just kind of winged it and went ahead and filled the tray up to the tippy-top and slid it in, and then fell asleep.  I woke up the next morning with two discoveries.  The first thing was my whole mouth hurt like 60 and the second thing was my darn tooth was just as white as me and Bertie Mae had hoped for.  Heck, my wife even said I'm too handsome now and she wasn't gonna' let me go over to the Piggly-Wiggly by myself because she didn't want the local girls a gawkin' at me.

Overall, this was a not very fun experience but my tooth got white, I paid .50 cents for the treatment and saved time not having to mold the tray as that was done for me by the previous owner.  So I'm going ahead and give it 3 stars.

Tastes like garbage and didn't work any better than the colgate brand I bought from Target before.  It does work its just pretty expensive for something colgate and crest make that works just as well and tons cheaper.

We've owned a dearly departed rechargable Braun toothbrush for years.  I'm bothered that they welded the case together so completely that it's impossible to replace the now worn-out NiCd battery with a new one without destroying the case.  Then I saw this AA-powered model for really cheap.  "A good solution!", I thought, especially for the international travel that I do. (AA- NiMH cells run my world.) So now I've had time to evaluate this little machine.
1. It really brushes your teeth and gums, just like it's big brother.  No complaints there.  Brush with this and you're shiny clean.
2. It really rattles your head!  It appears to run at a much higher motor speed than its rechargable big brother.  The old scrubbing oscillation of my first Braun is now a blurry buzz.  I'm considering making up a "dummy" AA cell, just a piece of metal, so that it runs on only one cell instead of two.  Maybe that will slow it down enough to be more comfortable.

As a shipwright I clamp and use fasteners on all my wood projects. I tried using this to save on the 24hr cure time of epoxy - This glue fails miserably for exact fits between hardwoods. I can remove the fasteners and easily take apart whatever I glued with this 24 hours later. Big fail! Epoxy is best, but even Elmer's glue works better than this!

There had been some really cold weather that was well below freezing in the area. Most of the 10 year old caulking was either cracking or barely there. I found a really bad caulking job that must have been done by previous people who lived here where they simply applied old caulk right over the new one. It was that nice silicon based ones meant for the bathroom. Basically had to redo that whole entire job.

Well it has been just over 3 months since I put this down and it hasn't cracked yet. Being cheap I wasn't expecting a whole lot, but it gets the job down. I haven't tried this on exterior yet I wouldn't think it would hold for long. For now this has had a really dramatic effect on temperatures indoors. Noticed at least a degree cooler in the hot spring weather. Would have to wait for the winter weather and see how it does. You do not want to apply this when it is below 40.

I'll update this if anything new happens but bottom line is that it is cheap and can help fix those old cracking caulk. I'd get something different if using for outdoors.

I ordered this glue to fix our front door where the metal framing was separating from the wood door, making it difficult to close the door. I followed the instructions carefully, using gloves and holding the pieces together for a considerable amount of time. What the instructions didn't mention was that this glue expands as it dries and dries brown. As a result, I had to scrape away a lot of excess glue that stuck out of the crevice in order to close the door - and it's not too pretty to look at, although it was an ugly door to start with anyway. So in short, it did the job, but with some not so great side effects.

Do you have migraines or Meniere's disease or just have a sensitive head? Don't get any of the pulsating Oral B brushes. They will just make you nauseous or trigger a headache.

I have used the classic Oral B electric brush for many years. A fantastic simple white design by Braun of Germany - since discontinued after Braun was bought by an American company. Now I have the simple low end non pulsing model. Essentially the same guts and head as the classic but with an ugly, over stylized, blue body.

When the battery started to die on my classic model, I picked up a pulsating Oral B. It is really banging away at your teeth and does as good a job as the non pulsatinging. But it vibrates your jaw and skull like, well, a vibrating electric tooth brush! After a month, it was just too much for me. I went back to the dieing battery original, but soon got its replacement as a gift.

The verdict: I'm in my 40s and I've had about 6 different dentists (moving from job to job) in 5 different states. One was a professor at a dental college. After each visit, they all proclaim my teeth are in excellent shape. I use the cheapest Oral B electric brush (non pulsating) in the morning and before bed with Colgate Total. I also floss just one time before bed and use the Crest rinse for night time. I get them cleaned every 6-9 months.

Save your money and get the cheapest Oral B electric toothbrush. I think it is on sale sometimes for about $10.
They work like all the rest.

Gorilla glue might be very strong but it is not user friendly for woodworking. It has some major drawbacks. It is not water soluble so you cannot wipe the excess with a wet rag (I had to use lacquer thinner). It expands quite a bit which means even if you wipe the excess initially, you are still going to have it coming out of the joint. Don't even think about using it to glue anything without using clamps, as the expansion of the glue will cause the parts to move. The bottle cap is cheap and it broke at the bottle when I tried to pull off the cap (which of course glued itself to the nozzle).
I've gone back to conventional woodworking glues and the new ones (tite-bond) are very strong so there is no real advantage to Gorilla glue.

Please do not risk your money or safety!  I purchased this product at Target two days ago and set about cleaning my tile floors.  All went well until 15 minutes into the second room.  The machine suddenly began to spurt scalding hot steam from the handle and hose attachment.  My four year old son was watching from what I thought was a safe distance and his thigh was blasted with hot steam.  Yes, he did suffer a minor, but painful burn.

My husband then tested the Shark later that evening by filling it, placing it in the middle of room and plugging it in.  Lo and behold, within 3 minutes, the thing was hissing and spitting pressurized, scalding steam in all directions.  I half expected it to start chasing us around the room.  Back it goes to Target tomorrow and I'll be stunned if they don't have several lawsuits on their hands if they continue to stock this ridiculous, dangerous product.

For what it's worth, having now done some research on the whole steam cleaner thing, it seems that vapor steam cleaners are more efficient, safer and better value in the long term, even though the initial cost is higher.

At any rate, I am warning everyone who is even considering purchasing the Shark to swim rapidly in the other direction...

We  bought this product some years ago  with red instead of black "hooks," and liked it until the hooks began to fail/fall apart and we had to discard the item. It is a wonderful item because it allows things to be stored upright and off the floor.  And provides great access to anything with a round handle. Ease of use is just great. I researched vacuums for two months before deciding that this was the one I wanted and a big part of that decision was this picture on the website.  The pretty black motor cover and the speckled bag.  It would have complimented the cabinet design of my apartment.  So I was completely disappointed when I opened the box and found the grey model.  It is ugly to me and it does not go with my apartment.  I called Amazon and they were going to send me the exact replacement free of charge.  EXACT REPLACEMENT.  I cancelled that replacement after calling the  Eureka Manufacturer in the manual I got with the grey one and explained that this picture is being showed on various websites that sell the Eureka Upright 1934B. Let me clarify the two pictures, and the problem after talking to the Eureka Representative.
First of all;  the only vacuum Eureka has out in circulation is the grey model that is the 1934B.  End of story.
There is no pretty black vacuum with a speckled bag out in circulation.  The picture is being shown on Amazon.com, Walmart.com, & Global Industries.com. A lot of sellers of the Eureka 1934B Upright Vacuum is an ugly grey color and are being shown as a pretty black vacuum with a speckled bag.  Although after looking more closely at the Amazon Website it does show you at the bottom of the page the grey model that you will get delivered.
I UPLOADED A PICTURE OF THE VACUUM you will receive when ordering from this Web Page.  Just look at my Profile Picture (Product2review).  I did that for reviewers so you would know what you are ordering and what will be delivered as of 12/03/2013.
The vacuum works great; very strong suction and can even get sand off of the tiled floor with ease.  It works, and is well-worth the money even though I am disappointed with the way it looks; and all the websites that are showing this pretty black vacuum with the speckled bag.  I wanted an upright and had the grey one saved in my (saved for later cart) on Walmart.com then I saw this pretty picture. I am not terribly handy, but found this glazing compound pretty easy to use.  A 10"x24" pane in our door was leaking because of cracks in the old glazing compound on the exterior side.  After cleaning out the old product I was able to put this in and get it all smoothed out in about 30 minutes.  I put it in when the weather was about 75 degrees and sunny and it got a little sticky and tough to work with, so perhaps next time I would work with it in slightly cooler temperature.  I didn't realize there was such a long wait time for it to cure, but after a couple weeks it took the primer and paint just fine and it looks great!  Better, in fact, than the pane adjacent to it so I may have to do that one as well. Luckily the weather will be in the 60's so I think this will go a little more quickly this time around. Porter-Cable: 32 sheets of 4.5x11, for a price of $0.43 pre-sheet (@ $14 per-roll)
Norton: 200 sheets of 4.5x11, for a price of $0.07 per-sheet (@ 15 per-pack (of 100 9x11 sheets).

Unless you seriously have something against money; spending six-times as much on sandpaper is stupid.  The only difference is the "adhesive backing" which wasn't that adhesive and provided no benefit whatsoever.

Received my "hangup" vacuum a few weeks ago.  I used it for some light duty vacuuming down in the basement. Unfortunately the hose is too small (narrow) and since the hose is so long it clogs VERY easily.  And when it clogs it overheats.  After about the 10th clog I packed it back up and sent it back to Amazon.  I instead ordered the 6.5 peak horsepower model (925-42-10) for $99.99 (has a 2.5" hose instead of this rinky dink one).  It's MUCH quieter, MUCH stronger, and has not clogged even once.  I'm giving this two stars because I am disappointed with the power, noise, size of the hose, and pretty much everything else about the vacuum.  The only good thing is the variety of attachments you get.  But who can vacuum with an attachment that only gives you an opening of about 1/2" (crevice tool)??  If you're just going to vacuum out your car or some dust then this is ok for you.  If you want a "shop vac" like the name says...then forget about this one.

I purchased these for my Hardie siding project and started using them today....no doubt they are useful for doing a job solo like myself, but they are not accurate.  I got to my 4th coarse and I've gained a 1/4 inch....I went back to old school way of a control line and measuring by hand off this to keep the elevations consistent.  That being said.  They are close enough so that you can one end or let one side rest on the gauge and set to your own marks the other side, then come back and remove the gauge to set exactly.  I think the only way you could up the accuracy is to have the gauges set off the bottom like the competitors gauges do, but I can't vouch for the Gecko gauges as I am fine with these and I think it's good to keep checking no matter what you use to keep a better control of your work....not much different than stacking 16 oc time after time....eventually you are going to be off...so I would say either gauge is likely to gain or lose doing a stacked approach with gauges.

In the early 80's my parents bought one of these Eureka vacuums during a K-Mart Blue-Light Special ($60) and used it as their only vacuum until I inherited it and have used it since. It still runs, but the motor bearings are worn out. This one appeared almost identical to the original so I couldn't resist ordering it. The shape of the motor housing has been modernized a bit but most of the machine is identical, wheels, handle, belt, bag, etc. (Evidently Electrolux now owns Eureka as the ad says Electrolux, however, only the name Eureka appears on the machine, like the original!)

Obviously, this is not the most powerful or sophisticated vacuum available, but it definitely has a place in the home. It has adequate power for routine cleaning. It is reasonably quiet, quite light, and is inexpensive. The combination of its adequate but not excessive vacuum and its good brush design makes it preferable to our bag-less machine for cleaning some of our more valuable rugs. (The bag-less is better on carpets.) In addition, it works well for use in our RV.

Once you get familiar with with how this works, then it's easier to strategize how and when to use it.  It's very messy to work with and takes a long while to set up.  I've used GG (and other brands of the same type of glue - which, incidentally, seem to be identical to the point that I don't really have a preference) for countless things over the years:  I repaired the broken frame of a Nordictrack skier that developed a crack (I glued the crack and clampled it, as well as glueing and screwing a piece of wood to the side, along the crack and a few inches beyond on either side), put a kickboard on the screen door of our front door which is starting to deteriorate at the lower corner, built a small playhouse ladder, and about a million other things I can't recall.

It works well and bonds seem to be very strong.  I generally use glue as a supplement, not as the only source of bonding (if possible).  I've repaired some non-wood items as well.  Some have worked fine, some not.  As another review mentions, you can peel the dried glue off of the nozzle when you're opening it for another use - so it's probably not the best choice for plastics.  I've done some ceramics and it's been fine - the foaming as it dries can of course make the end results look less-than-perfect.

Overall GG is very useful, and there are plenty of things for which it works very well and where, say, super glue doesn't do the trick.  I don't know if it's better than wood glue for wood projects.  From what I hear it's not, but I don't always have wood glue around, so I'll use this.

The most important advice I can give is: don't buy too big of a bottle unless you really use it a lot.  When you're done using it, squeeze as much air out of the bottle as you can.  I've never been able to actually finish a bottle of this kind of glue, because as I get to the last third or so, it usally hardens or there's so much dried glue at the top of the bottle that I have to cut apart the bottle to get to the remaining glue.  Squeezing out as much air as possible before closing the cap will mitigate this to a large degree, but at some point you just can't get enough air out and so you start to see the crusty, hardened end of the life of your precious bottle of glue somewhere on the horizon.  It's the circle of life.  For glue, anyway.

Okay, this is not an industrial fryer,  let's just get that out of the way.  The place I work, took out it's fryer probably over 10 to 15 years ago and have never looked back.  Cut his insurance significantly and they did not use it enough for it not to be a hassle when it was used.  However, no matter what anyone says, some things just need to be deep fried, there is not good substitute for example, mozzarella sticks. We have tried doing them with a kettle on the stove, home frier and purchased products that we were guaranteed could be done in the oven.  We have made our own and pre fried them then finished them in the oven and we have made ones that we did in the oven from beginning to the end.  There is just no substitute.  We had a wedding to serve that was very upscale but mozzarella sticks are the grooms favorite so we needed to do something.  I did not want to spend a lot of money on a tool that would not get that much use but from past experiences knew any of the fryers you get that use a gallon or less of oil are useless for mass production.  I decided on this one after reading the reviews.

Unboxing and set up are easy.  Be careful, this is not high grade stainless steel not matter the specs listed.  The insert that hold the grease is like a a medium quality hotel pan. It got up to temp quickly and maintained heat well.  The fryer basket holds a 2# bag of moz sticks perfectly and they fried beautifully.  Clean up is easy and it fits nicely on our ss work table.

I do not think this unit will take abuse or a lot of hard use well but if you treat it respectfully and with the knowledge that it is not an industrial fryer, there is no reason it should not work for some time and work well.

Overall, I LOVE this fryer and would buy it again without hesitation

One of the benefits of being a senior is to have lived long enough to tell the difference between quality and junk. Change is not always good. New devices are not always better. I picked up an old style Eureka that had been put out for trash. I easily and quickly had it going and have used it almost daily for 15 years or more. It ain't pretty but it was cheap. I am a Mr. fix it and have become rather good at it. Over the years I have been given several uprights and got some of them going. But They were heavy, didn't roll easily and were very disappointing in their performance. One thing that I learned was that on every task the Eureka out performed and outlasted them. Recently the motor in the old Eureka began to fail. I began looking at new replacement models. All the new models were pretty and shiny and very pricey. But they were also poorly engineered  and since I am the one who uses the vacuum and and has to keep it going, I began to realize that none of them measured up to the old Eureka. So I went online, hoping and praying that maybe this old reliable friend was still available. I couldn't believe that it was still available online and quickly ordered one. Best Christmas present in a long time. I was absolutely thrilled to get a brand new Boss unit in just a few days. Thank you Eureka!!!!!!!!!!! ideal4ujoe@yahoo.com

I deliberated for a few years on how to try to winterize my screened in porch in the North Woods of Wisconsin.  Living in Chicago, it's hard to take on a big project so far away, but I came across Warp Bros products, (which are made here in Chicago), and boy am I glad I did.

I have a 20x8 screened in porch up north, and wanted an easier way to keep the rain and snow out in the fall and winter, instead of covering the windows with the typical bunjee cords and tarpoulin.  I did my research and purchased a case of the Warp Bros Flex-O-Channel, and a roll of the 25yardsx3feet Flex o Glass.  It was an afternoon project,  but considering the alternative, (buying storm windows), this was so much easier and cheaper.  The flex o glass is crystal clear, goes up easy (if it's not windy out), is VERY durable, and snaps right into the flex o channel.  Goes up easy, and comes down easy too, store away the flex o glass for the summer, then put it back up in the fall.  Keeps the rain, snow, and whatever else out.

I was up north in early February, it was in the 40's during the day.  After the sun beat down on my screen room for a few hours, the temperature in the screen room was 70, from about 3pm to almost 7:30!  I'm not entirely sure what the flex o glass is derived from, but it keeps the cold out, and the heat in!

I love Warp bros products.  Do the math, new windows...$1500......Do it yourself Warp Bros windows.....$200 bucks.  No brainer.

Keep in mind any product that promises white teeth in two hours is pure baloney. All these whitening products you see on tv are displayed by actors and models who have brilliant white teeth to start, having had thousands of dollars worth of cosmetic dental work done. That's the bait. They never show an average joe putting whitening strips or trays in their mouth. This product isn't even made in the USA, it's made in Canada and imported. This product contains a known caustic bleaching agent, hydrogen peroxide, that can and has caused adverse reactions, such as blistering and whitening of the gums, severe swelling of the lips, burns and sores in the lining of the mouth, extreme sensitivity of the teeth and tongue pain when used over a two hour period. This product is not FDA regulated for quality assurance, safety or efficacy, and is not endorsed or recommended by the American Dental Association. When it comes to putting a caustic bleaching agent in your mouth for two hours, you're taking a big risk that could land you at the dentist with a large bill to reverse the damage caused by this product, far beyond what it would have cost had you scheduled a regular exam and cleaning in the first place. For safety's sake, use common sense. If your teeth are stained or yellow, go to a dentist. They are trained in mixing cleaning preparations for the teeth that will not harm delicate mouth tissue. They often use a stannous flouride treatment along with cleaning. This seals the teeth and prevents tooth sensitivity after cleaning. This product should be removed from the market pending an investigation on safety. Save the twenty dollars this product costs. It could cost you a lot more in the end.

I purchased this brand new measuring instrument (General Tools #142 Caliper) in its original and sealed packaging. Upon opening it, I discovered that the unit is defective, due to a manufacturing problem. It cannot be properly zeroed due to a lack of parallelism of the jaws. As a result, a visable air-gap exists between the jaw surfaces and a reasonably accurate measurement can never be taken.

I contacted General Tools about this product, thinking they would be interested in evaluating it in order to make improvements to their manufacturing process and produce a better product. This is a very effective and powerful glue when used carefully and properly. It expands (foams) when it cures -- great at filling gaps. It is flexible after curing. It doesn't smell. It can be trimmed with a sharp knife after curing. It really sticks well to just about everything (except polyethylene). It cures enough to stop clamping in 2 hours, completely in 24. It is very good for making or repairing a paperback book binding if you are careful. Using masking tape (the sticky side) or wax paper can be useful to block the glue from gluing/sticking to surfaces (both peel away from the glue afterwards).

The instructions advise you to push excess air out of the bottle before closing -- this can be a bit difficult. This is to exclude water vapor as reacting with water on what you are gluing or from the air is what makes the glue cure.

Epoxy is better if you need a hard rigid strong bond. Cyanoacrylic ("super glue") is better if you need a strong bond in a very tight space (like cracked china). White & yellow "Elmer's" glue is best for paper and normal wood joints. This glue is best if you need to fill gaps, glue difficult materials, need flexibility, need something very durable (waterproof, doesn't dry out/crack), and don't mind having some glue foam out of the joint at times (this is easy to trim back).  Basically you need to use the right tool/glue for the job.

The only things this tester is good for is if you KNOW you have a good ethernet cable, you can confirm it. And it will identify a SOLID failure of a line or pair within an ethernet cable. It is of no value in troubleshooting structured wiring, or a questionable cable (intermittent) crimp/end.

 I found a couple of things wrong with this item.

1. You can't use it on live circuits or you will damage the devices connected to it.  That means you HAVE TO KNOW FOR SURE what is on the other end of the wire, and that it is FOR SURE disconnected.

2.  It only tests cables when you power on.  Thus if you have an intermittent cable end, and the unit shows the pair as"bad" with most testers, you can wiggle the questionable cable end (who knows which one) and the tester will then show the cable as either open shorted or good.  With THIS tester, it only tests once upon power up.  Thus if you wiggle a questionable end AFTER you power it on, it will NEVER show as good so you are guessing which end is bad.

I bought the original Sonicare when it first came out -- 20 years ago? I don't remember. The technology clearly works. My dentist reports a significant improvement in plaque. I have never used any of the other "sonic" toothbrushes. I imagine they work as well. My original Sonicare just started acting up. It still works, but I think the battery is dying. So I bought the e7300. First impressions are that Philips went for glitz over quality and has added all kinds of marginally useful or even useless "features" so they can engage in marketing hype and jack up the price. It looks to be more cheaply made. I would be surprised if this unit lasts even a fraction of the 20 years of the original unit. It looks to me like it was designed to fail. I was annoyed by the very first page of the manual. It tells me to make sure the handle is properly seated in the base, because if it is put in wrong, the charging light may still come on, but it won't charge. What kind of engineering is this? If it's not charging, don't turn the light on. Don't they have engineers smart enough to figure that out? So I tested it. Sure enough, you can put the handle in any which way and the charging light comes on. This is just lazy or careless design work. Worse, the base is too small, too light, and too shallow. In the original unit, the handle goes well over an inch into the base and there is only one way it will fit. With this unit, the base only holds the handle by about a half inch so it's easy to put it in wrong. And sure enough, no matter how you put it in, even half falling out, the charging light lights up. Looks like it was designed by the marketing department? Then there's the idiotic 2-minute shutoff. I can see zero benefits and several disadvantages. First of all, why are they shutting it off after 2 minutes? Do they think I might leave it on or am too lazy to turn it off myself. This is a clear case of terminal helpfulness. But that's not the most annoying problem. You do NOT want to take the thing out of your mouth while it is running or you will spray toothpaste and spit everywhere. After a few uses, I am operating on autopilot. When I finish brushing, I click the on/off button to turn it off and remove it from my mouth in one simultaneous motion. If you happen to finish brushing just as the thing shuts off (after 2 minutes), clicking the on/off button will actually turn it back on as you are removing it from your mouth. Now you will have a nice little task of cleaning the mirror, the sink, your shirt, the wall, the floor... Nice. #@$%#$@!!! I have done this a few times. Not good. Personally, I find the "timer signal" every 30 seconds annoying, too. I just want a simple on/off button. It's a toothbrush, not the control panel for a heart-lung machine. KISS. Actually, I have no problem with this "feature" if some people are unable to figure out how to brush without a built-in timer as long as the company provides a way to turn the infernal thing off. But clearly they think they know what I need better than I do. In the original model, I could at least turn off the 30-second reminders by holding the on/off button for a few seconds -- simple. With this "improved" model, they have added a "dual speed" button, but it only works while in the charger. Now that's convenient. I have the charger at the back of the sink behind the radio and out of the way. Now I have to move the charger to where I can actually see it. My guess is that they are again protecting me from myself so I won't accidentally change the settings while I am using the unit. Did they test this on morons? Did they test it at all? The ultimate insult to injury is in the instructions on recycling the battery. I am told to first deplete the battery. I am to do this by removing the unit from the charger, turning it on, and letting it run until it stops. But it stops every 2 minutes! Since they brag that the unit can be used for 2 weeks (twice a day) on a full charge, they are really asking me to stand there for an hour (2x2x14 minutes) and restart the unit 28 times. Like that is going to happen. On the bright side, it comes with a very nice travel case. I used to toss my old one in my dopp kit, which is probably why it broke and I bought this piece of junk. Summary: The technology works. This unit was designed to fail early so that you would buy a new one. I give it 3 stars for cleaning teeth and 0 stars for arrogant, cheap design and being overpriced. 07/30/10 I have since junked this thing and bought an Oral B Sonic Complete. (Oral B S-320 Sonic Complete Rechargeable Power Toothbrush) What a difference. The Oral B is well designed (with one minor annoyance) and it cleans better. I have a mouth guard. I clean it every morning. It had become yellowed over the years. After a few days with the Oral B, it has lost most of the yellowing. I am downgrading the Sonicare to a 1 in comparison to the Oral B. Check it out.

I bought a gorgeous old Jet contractor's saw.  It was in good condition, but it SHOOK violently when it was turned on and off.  I had heard a lot about this kind of vibration-reducing belt and I figured a new belt couldn't hurt.

Granted, this was an older saw with an older belt, so I don't know how much of the reduction was due to the better belt or just that the older belt was worn out, but I was amazed and would definitely suggest picking this up if you have a vibration.

This new model  isn't anything like the one I had before.  To date, it's proven to be very rough on gum tissue and doesn't do anywhere as good of a job of cleaning teeth as the older model.  To add insult to injury, you can't replace the battery.  Once the battery is worn out, just throw the unit away.  I say, stay away from this unit.

UPDATED REVIEW:
I gave it one star to begin with, and now wish I could give it zero.  It broke after less than one year of minimal use (I disliked the Eureka vacuum so much that I purchased a different vacuum to use instead, and used this one only on occasion for quick pickups since the other vacuum is a canister vacuum, not an upright).  Horrible customer service from Eureka.  Was a longtime Eureka customer (and told them so, but they didn't care), and will never buy another Eureka product again.  Bought a Bissell (canister vacuum) and love it.  I bought the Bissell with the intention of using it to clean baseboards, upholstery, etc, but wound up using it to vacuum the carpet too.

I mentioned this below in the comments to my review, but it bears repeating here: I had a previous version of the Eureka Boss and really liked it.  Eureka  changed the vacuum substantially but kept the name and raised the price.

MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I did a lot of research (not enough apparently) before buying this vacuum.  I was looking for a Eureka vacuum that was similar to the previous ones we've owned.  Eureka's own website led me to believe that this vacuum had a place for attachments.  It was not necessary that the vacuum itself come with attachments, as long as the attachments from my old Eureka uprights fit this model (since they have all been interchangeable in the past; and if not, I would have been willing to purchase new attachments).  This vacuum was a complete waste of money for me.  Now we need to spend even more money so that I can purchase a vacuum with attachments.  Eureka makes one, but I'm not sure I want to give them any more money.

Also, I am not in love with this vacuum even if I consider just its intended purpose.  I will update this review with more details when I get a chance.

I seem to be the only person on here who did not realize that this vacuum had no place for attachments.  Even the manual that comes with it, has an order form for the attachments.

But that aside, I will say that for a vacuum that does only one thing, I expect much more for the price.  It has many flaws that I will list when I get a chance to update this review.  Because of this, I think that this vacuum would still have been overpriced (compared to what we've paid in the past for other bagged upright Eureka vacuums), even if it had come with attachments or had a place to attach them.

I bought this wheel to grind down a sidewalk that was damaged/lifted by a tree root. It works well. You need to keep it moving or it can dig into the concrete. I was prepared with safety glasses and a dust mask. But had to go back to the garage for some ear plugs, it it loud. You need to give it some muscle to really take off the concrete, I was trying to take my time and do a nice job. I might do a little more grinding and put in some patch material in the crack. The secret for me was to keep moving it back and forth on the area I was trying to remove, it came out very smooth. No one is going to trip on this crack. Best 4 bucks I spent lately.

I purchased Delta's 10-inch benchtop drill press last year and quickly learned that a drill press vise would be a must-have accessory.  I first purchased a generic, "universal-fit" drill press vise, but it didn't fit the table properly.  The mounting holes of the vise didn't align with the mounting holes on the drill press table.  I returned the vise and decided to buy the appropriate Delta model vise for my press.  Contacting Delta, this is the model they said would fit my drill press.  When the vise arrived I was surprised to encounter the same problem.  Once again, the mounting holes/slots didn't line up.  I complained to Delta and their response was pretty lame.  They said the vise would still work fine if it was mounted to the table at an angle.  Furthermore, it would not be cost-efficient for them to make a vise which perfectly fit every model of drill press.  Excuse me, but wouldn't it be a simple matter to machine the holes and slots on the drill press table to accomodate the slots on the vise?!  I don't get Delta's flimsy explanation.  Anyway, I'm sure this vise is of good quality and will do the job it's meant to do, but if you order it for your drill press, you may not be able to expect it to fit the way you think it will.  When mounting the vise to the table on an angle as Delta suggests, it looks and "feels" odd.  In addition, you can't achieve the same amount of adjustability with it as if it were mounted properly.  Delta needs to re-think its engineering and tooling strategies so its products are more compatible with each other.

The first bottle I used seemed to work well at first.  Then the sprayer assembly came off the bottle body and I had the liquid I was spraying on me.  The second one worked great.  The third one was a repeat of the first.  That is when I decided to closely examine the product and found that during assembly two gaskets had been installed on the tubes of the sprayer assemblies of the two bottles that had come apart when used.  The extra gasket prevented the sprayer assembly from screwing onto the bottle body properly. Therefore, I cut one gasket off each and now all three screw together well, do not come apart unexpectedly, and so far work great.

I am quitting smoking, so I thought whitening my teeth would help me to stop. Forming the trays to my teeth was easy, so I was optimistic. I filled the trays with the bleaching gel, popped them in my mouth and set the timer. Within five minutes I could feel it burning my gums but I hung on. Ten minutes, still burning. I made it to twenty minutes, removed the trays and looked. My teeth didn't look different, but my gums in several places where it burned the most were bleached white! I rinsed my mouth with water but they stayed white. I was more careful putting the gel only on my teeth for the second round, but only made it 12 minutes before the burning was too much to handle. I brushed my teeth and gums immediately but they stayed ghostly white for two days, a little creepy since I am a culinary instructor and talk for a living. I see very little difference in the color of my teeth, so the pain isn't worth it.

I am going to knock 3 full whopping stars off of this review for the packaging.  I bought these because I needed a small quantity of nails for a small project, and had a coil gun already.  It will probably be 10 years before I do another roofing project, and I didn't need to go to home depot, buy 7200 nails, and be storing 7000 of them for 10 years.  For that reason it was worth paying a much 4X greater per nail price, but still half the total order price.  But, come on guys, these are nails, not eggs.  The nails were themselves in a fairly rugged box with cardboard padding inside the box already.  Then they were in yet another box, with more cardboard padding, that was labeled on the outside with product information.  Then, of course, Amazon puts them in yet another Amazon prime taped cardboard box, with cardboard padding.  How many trees did this take to ship a box of practically undamageable nails?

Glue works great for repairing broken glass things in the yard, but the spout where the glue comes out will harden into an unusable mass after a few uses, even after following clean-up instructions to the letter. If I ever buy another bottle I will not snip the tip off, but instead try to remove the entire cap each use & use a small stick/ "spatula" to dip out of the glue bottle & spread on the surface to be repaired (sounds like this might work).

I bought several dozen of these bottles. Initially I was happy with everything about these bottles. I am now on the 6th bottle breaking. I had to come back an update my review to make sure others knew what they were getting into.

 The issue on all the bottles has been the nozzle which does not stand the test of time let alone the test of rigorous use. The single stream no longer exists and instead the bottle will spray just as if you unscrewed the nozzle completely. The nozzle seems to come apart in the middle so one wouldnt even notice what was going on until they sprayed.

Everything else is great, the size, the style, the power of the stream. But 6 bottles breaking. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.  Coming from separate orders. (I placed multiple). There is a reason this squirt bottle is not 5 stars when all it needs to do is operate properly. The reviews reflect the poor quality (in my case all 6 times just the nozzle)

My solution is just buy more nozzles. But I'll never order this product again.

If you see any reviews that reflect otherwise then the chances are it is just a person who wrote their review quickly and did not come back to update it after the bottles failure. I'd bet every 5 star review is now a 1 or 2 star if they remember to check back in.

UPDATE:  Apparently , every spray bottle doesnt last. No where on Amazon there exist a superior spray bottle solution nor can I find one on the internet.

In light of all products in this category being a different variation of "bad"  this product deserves 3 stars. Because it isn't horrible and my problems with it were fixed so far by getting nozzles.

I have a very old (20 plus years) Craftsman 1/4 sheet sander. I got it because you could cut down full sheets and clip them to the sander.  Well after 20 years the clips are just plain worn out and no longer hold the sheets in place.  Well 1/4 sheet adhesive backed paper is WAY too expensive, and I have not found any full sheet sticky back.  I was just about to toss the sander in the garbage when I stumbled across these rolls.  I decided to give them a shot and I'm so glad I did.  The adhesive sticks well to even my 20 year old rubber pad.  The sandpaper is very durable and long lasting.  I'm using this mainly for wood, but won't hesitate to go after metal or fiberglass (should the need arise).  At only 20 cents a pop this is one of the most economical adhesive backed options around.  I'm gonna have to order a couple other grits cause this stuff is great.
These work great.  Will reorder when I need additional item.

It's OK. There are many better alternatives if you consider price, performance, cost, hazards. Some old, old timers used anhydrous lanolin strait or cut with alcohol (95% plus) in a pump spray bottle. Need low water content to keep lanolin in suspension. Side benefit of using strait lanolin lightly smeared on cartridge case with your fingers is your skin stays soft and no hazards.  Check the hand-loading websites for more suggestions.

I do not recommend this product at all! To start, I do not have any known allergies, I don't have sensitive skin at all, I've never reacted to any chemicals. I have tried other teeth whitening products before.
I read all the instructions carefully prior to starting, and kept referring to the instructions while I was doing the steps. It is a very easy set up and very easy to use. My teeth absolutely became noticeably whiter.

It very clearly states not to put the gel on your lips and gums. Each application, I was very careful to avoid putting the gel on my lips or gums and even wiped with a towel for good measure. I made it to the last session when my gums started to feel weird. It was a very dull pain, but I hadn't felt it until the last session and towards the end of my 20 minute time.

It has now been two days and my lower gums are in SO MUCH PAIN!! It is painful to eat, painful to talk, painful to touch. If the paid doesn't go away in another day, I'm going to seek medical attention. I will update my review.

So, this product did whiten my teeth, but also gave me immense gum pain. Not worth it to me at all.

Rembrandt used to have a product called the Dazzling White kit. It consisted of four or five little tubes of a very, very effective whitening toothpaste. You just brushed your teeth as you normally would, using the Dazzling White. The only difference was that you didn't rinse your mouth for thirty minutes after brushing, giving the paste time to work. Results were excellent. I noticed a real change for the better in two weeks, and it lasted. No messy trays or fumbling with whitening strips.

I'm not sure why Rembrandt discontinued Dazzling White, but it was a big mistake. Rembrandt, bring it back!

I bought this vacuum after my fourth vacuum died after catching on fire.  I have pets, which means lots of hair on the floor.  This vacuum gets it all up with out a problem, it is very light weight, the bag is very easy to switch out, the roller is easy to clean off, and I can actually see it lifting up the carpet a little while vacuuming, so it definitely has the suction power.  It is much quieter than my previous vacuums, and has a bit of a purr to it from the rubber bar on the roller thumping.

It is not a shop vac, so do not expect it to pick up bigger items like leaves or scraps of paper, it just pushes them out of the way.  It also makes a huge racket if you accidentally get a coin or other small metal object up.  I just turn it off, shake it a bit, and the coins fall right back out.  It came with no attachments, so I did purchase the attachment kit, but have not tried it out yet.  As a floor-only vacuum it does well.  I have not noticed it blowing any dust back into the air, like my old vacuum did, and the brush and beaters do a great job of brushing the carpet, so it looks newer and feels softer.

Unfortunately the item arrived with the indicator glass broken so I am returning it. The case has no foam or anything to protect the precision tool, it is just hard plastic. The instruction printout was crammed into the case and the various components were actually forced through the paper so it's got a bunch of big holes in it.

The magnet is plenty strong, the arms are beefy, the adjustment knobs are chunky and easy to tighten. It is actually quite a bit stiffer and easier to use than the Starrett bases I usually work with.

I set the indicator up on a flat surface and slid some feeler gauges under it and it did give accurate readings. The bezel I received is not as pictured on this product page. It is a chunky black plastic that is pretty snug to move even with the clamp backed all the way off, zeroing without moving the indicator may be difficult.

Overall this combo is a good value, but the case does more harm than good... at least during shipment.

This works well, and it's quick and easy, but it caused me such gum damage that I can't give it 5 stars. I thought I was being careful! I used just enough gel (there is probably enough in each tube for both trays) and removed extra gel if it came into contact with my gums. This is a problem, as most of my staining is at the gumline, so ideally I should get the product all the way up there.
I typically use Crest Whitestrips. They give me some discomfort, but nothing I can't handle with a bit of numbing gel. This Rembrandt set appealed to me because I could use it once, instead of daily for weeks like the Whitestrips. Alas, it made my gums VISIBLY irritated- red, peeling, and so painful. I didn't have this discomfort until the following day, and then it took another 2-3 days to heal. It was really unpleasant to eat and brush my teeth.
That said, if you have less sensitive gums, I do recommend this product for its results and speed. It certainly does whiten nicely, at a reasonable price. Per the other reviews, my experience was not the norm.

I have a number of Shop-Vac hoses and a whole box of attachments and adaptors, the latter which I have ordered trying to get a good fit with some odd sized or metric dust outlets from woodworking tools in my shop.  I thought I could use this to conveniently join two Shop-Vac hoses.  The problem is that this coupling doe not have enough depth or friction to hold the two hoses together, including with the vacuum operating.  I don't know whether Shop-Vac intends that you use duct tape or solvent to glue it in place, because it certainly won't work as a friction fit with the supplied Shop-Vac end couplings.  It may be better to go with this rubberized union coupling with stainless steel straps if you want an airtight connection and one you can undo readily:: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006TWQDG8/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_3
Note that this coupling under review is not intended for use directly on the corrugated Shop-Vac hoses, but rather on the end nozzles/couplings for those corrugated hoses supplied by Shop-Vac, or for connecting with outlets on shop equipment.
Paul

I purchased these because I am doing most of my restoration work myself.  There are some good points and bad.  The bad:  The top and bottom caps pop off continuously.  If the poles drop they fly off.  When I go to release the tension from the top of the pole, it slides down fast, popping off both of the cap and the round piece (used to allow the top to swivel).  One time when I released the pressure, the pole extension dropped and went into the pole itself, the spring flew off and the clip that allows the poles to extend got smashed, I spent 1/2 hour taking the thing apart and trying to reassemble it.

These are a good idea and have helped me out, I have saved time building my own, but they are not the best quality.  When I received the poles, some parts were missing and there were no instructions.  (I did not take off points for that as it is not manufactures fault, but this is becoming pretty common when purchasing things through Amazon)  I went to youtube to see what some of the parts were and found a lot of instruction on how to repair these poles.  That kind of tells you something.

The good:  if you are working by yourself they will save you time and some frustration (except when you have to reassemble them)  I have found that I have to attach the poles  by wire to something so they won't fall over, I am installing framing on a ceiling and using 9 foot boards so I have to tie one of the poles to one ladder then to another ladder then put up board.  The best part is  the  hand adjustment, you just squeeze the handle and you get a final adjustment.  But if you try to put any type of pressure on it, it stops working, due to the plastic pieces.  You can make things snug but not overly tight.
If you are going it alone these are a good option, but there are some limitation.  There needs to be a safety on the top cap so the rod does not fall into the pole, itself.  Top and bottom caps need to stay on better.

"Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.

Here are my observations:

* You must read the directions!
* Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work
* Use clamps when possible
* It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-)
* This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface

Highly recommended!

Not as expected. The rubber foam tends to crinkle and crunch up around the door. The adhesive sticks very well, but when opening and closing the door, the gasket tends to crunch up a leaving the seem around the door in a state that will eventually leave a gap large enough to allow insects to penetrate the opening/s. We bought enough gasket to go around two doors (two packs) and at first, the gasket seem to workout well. But then after a couple of weeks, the gasket started to buckle and crinkle up. So far, I have been able to adjust the gasket to close the gaps, but after a few times of opening and closing the doors, the gaps return.

Note to self: Keep looking for a better solution to close the gaps around the exterior doors.

This is my first electric powered toothbrush so I was not sure what to expect. It takes a lot longer than 2 minutes (around 5 minutes or more) for me to brush properly with this brush and cover all tooth surfaces. When I am done, my teeth do feel "squeaky clean", a feeling that would require a ton more brushing with regular non-electric brushes. I don't like the automatic indicator feature on this brush that indicates when to stop brushing a particular side and switch to the other side. The brush actually stops spinning for a second and it feels like an interruption to me.  I am almost NEVER done when the indicator comes on to give the signal for a switch.

Brushing with the electric brush is MESSY - way more messy than brushing with a regular brush. A number of other reviewers have complained about the difficult cleaning of this brush. I have no such issues. I simply take the whole brush head part off the brush base and rinse both the brush head and the metal base that holds the brush head in the water before leaving them on my bathroom counter to dry. Recharging takes an entire day but when fully charged, I can use the brush for nearly a week (once a day) before the red-light-indicator for recharging comes on.

Overall I am happy with this brush. I think the lesser features there are on electric brushes the more functional they are. This is one of the simpler brushes on the market but I wish it didn't have the annoying timed-interruption "feature".
The product itself is very good, but it was priced way too high. I can buy the mouthwash at my dentist office for about half.

I returned 1 of 2 that I ordered. I explained the shipping issues in my complaint and put in a reorder request. I also asked that the new box of staples be taped up more securely. The return process was very easy and the new order arrived quickly however it came just as poorly packaged as the first. The product is great, that shipping could leave you staples less for weeks. When I bought my cheap Harbor Freight table saw (these used to be sold by Craftsman for almost twice the price) I knew better than to expect to do a nickel test.  When I finished tuning it, finally getting the blade square and pulley's aligned, it was still a 'nickel launcher' rather than anything you could consider smooth.  I took off the drive belt and took a closer look and found that it was about 30% thicker at the splice.

So I KNEW the PTP would help...KNEW it would solve much of the problem.  And it did... beautifully.  I doubt it would start and stop with a nickel standing on it (at 3hp it snaps to life) but there's no vibration now while it's running.

BUT BEWARE:  I bought my PTP in spring, but in Texas, without air conditioning, it's not very enticing to work in my shop during the hottest part of the summer, so I tend to only rush in and out to do small jobs.  I walked in the other day and found I'd left the blade all the way up, which leaves full tension on the belt, and since the motor is heavy and spring loaded, it had stretched the belt and was sitting at the bottom of the range.  I lowered the blade height and oops... no blade spin.

Soooo, I took the belt off and removed a link and she's good as new, but I'll have to remember to run the blade all the way down each time so it doesn't happen again!  I'm horrible at remembering to detension my bandsaw as well, so I'm predicting it will happen again.

Don't get me wrong, I'm still happy as can be with the little marvel of a belt and will buy them anytime I have a v-belt causing trouble.  I just wanted to pass on this one caution to the other users down in the hot hot summerlands.  Good luck and happy woodworking!

Ed

I debated giving it a 4 star because it does seem accurate.  However, it's difficult to set up in a fashion that allows you to measure something low - around the level of the base. In my case, I want to measure runout on a table saw blade.  I got it to work after fiddling with it, but the next time I use it some more fiddling will definitely be involved. The easiest way to set it up for that purpose has the dial facing down towards the table so it cannot be read.

I can attempt to create an alternate base for it, but hate to forego the magnetic base.  Also, the attachment point for the dial is dead center in the back, so any alternate base will have to make allowance for that.  Finally, my unit is missing a washer and has a completely different style nut for attaching the dial to the base.  The diagram says the nut should have a slot in it allowing you to tighten it with a screwdriver.  Mine is simply knurled and ends up close enough to the dial that I can't grip it hard enough to tighten it very well.  The end result is it's hard for me to get it firmly attached with no slop.

I only used one ampule for both trays, sometimes a little more (I used 5 ampules all together). By the fourth go around I was dreading having to have to do it again because my gums hurt so bad. I know it says to avoid skin, but there is no way you can completely avoid your gums, otherwise you won't whiten all of your teeth. First I have a clarification of the Product Description.  The bottom surface of the workbench top is not "satin smooth".  The bottom surface is somewhat rough, though this is unlikely to cause anyone any grief.

Mine arrived with a couple of dings in the top surface.  The larger one was obviously caused during shipping, as there was a hole in the box.  The other, a two-inch long groove, I'm uncertain about.

I was hoping for a flatter surface overall, though I didn't know what to expect from the Product Description.  The 30x60-inch surface on mine is quite flat along its length, but I have 1/8-inch of curvature along the width--the center is 1/8" lower than the edges.

The Slim Guide calipers are a decent alternative to the Lange or other, higher end calipers.  While not quite as accurate, you will get a similar reading on this $20 version as you do on the $150-$300 calipers, as long as you are a reliable, experienced tester.

While I recommend spending the extra money for the best calipers that produce the most accurate results, these aren't bad for someone just starting out.

A review based on use with mortar, bricks and paving slabs.

My mother has a wisteria in a brick planter / rockery, constructed from semi engineering bricks topped with cut paving slabs all the way around. This was built around 3 years ago and all the cut slabs had become loose.

Now in an ideal world, I would have simply removed all the mortar and stuck back down with fresh mortar. The problem with this method is a possibility of breaking a slab when chipping off the mortar and the fact that the slabs she bought at the time were end of the line and are no longer available.

In the past with this sort of situation, I would have just removed the slab dusted the mortar and stuck back down with weather proof exterior PVA glue. Ive done this several times over the years and it has always dried solid and firm in a day or two and years later each slab is still stuck down. However, repairing a single loose slab is a rather different prospect to doing several adjoining slabs in one go with PVA. It has no grab and takes an age to set which can easily result in movement and is susceptible to the effects of the weather.

In fact, if I were to have done this I would probably have done one slab per day, waiting for the previous to have dried before doing this next. As such I needed something to do the job that dried quickly to enable me to do it all in one day, and after a little searching I decided upon Gorilla Glue.

Based on my experience with the glue I would offer the following observations.

Gorilla glue is carcinogenic, it does not state this anywhere on the product information about this so be warned.

The glue is a slightly viscous but very runny liquid that looks like Rowse honey, and if you apply the glue vertically it will run, if you apply on the underside of something it will drip.

The best way to describe this glue is to compare it to Soudal fixing foam thats super concentrated and had all the moisture removed that gets activated and foams by adding water. If applied as per the instructions it starts to expand within about 15 mins and continues to do so for over an hour. I strongly advise that you should babysit your work until it is fully cured.

The product description states that the glue expands 3 times its size, the bottle states that it expands to 3-4 times its size, the fact is it expands to more like 6-8 times its size. I used on top of bricks to adhere a slab on top, in this situation a thin bead in the middle of the brick not going within 1 of the edges is the optimal solution.

Anything that the glue comes into contact with while in liquid form (brick, mortar, slabs, skin) will turn black. If you get the glue on anything not intended use white spirit and a nylon brush to remove, this will sadly not prevent black staining but it appears that white spirit makes the glue inert and prevents it from foaming and  removes the glue from the surface.

When gluing the 3rd slab down I suffered a glue run which covered almost an entire brick, I managed to clean it off quickly enough, but the brick went black, I tried to jet wash, then scrubbed with soap, then white spirit and in desperation tried muriatic acid twice and nothing worked, I just ended up with a slightly faded and mostly black brick.

When the glue is dry it can be treated in the same way as expanding foam, it can be cut, sanded and filled if required.

SO HOW STRONG IS IT ?
----------------------------------
This glue has no initial grab; it is not that sort of glue. The items being glued can easily be manipulated for up to 30-45 mins after applying the glue, I would advise against doing so after 15 mins however, and is rock solid within 2 hours.

Roughly 2 hours after applying I yanked the corner of one of the slabs upwards with all my strength, while Im no weight lifter at 61, a 44 chest and weighing 17 stone I consider myself stronger than average. This amount of force would easily have disjointed a slab laid with mortar, yet the slab held down with gorilla glue did not budge.

Since it has been in place it has suffered torrential rain, 24c direct sunlight and several nights of ground frost and I am glad to say is as secure as the day it dried.

SEPERATING THE GLUE.
----------------------------------
The day after I had laid all the slabs back on top of the planter I found that one was uneven, and I did not want to leave it as it was. Being very careful with a 4lb hammer and masons chisel I was able to separate the bond, I started at one end with a few taps, and worked my way around to the other edge and then went back to the start and repeated until it came loose.

Given the strength of the glue I would seriously advise against just taping the chisel through in one place until the slab comes loose as it is a very real possibility that if you do you will crack the slab in half. I would compare it trying to remove a large ceramic tile intact from a wall that has been stuck on with decent adhesive.

PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT.
-------------------------------------
Wear gloves, I used a pair of latex gardening gloves and they protected my hands fine, at first I wore a pair of latex gloves underneath but found it was not necessary. If you get any glue on your gloves, pour a tiny bit of white spirit on the glove and rub the palms together and this will prevent transfer to anything you are handling.

Wear a long sleeve top, I did not and even as careful as I was I still got a tiny blob on my arm, if this happens to you use white spirits to remove and then wash with soap and water.

Wear a dust mask, I was using the glue outside in the open and used a P3 mask that filters 99.95% of airborne particles yet still suffered throat irritation for several days after use.

CONCLUSION.
--------------------
This is a hard one, the adhesive properties of Gorilla glue are undeniable, but not without cost. This stuff is exceptionally hazardous and there is no amount of pressure, money or other incentive that would make me use this indoors ever.

I would strongly advise against using in a situation where should it run, it would ruin the finish of the items being worked on.

Given the same situation again, I would use my old tried and tested method of weather proof PVA for the job, there is just no way that I would consider using this again, the risks just outweigh the benefits it offers.

If I were to review based on my experience I would only give it 3/5, however I can see that it has many useful uses that I would consider it for in future should the need arise. I would go so far as to recommend keeping a small bottle handy in the shed as I can not think of a better product for emergency weatherproofing repairs in the middle of a storm.

As such I am more than happy to give it a 4/5, as it does do nearly everything it says on the tin.

This has admittedly been a rather one sided review based on my use thus far I do hope however that you have found some part of this review of use and I wish you well in your upcoming projects.

The downside:  It foams up as it sets, expands and turns light yellow and bubbly, so it's not really for use where it will be seen.  It cures by absorbing moisture from the air so it may take a long time to set in very dry areas.  And no matter how tightly you cap it, it will eventually harden in the bottle, wasting all you haven't used.  I don't use it often so I end up throwing away 95% of the gorilla glue I buy because of this.

After conducting extensive research on which tape to buy for an upcoming home move, I learned that there is a big difference between "packing" tape and "packaging" tape. Apparently the "packaging" tape is the type of tape that works best on taping up boxes and is supposed to not peel up as "packing" tape tends to do. I decided on going with the recommended "packaging" tape listed here but had the same issue as I have previously had with "packing" tape. Within two hours the tape peeled up off of the boxes that had been packed, leading to much frustration. Due to the great reputation of the 3M brand (I love many of their products) I decided to go with their recommended item. I only ended up using 2 yards of the very first roll and quit using it. The remaining rolls are untouched and sitting in the garage never to be used. I ended up using the cheap/thin tape that the moving companies use and have had much better success. Side note: I am also a small online business owner and need a dependable tape to ship products with peace of mind. Scotch Heavy Duty Shipping Packaging Tape, 1.88 Inches x 54.6 Yards, 6-Rolls (3850-6)

I bought this toothpaste due to the positive reviews it received and the price at which Amazon was selling it when I made my purchase. As far as the toothpaste itself goes, I agree with the majority that it whitens and cleans my teeth as good or better than any other toothpaste I've used before. What I don't like, is the product packaging and the result of the formula used with this toothpaste.

When I first opened the box for the toothpaste, I noticed that the tube was very "tight". After reading the back of it, it mentions that due to the chemicals used, they will release gas and cause the tube to expand, which is nothing to worry about; however, upon opening the lid to my first tube, the pressure inside the tube forced about 1/3rd of toothpaste in the tube out and into my sink. I haven't gotten to my 2nd tube yet, and maybe there's a way to get the gas to accumulate at the top of the tube before opening it, but there was no warning on the package that this could/would occur and frankly it will be pretty annoying if it does it for the remaining tubes. I'm sure someone will comment with "It never happens to me, you must be opening it wrong", but besides randomly massaging the tube trying to get gas to the top, there's not much else I can do to prevent it.

So, not only is this toothpaste more expensive than other brands (maybe justifiably so) keep in mind that there is the potential for a large percentage of the toothpaste to uncontrollably exit when you first open it, thereby increasing the cost of the toothpaste even further. If anyone has found a way to prevent this from occurring, I'd love to hear it before I open my remaining tubes.

UPDATE on 5/1/2012 - I opened the 2nd tube some time ago and was able to prevent toothpaste from exiting by massaging it around and getting all of the gas near the opening. Unfortunately, I no longer use this toothpaste. After making it through the first tube and part of the second, I started to notice a trend of bad breath and a funny taste in my mouth. The taste in my mouth was similar to hydrogen peroxide and I made the assumption that this was also the cause of my bad breath. I switched to some cheap Crest from my local department store and the bad breath slowly went away. I'll see if I can get my girlfriend to use the rest of it. :)

Buy a caulk gun and use these larger tubes over the small ones - this will go much further for the $!  We use this type of caulk for doing windows, caulking between wood, etc.  This is NOT for bathrooms!  Cut a small slanting tip off the tube and this will work great.  Use Youtube if you are inexperienced with caulking - very easy and it makes a huge different for window seals and bathrooms!  We sealed some walls of a room that someone had built in our barn.  Worked great for keeping the dust out!
I got one with rough patch witch made it unsafe to use. Won't get this again just because QC didn't catch it.

As described, apparently a well known product for heavy gluing. My advice to the common crafter: READ the instructions! I thought it would work like common brown glues with which I was familiar, but it does not. You need to wet the two surfaces, and WEAR GLOVES!! If even a tiny amount gets on the skin, it spreads evenly over the entire hand and is very difficult to get off. After trying multiple remedies posted on the Internet, the only one that worked was to slather vegetable oil on my hands and use fine sandpaper to sand off the glue and the top layer of skin cells.

Do not buy the Shark Portable Steamer under any circumstances.  The trigger mechanism is defective and fails after a few uses, causing all of the steam to leak out uncontrollably, which is also exposes the user to a possible steam burn.  Euro-Pro Operating LLC does not stand behind its products.  They will not sell you a replacement trigger or hose assembly if it fails (and trust me, it will fail).  Instead, Euro-Pro wants you to spend $40 ($12.95 shipping + $27.00 "minimum" repair charge) to even look at it.  Replacement parts are an additional charge!  I can buy a competing product for the cost of Euro-Pro's "minimum repair" charge, shipping charge, + parts charge.  Euro-Pro's service after the sale stinks. I will not buy Shark Products or do business with Euro-Pro Operating LLC ever again.

This vacuum sure isn't like it's old predecessor upright.  Made entirely of plastic, it's a very cheap, flimsy design, and after assembling it I have to wonder how long the handle is going to stay together.  However, it does vacuum pretty good -- very strong suction -- for a vacuum of this price range.  I have two wonderful Oreck vacuums and this Eureka doesn't come close to the quality of an Oreck, but it also only costs 1/4 as much as an Oreck.  I bought the Eureka upright for a basement rec room and it's great for that.

One thing that the online description doesn't point out, but that the enclosed booklet states, is that this model is supposed to be used only on carpeting, not hard floors.  That makes no sense to me and I have already used it on my tile and my laminate flooring with no problems.  Can't figure that one out, because I had an early version of the Eureka upright for many years and it cleaned floors and carpeting equally well.  It was made entirely out of metal and lasted for decades.

All in all, this is probably a good "backup" vacuum to have on hand, plus is lightweight and easy to carry around from room to room.  The drawback for me is the poor quality of construction and concerns over how long the vacuum will stay together in one piece.

I purchased these wall jacks after doing research on them. I had used the same jacks 25 years ago and was pleased to find out they were still available. My crew and I framed 60' x 9' high walls, sheeted them and lifted with no problems at all. I would recommend that only skilled carpenters use them. you do have to know what you are doing.

We have used the cordless toothbrushes for decades.  This one rates as OK for one reason only.  The motor runs the brush head rather slow compared to the competition.  They must do this for a reason/purpose but after using the Oral-B's I prefer the old Oral-B's.  The one great aspect of this tooth brush is the heads it uses.  They are fat, varied texture to hit the spots and crevasses and goes deeper than the Oral-B's do.  Unfortunately the heads are specific to this brush.  I would love this brush head with the Oral-B's power.  Again, not sure why they made it this way as the faster spin is a great massage on the gum while brushing.  whoever decides that a weaker/slower motor was where to save money made a mistake.  Oral-B customers that moved away thinking this top brand would be good will return to Oral-B the next purchase.  And in case you wonder if this one was a fluke I returned the original believing it was defective.  The replacement was the exact same. Great head, mediocre performance.

Building a house by all by myself, in a developing country where labor is let's just say not very laborious. Even if I had a big crew of men, I would still prefer these as they allow for fine adjustments at my own pace.

These puppies rule. I can lift a 30 foot or larger segment of wall, with osb on, while drinking a cup of coffee and enjoying the view. 40 foot long is as brave as I have gotten with no sheathing.
