I could not find a 2x4 that length, but was able to buy a 2x6 and rip it down. when they say 3.5 inches, they mean, 3.5 inches. I cut my 2x4 to 3 3/4 at first, but it ended up binding as it lifted, which is spooky to have tap with a hammer to get them going again while under a 1,000 pounds or so. Never an indication however that they might slip back, or fail.

I have two different lengths of pipe handle. One is about 5 feet long to help keep you out of the "kill zone" longer until the wall is mostly in a stable upright position.

I also bought the wind hooks, and the floor plates. the floor plates are totally worth it as you try to position this super tall piece of 2x4 by yourself with one hand. the wind hooks, you could likely just get by with a piece of cable and a simpson strong tie to do the same thing. Still, nice to have. I don't hesitate to lift walls on a really windy day.

The tape does not stick to my cardboard boxes. Seriously, I wish I would have read these reviews before buying the tape, but why should I research reviews of tape before I buy it? I went to the store, this was the priciest tape and said "heavy duty" so I assumed: best tape!

Big mistake. So the thickness is 20 times as strong as other tapes? Who cares if it doesn't stick to simple freaking cardboard boxes! I taped my boxes up one weekday evening, put them aside to move into my storage unit on the weekend, and then come Saturday I see the ends of the tape peeling away from the cardboard! Upon further inspection, the tape just peeled away from the cardboard without even stripping the top layer of paper! That is some lousy adhesive.

I'm just glad I noticed early how crappy this Scotch tape is, and I will always look for another brand now.

Scotch Heavy Duty Shipping Tape - AVOID!!!

There are a couple complaints from people saying how the glue didn't work on some other materials... like stone or ceramic.  That's not what this stuff is for... it's for wood.  Use it on wood, it'll do well. Very well.

The wood needs to be mildly moist, as this stuff reacts to moisture.  The wood needs to be clamped, as this stuff expands.  It's polyurethane foam, for the most part.  I haven't found another commercially available wood glue that works half as well as this does for it's intended purpose.

Be aware that the size stated includes the lip/thick edge, so the overall length is maybe 2 inches shorter than what it says. This really screwed me for a specific project I was doing. I bought one of these about 15 years ago and still use it frequently. However I often have to go looking for it because my wife uses it too. So I bought another one. Unfortunately, though the Amazon description and the one on General's site both claim there is a conversion table on the back, there most definitely is not. I have six other calipers, some digital, some purely mechanical like this one, some that read down to .001", some that read out in 64ths, but when I'm woodworking I always want my old General because it has that handy conversion table on the back that prevents me from making stupid mental mistakes when trying to convert 48/64" to 3/4". I went to General's customer support asking if they could either sell me an older model or give me a sticker to put on the back, but they just said it is no longer made with the table, they have no old stock, and have no stickers. I know this will sound trivial to some, but that conversion table is VERY useful and the whole reason I bought the product. I returned it to Amazon and they gave me a full refund. So I'll go back to using my other half dozen calipers when my wife is using the old General.

This is a very good strong bonding glue formula, but I find that its not valuable in some applications.  For example I used this to put a velcro patch on a piece of foam and it worked great.  I have stressed the patch and no problems.

I am from Texas and neither myself or anyone I know had ever seen or heard of these before. I am in the middle of rebuilding our home, after losing our original one to fire in late 2010, I read about these in a book from Taunton Press on Home Construction. I was able to erect 10' 2"x6" framed walls 25'-45' in length complete with OSB siding installed using only three people (one for a tagline). Absolutely incredible!
I raised the walls on a slab, so I had to use a different method than the instructions cover. Due to having already stained the concrete floors, they are essentially finished, and I couldn't use concrete fasteners to attach the bottoms of the jacks to the floor. In order to keep the jacks from kicking out from under the wall in the middle of the lift, I built a couple of small wood "sleds" for the jack bases to ride on. I tied the "sled" to the bottom of the walls with 1/4" steel cables, via a 3/4" hole drilled in the center of & about 4" from the bottom of the 2x6 stud inline with the jack. I propped the bases of the walls up with blocks in order to clear the anchor bolts, and they dropped right down on them. We use a 12# sledge to bump the base of wall into final position over the bolts, then removed the blocks. It worked great. Be sure to use a tag line, or some other way to stop over-travel. The wall will tend to try to fall away from the jack into and beyond the vertical position when it gets to within about 10 degrees from plumb at the end of the lift.
Also VERY important!! Be sure the 2x4" used for the jack posts are flawless!! No knots or cross grained wood. You need very straight grain. These posts will have a lot of load on them, especially at the halfway part of the lift. Failure of one post will likely cause failure of the other one and at the very least damage your wall and possibly smash someone like a flyswatter. So be careful always stay out from under overhead loads.

This is a nice tool for use with an AC clamp meter for measuring AC currents.  There are two places one can put the clamp meter.  One is the  "1X" position, and the clamp meter will measure the actual current.  The other is the "10X" position, and the clamp meter will measure 10 times the actual current.  This is especially useful for measuring small currents.  I've had this line splitter for a few weeks now, and have used it many times.  The one problem I've had is that one of the 120 volt sockets does not always make a good connection - not sure which one.  This is sometimes a small nuisance, and then one just plays with the connections for a second and all is well.  Sometimes it is more of a pain.  For example, I was just doing measurements of the current carried by an attic fan.  My wife was downstairs watching the clamp meter for me while I was in the attic turning the fan on and off.  The attic fan was working, and then all of a sudden it wasn't working.  I didn't know if I had tripped a circuit breaker or what.  So, I got down from the attic, and tried wiggling the contacts to the Extech - I heard the fan come on.  At least, I've learned to check it first if there are problems.  It's a good and useful tool, but it does have this quirk.  Maybe yours will not.  Incidentally, I am an electrical engineer.

The description on Amazon says that these work with doors up to 1 3/8 inch thick.  On the actual package, they are made for doors up to 1 1/8 inch thick.  The package is correct.  With my custom made 1 3/8 inch thick doors, I had to move the mounting points over by 1/8 of an inch to prevent the corners of the door from hitting the door jamb.

Speaking of mounting points, if you follow the included instructions, the bottom of your doors will be 1/16 of an inch closer to the jamb than the tops, resulting in a 1/8" uneven gap between the two mounted doors.  Another modification by moving the bottom mounting points out 1/16 to make the doors plumb.

I am a custom woodworker with many years of experience.  Luckily I have the know how to do a test mount on scrap first.  If I had not done this, the custom saloon doors that I just made would be ruined with incorrect mounting holes.  Some epoxy and sanding later, I could have corrected the problem, but this should not be necessary.

If you are purchasing these hinges, be sure to do a test mount first to determine if they will work for your application.

Here are my modified instructions for those that are interested:

The edge of the top hinge that attaches to the door should be 7/16" as stated for doors up to 1 1/8" thick.  For doors up to 1 3/8 thick, change this to 5/16"

The edge of the bottom hinge that attaches to the door should be 1/4" instead of the stated 5/16" for doors up to 1 1/8" thick. This will ensure that the doors have an even gap between the jamb.  For doors up to 1 3/8" thick, change this to 1/8" instead of 1/4".

The mounting instructions for the jamb side are the same as the instruction manual.  There are also slots on one of the hinges for adjustment though this is never mentioned in the instructions.

The flat head screws are used in the recessed holes and the round head are used for the other holes.  This may seem like common sense, but should also be mentioned in the instructions as some people may not know this.

I have not yet mounted them the doors jambs, just a test piece.  With the test piece, the doors only return to center when opened one direction.  I am hoping that this is because my test piece is not plumb and level.  If they work the same after the final mounting, I will update this review.

Overall, the product seems to be OK, but the instructions are very poor and could ruin a set of doors if a test fit was not done first.

I purchased the Steam Fast SF-275 and did not get what I was expecting. After doing a lot of research on steam cleaners, I thought this one would be great. First, it is misleading to state that this product has on-board storage. Its tiny store compartment barely holds the little brushes it comes with and they get really hot because the storage is on top of the heating element. Below I will state the pros and cons of the unit. This product is not all bad; it just wasn't what I was expecting.

Pros:
 Rolls on wood/tile floors well
 Puts out decent for cleaning minimally dirty surfaces (floors/countertops); but doesnt consume enough power/pressure to clean major areas (dirty grout)

Cons:
 There is NOWHERE to store the power cord. You can't even wrap it around the unit and expect it to stay.
 There is no storage for ANY of the accessories except for the 6 little brushes. It would be hard not to eventually lose some of the parts.
 It has NO low water indicator
 The handle gets pretty hot while in use; wear a glove.
 Doesn't work very well on ovens, probably due to the 36 PSI.
 The squeegee is supposed to also be a garment steamer, but that is impossible.  The squeegee practically pours out  water. I'm not sure if mine is broken or if that is the way it was made.
 You can't refill the unit until it is shut off and cools down (30+ minutes).
 There is no way to control the amount of steam the unit produces; you cannot increase/decrease the amount of steam that comes out.
 The cloth used with the floor attachment barely stays on.

Overall, if you want something to do light cleaning with, this would be a great product. I was expecting something that could really cut through some extremely dirty surfaces, but could also steam garments, but that is not what I got.

I'd like to start by saying that I personally found this gas can very easy to use - the design is far superior to many of the plastic cans on the market today. The plastic cans have one key advantage however: they are not painted!

I purchased one of these cans about a month ago to replace the one I've been using for my lawn mower and filled it with out issue. Other than filling the tank of my lawnmower once every weekend It's not seen much in the way of work. I haven't even re-filled it yet! This past weekend when I went to fill my tank, I happened to notice (thankfully before I started pouring) that there were red paint flakes around the rubber gasket. Not sure why the manufacturer decided to paint the black rubber gasket, but now that paint is flaking off into the steel mesh filter (which is at least catching some of the larger ones). Unfortunately I've not been able to remove the filter, and so I had to pour through another filter to get those the red paint flakes out of the can.

I like the design and it's still usable, which is why I'm giving it two stars, but needing to poor everything through a filter is a pain, especially for a brand new can that I paid nearly $40 for! I'm going to try to contact the seller to see if they will replace this unit. Hopefully it's just paint over-spray (defective) and they replace it. I'll adjust my review accordingly depending on how that goes.

I like Rembrandt toothpaste. It doesn't leave a "film" in my mouth like some other toothpastes seem to, and my teeth did become noticeably whiter after a couple of weeks.

A big problem I have is with the tubes they are using. They are a hard plastic and it makes it difficult to squeeze the toothpaste out. Because this product is so expensive you're going to want to get every last little bit out of the tube, but that's incredibly difficult because of the toughness of the tube.

Because this is 3 to 5 times more expensive per ounce than other toothpastes, if you are considering using it I would suggest you do a little research before buying. Regardless, shame on the Rembrandt people for not using better packaging in such a high-end product.

The hole punch does not work.  After much pounding (with a rubber mallet per the instructions), I wound up with a "hole" that was in fact one or more ragged tears tangential to the edges of where the hole should be.  When the grommet was attached, it didn't cover the ends of all of the tears completely.

I gave the punch three tries on tarp and got the same results.  For the second and third tries, the hardwood backing that comes with the kit was held in place securely by cleats.  The material was secured over the hardwood piece with small clamps on either side.

For a fourth try I used a hand paper punch that cut a clean hole slightly smaller than the one the grommet tool is supposed to cut.  It worked fine anyway.

If you decide to buy this tool set, get a paper punch that's about the right size, if you can find one.  Otherwise, you stand a good chance of tearing your material.

Although the grommet worked fine once a clean hole was cut, I gave the entire tool set only one star because the hole punch can cause damage.
I would strongly recommend that if you are moving anything over 50lbs you avoid this product and go with a 4 (or more) wheel design.
This paper lasts and lasts. I have done over a dozen sandings with one sheet cut to fit my pad sander and the grit is still usable for even more sanding. Highly recommended.

Its a reasonable caliper.  Its good to hundredths of an inch for metalwork and 1/64ths for woodworking.  My only issue is the needle on mine was bent about the width of the needle blade itself between the fractional and decimal scales .. which means I have to rezero it for changing scales.  If actual thousandths was wanted, the company should swap the locations of the fractional and decimal scales (which would be a reasonable thing to do regardless, considering the decimal scale has greater accuracy than the fractional 1/64ths).  Swapping the scale locations would give the caliper accuracy to .001 instead of a mere .01(5).  Still, not bad for the price.

The grommet fastening tool works fine.  The tool and wooden block supplied to cut the holes in the fabric, not so much.  The hole cutting thing is basically a metal tube with a moderately sharpened end.  You pound it into the fabric with the wooden block as a backing to hopefully cut a neat hole in the fabric which is then grommetted with the other tool.  The problem is the sharpened hole cutting tool is not very sharp and seems to dull after maybe 30 grommets.  The result is an incomplete cut which you then need to finish with a pair of scissors, and its hard to get a clean cut that way.  And pounding away at this tool to try to get a decent hole destroys the wooden block underneath leaving splinter refuse underneath, further eroding the ability to get a clean cut.

The instructions say its not meant for "industrial use" or whatever, clearly indicating you're not supposed to use it a lot as it will lose effectiveness.  You can sharpen the cutting tool and get a new block of wood at Lowe's but I was hoping for a self contained kit that would go the distance.

Cheap knock-offs.

The package is a obviously some non-Braun, cheap third-party. It's a weird, amateurish blue. On the front, in cheap-looking yellow type it says, in German, "4 brush attachments. Fit for all current eletric toothbrushes," but with grammatical mistakes like the ones you see in spam:

"4 STCK Zahnbrstenaufstze.
Passed fr alle gngigen Elektrozahbrsten"

Grammatical errors:
1) Why is "stck" all caps?
2) The first sentence ends in a period, the second does not.

At the bottom of the package it says in poor English: "Replacement brushes to be used with Electro toothbrushes that fits." No way an international company like Braun would write like that.

On the back of the package is a sticker with a bar code that reveals that these brush heads are not made by Braun. It reads: "Braun Oral-B Compatible Ge...ent Power Toothbrush Heads New".

The real Braun brushes have an inner ring of bristles different from the outer bristles; on these knock-offs, all the bristles are the same.

So it's up to you, but my feeling is: if I've already shelled out extra money for a toothbrush that is supposed to clean better than a hand-held one, why pay to make it no better by putting plain old tooth brush heads on it?

Be careful when you buy an item like this. It's important to buy the model that is designed for compact fluorescent bulbs. This particular model is designed for incandescent bulbs. As the sun hits the light sensor, it begins to flicker and  to dim and eventually turns off by mid-day. The sensor is essentially behaving like a dimmer. Sometimes light from the bulb itself will reflect into the light sensor and result in dimming of the bulb.

Choose a different brand or model that is designed to be used with compact fluorescent lightbulbs. Because electricity through the sensor flows in an all or nothing fashion, the bulb will not appear to be dimmed. Like all of these automatic dawn to dusk controllers, any light that reflects into the sensor can still affect the function of the device; in my case it was causing intermittent blinking or random on/off behavior.

Many factors affect the function of these devices. Sometimes it's the shape and color of the light fixture. Sometimes it's the length of the light bulb or intensity of the bulb. I also don't like the appearance of the lightbulb after it is lengthened by this device. My solution was to buy a different model/brand (from a big box store) designed for compact fluorescent bulbs. I wrote a review of a similar product and I find it works when I use short LED bulbs. Your mileage will vary.

I had been a user of bagless vacuum (Infinity) for 4 years and had enough of messy job of emptying the canister. I also had to wash the filter more often. I received the Electrolux Home Care 1934B (yes, what you get is the newer model B, not A) vacuum just yesterday. I had it easily assembled in 10 minutes. This vacuum is as simple as it gets and it does its job very well, which is cleaning. It is relatively quiet compared to my previous bagless vacuum. The top of the vacuum has a knobble to adjust the hight of the rotating brush. I use setting 4 on my carpet, which guarantees very easy movement over the carpet while doing a good job on the "brushing" side. The cleaning results are great and consistent throughout the cleaned area. It also does a good job on reaching the corners and picking up dirt where my previous vacuum failed.

For cleaning the stairs, I strongly recommend purchasing the extension set here at Amazon. The extension "snaps" to the bottom of the vacuum and is very easy to use.

If you are looking for good vacuum without all the bells and whistles (and complexity) of the expensive machines, I definitely recommend this vacuum.

The switch toggle lever is stiff to operate which leads to the switch loosening and rotating on the panel which in turn loosens the wire terminal screws.

They have a twisting barrel that makes the metal probes go in and out of the insulated sleeve and the probe points are anything but sharp.  I guess one too many morons electrocuted themselves and the C.P.S.C., OSHA, or some other big-bother (Yeah, that's right!) organization told the manufacturer to better make them safer. Don't buy this. This is very poor quality.  I used this with my Makita LXT 18V 4" grinder, 10,000 rpm max.  This wheel is rated to 20,000 rpm. I only used the weight of the tool, and very light pressure.  After this time the twisted wire was worn down to 1/2 its original length.  This is from the wire wearing down quickly, untwisting, and the ends breaking off.  This is dangerous and you must wear a full face shield.  I had a least a dozen wire ends impact the face shield, and I was using only very light pressure on a rounded smooth surface. You must also wear a long sleeve shirt.  I took my long sleeve shirt off, and one of the wires that broke off hit my upper arm, and left a big welt.  If it had hit my arm point first it, it would have embedded itself into my arm.
DO NOT BUY THIS WIRE WHEEL, LOOK FOR A DIFFERENT MANUFACTURER, DEWALT IS NOT GOOD QUALITY.  I purchased by price, and Dewalt is traditionally mediocore quality.  I should have bought a MAKITA branded wire wheel.

I've used Gorilla Glue to repair everything from loose chair legs to broken sculpture. Two caveats. One, it increases it's volume as it dries and can ooze out, so don't go crazy and squirt it around like Elmer's Wood Glue, or you'll have a mess on your hands in an hour. Second, don't mistake this for Crazy Glue. You can't just press two surfaces together and imagine it's bonded. The surfaces need to be held together securely with a clamp or other securing arrangement. Take those precautions and you should find it creates a very strong bond. Because of it's expanding characteristic, it's especially good at holding loose objects together that perhaps have a gap to fill, as in wood joints.

I used to use the oral b toothbrushes and then decided to venture out and try others. After reading the reviews on Amazon, decided to give the Spinbrush Pro a spin. After 3 weeks, I am retiring the Spinbrush and returning to Oral B.

The head of the brush is much larger than the head of the oral b brushes. The smaller head is much easier to use and reaches the various crevices that a normal brush and the spinbrush can not get to.

The spinbrush is also very harsh on the tooth enamel - much more so than the oral b models. The powerful motor - a gas guzzler by all accounts - is too powerful for me. It's also a little too noisy.

If you really want to get this one instead of the oral b, would suggest giving the soft bristles version a whirl instead - the softer bristles might be a little less abrasive on the enamel than this is.

But the price and the fact that it does do its basic job - cleaning teeth - keeps me from giving it a 1.

My husband and I wanted to whiten our teeth so we purchased 2 kits, one for each of us. I tried the Rembrandt kit while he was at work. Thank goodness I tried it first!  I read the instructions carefully, and took note of tips from others' reviews to reduce reported discomfort. The instruction packet informs you that it may cause tooth and gum sensitivity that should disappear after 2 days. Hmm...okay, noted.

I started the 4- 20 minute sessions. During the 2nd session, I started to feel some discomfort, but nothing I couldn't manage. The 3rd and 4th sessions had increased discomfort, but I stuck throuh the 20 minute session for each.  I followed the directions exactly, with 10 minute- 20 minute breaks, and rinsing my mouth in between treatments. Afterward, my mouth was a bit sore- but the real pain was a few hours later.

Starting 2 hours or so after I completed the treatments, I felt an intense tenderness in my gums and whenever I moved my mouth (to eat, drink, smile, etc.). What I found in the mirror were streaks of my gums that appeared to have been burned off. I looked on the inside of my lips, and the same thing- streaks of skin that looked burned by acid. I am not a doctor, but the above description is the best I can explain what I saw and how my mouth felt. As I write this review it is 34 hours after I did the treatments, and I am peeling pieces of my (burnt) gums and skin from my mouth. Needless to say I threw away my husband's kit.  I am much more tolerant of pain than he is, and had he done this treatment with me, I can't imagine what he would be going through. I have been on a liquid diet since, because it is too painful to chew food around my burning, tender gums and mouth.

I do not have sensitive teeth, or gums. I have excellent dental health, so the excessive damaging and painful effects of this products made me feel like I owe it to other consumers to share my experience before you make a decision on this product. I do not recommend this to any consumer. Ever.

The PowerTwist Plus V-belt is often advertised as quieter, smoother running and with a far longer lifespan. Lifespan I can't measure but here's what I experienced with the first two qualities:  As an audio buff I used my sound level meter to measure dB sound reduction on my 6-month old Dewalt 746 tablesaw, Forrest II sawblade, before and after PowerTwist belt installation.  At the level of the operator's head the "before and after" decibel level was 81 and 81... no difference.  Two feet behind the saw at the level of the belt (below the table surface) the dB rating decreased from 93 to 92, a neglible amount.  Vibration was reduced - sensed by finger touch to the tabletop, and by using an old (and outdated) method of balancing car tires: viewing a glass of water placed on the tabletop surface, i.e., the size of the water-surface rings generated by the vibration.  Though the original vibration level wasn't a significant issue with this saw... it was reduced by, I'd guesstimate, 50%.  Possibly on old machines (using old belts) the vibration improvement would be greater. Excessive vibration possibly could cause sound harmonics... generating additional sound.  In an industrial situation with machinery running non-stop, the PowerTwist belt's extra cost, versus life span, is undoubtedly justified. In other instances, simply replacing an old belt with a new one would probably prove a better dollar value.

If you're going to use this tool, here's what I found works very well. Use it to hold the plank at the far end, nail your plank on at the other end and then go to the tool end and remove it and nail on the plank, then fill in the nails inbetween the ends, works really well with far fewer blow throughs. The lock works fine, but the steel is noticeably lighter than a REAL HD 3" caster and the axle is only about 1/4" vs approx 3/8" on a HD one (remember that all Pacific Rim imports are metric).  Wheels are rounded like donuts and don't ride on a wide flat surface.  I bought them to compare to a set of HD casters I got at a local woodworking show which cost almost double.  I am currently using them on a plywood dolly to hold my portable planer w/stand.  It's only used occasionally so I have not had any problems except the wheels are a bit loose & wobbly on the axles.  Overall, just okay.

I bought this fuel can because I wanted a quality metal can that would contain vapors in storage, and hoped it would be easier to deal with than other CARB compliant cans.  While it may be easier to pour from (haven't tried that yet), it has a couple of significant drawbacks for me, as a small person with not a lot of hand strength.

1.  The cap for the can is held down by a very strong spring, and to open the cap you have to hold onto the handle and pull back on a separate lever - much the same way as holding the safety bar to the handle of a lawnmower.  I found that I couldn't hold the can open with one hand and fuel with the other.  My solution was to use a tie wrap to fasten the lever to the handle to hold the cap open while fueling, and then cut it off when done.

2.  The flash suppressor is a mesh screen inside of the opening.  My usual way of dealing with full five gallon gas cans is to siphon half the contents into a 2-1/2 gallon can and use the smaller can to pour into whatever I'm fueling.  However, with the screen it's not possible to siphon from this can; I couldn't see a way to remove it for siphoning without destroying it.

I wish someone would sue CARB under the Americans with Disabilities Act for requiring these ridiculous mechanisms to prevent vapor loss. They are difficult for someone without a lot of strength to use, and would be impossible for someone with a disability.  The various measures that people have developed to work around the CARB requirements have probably released more vapors into the air than the old cans ever did.

For years I have used PC7 as my best all time glue, when I need stuff to really hold a permanent bond.  I heard people raving about this gorilla glue, so I figured I'd give it a try.  I needed to bond two pieces of stone together, and both were irregularly shaped.  Normally I would mix up some PC7, spread it, stick it together and wait overnight.  I wouldn't even have to clamp it, and the bond would be absolutely permanent.

With the Gorilla glue, since it foams and expands, I knew I had better clamp them, so I did.  I allowed the glue to cure for a full 48 hours, unclamped them and gave them a real hard test...  I pulled them apart with my hands!  Not very strong, at least in this situation.  I didn't even have to pull hard, just a little twisting motion and pop...

I'm sure this stuff has its uses, but it is nowhere near 'the strongest glue on earth.'  Maybe their slogan should be 'average glue with a catchy name...'

Rembrandt used to have this really wonderful whitening kit in a silver box that came with syringes.  I was so loyal to their kits over anything else. I have pretty white teeth to begin with, but every once in a blue moon I feel like they are lookin a little yellowy so I do a touch up. I searched high and low for my old faithful, and after reading reviews on this, decided to take the plunge. I was fully aware that my gums would be sensitive, but I'm not one to really care about that. In fact I was sort of excited when they were feeling sensitive thinking for sure it must be working. The end result. After two hours my lips feel pretty dry, my gums a little sore, and my teeth hardly able to notice a difference. I miss the old kit that you could put on for (i think it was 30 minutes) . The moldable trays that it comes with are still as awesome as they ever were, but the formula stinks. Not only that, but it's basically set p for a one time use, whereas the old syringes used to last me forever. I'm sure the Rembrandt company had to make this new kit so people would have to rebuy it since the old one was so awesome you hardly ever had to rebuy it, but i'm really disappointed. I'll be trying other options from now on.

I got it for the safety feature of self sealing spout and the fact that it would be "easier" to use than the usual plastic ones....it wasn't.  As a matter of fact, it was harder.  I found pulling against the return spring while trying to hold it just the right way for the gas to flow into what you want it to, exasperating.  Then, when there was about a gallon left in it, and I had it almost vertical, I dropped it. And wouldn't you know it, it fell right on the spout.  Did it bounce?  No.  Did it laugh off the the little mishap without a whimper?  Nope.  The top pushed down and the alignment between the spring loaded cap and the spout was lost forever.  Mind you, this was not from the top of a ladder, no siree.  A mere 2 feet to earth, not concrete. Oh well.  If you have a strong grip and can hold 10-40 pounds up without moving about, then this is the receptacle for you.

I'm surprised there aren't more complaints from users on how the brushhead's design traps toothpaste and mouth gunk (yuck!) inside its plastic shell- which can't be totally taken apart enough to get at the inner workings. Everyone is oohing and ahhing over the toothbrush's great performance (I don't disagree at all) but seem to overlook the poor design of the brushhead that allows gunk to build up quickly - even with a reasonably thorough "cleaning" following Sonicare's recommendations. They say nothing in the cleaning instructions on how to get into the areas beyond reach in the design.

I was hoping the Elite series  would have improved on the older Advance series design that was hard to keep clean but not so. I don't know about most people but I wouldn't put something near my mouth festering with bacteria and black mold. I rinse the brushhead, wipe it as dry as I can and remove it from the handle  after each use to air dry- but it isn't watertight so despite best efforts stuff will get into the inner part of the brush/magnet unit that is factory sealed (I'm not talking about the removable threaded part that screws into the handle). I have ended up taking apart the factory sealed part by bending the plastic tabs and giving the inner parts a good hot water bath and scrubbing with a q-tip. But the unit obviously isn't designed for the user to easily do this.  Maybe Sonicare figures their customers will be discarding the brushhead in 3-6 months or whatever they recommend so no big deal.

For what you pay for the unit this is a major design flaw IMO. They need to design a totally sealed brushhead- why can't they use o-rings, rubber gaskets or a tighter rubber/vinyl boot like they use now to keep the brushhead sealed but still leave it flexible to vibrate?

Oh I laughed at the one negative review of the travel case- I use that a lot and the reviewer is super-picky. It's sturdy and latches fine and the plastic in the hinges is made to bend a lot. The carry case will outlast the toothbrush if they only last a few years like many people are saying. (<:

This is the worst gas can I've ever used!  Just received it tonight.  I temporarily working in CA.  Amazon shipping would not ship any other fuel container to CA, so I saw the great reviews and bought this one.  There is another traditional 5 gal fuel jug that says it's CARB approved, but they will not ship it to CA either!.

First, the lid mechanism is spring loaded to the closed position by two very large springs.  It takes quite a bit of hand strength to open the lid.  There is no way my wife or grandson could open it.  They wouldn't even be able to put gas into the container with these stout springs.

Second, the yellow funnel arrangement seems nice on first glance, until you try to use it!  It mounts to the spout on a 90 degree angle so you cannot get the gas can tilted enough to get all the gas out.  My cars fuel filler spout (and most others) goes into the car at a 45 degree angle.  If I tilt the gas can all the way (sideways/90 degrees) the funnel interferes and wants to pop out of the 45 degree fuel neck (the funnel then wants to point straight down).  I could only get maybe 3 of 5 gallons out.  I tried to turn it sideways but it will only go so far.  I finally was able to get 4 out of 5 gallons out while spilling it all over my shoes, the side of the car, and the ground.

There needs to be a way to swivel the spout for different filler neck angles.  They also need to reduce the spring pressure on the spout and maybe add a safety lock to hold it down instead of that 50# of spring.

Now the good:  Its made pretty well and the steel is not as thin as I thought by reading some of the other posts.  It is compact and at first glance it does not look like 5 gallons, but it will hold 4.95.

Find an older designed gas can at a yard sale instead of this new design.

You nearly always get what you pay for.  I have looked (shopped extensively)around a lot before I bought these.... these are well worth the price.  They are what I would call a good heavy unit in the low capacity type of wheel assemblies.  You can always buy better than this, but you will pay at least double or more to what these will cost you.  Good deal for the money and reasonably well made too!
UPDATE: What I said above has been tested now.
Part 1:  I built a 200# 4ft. X 8ft. plywood work table and installed 6 of these assemblies to make it light and easy to roll.  Loaded it is about 250 to 300# max.  The wheels can't handle it well at all.  The problem is not the wheel itself, it is the chincy metal materials they used.  Soft, flexible, and bends rather than turn on the rollers, even on a flat new cement floor.  Sad. Data: 300# by 6 rollers = ~ 50 # each loading.... pretty over rated huh?!
Part 2:  I made a small cabinet for the Sander I bought on Amazon, and I used 4 rollers to easy the locating of the tool in my shop.  Wieghs about 100# with the sander: works perfectly.  DATA: 100# by 4 wheels = 25# per wheel.  Obviously, typical China Junk.... very overrated.  Listed to handle 220# loads each, and at 50# each they begin to fail.

Derate them by about 400% and you are just about right.  If you must have 50# or more on them, the metal is just tooooo soft and bendable.  Otherwise, just great.

Ineffective and glue hardens in bottle despite following instructions.

There are two very basic problems with this product, at least with my several different uses (i.e., different materials, wood, plastic, cloth, metal, etc.):  (1) It just does not hold up.  That is, it does not last long and is not very strong.  (BTW I follow the instructions *exactly*.)  (2) It very easily dries up in the bottle, even if you follow their instructions to try to get all the air out of it (which, by the way, seems impossible.)  I suppose this product *might* be useful if you were going to use it all up within a couple of weeks, but beyond that, it just does not do as advertised.

I hate writing a negative review, especially when obviously there are others who have had a much better experience.  Frankly, I cannot explain the difference in experience.

I would not buy this again, and wish I could return it and get a refund, but I'm past Amazon.com's cut-off.  Alas.

I also do not have an alternative to recommend, but another to stay away from is Sticky Ass Glue SAG4OZ Waterproof.  Same problems, similar product to Gorilla Glue.

If anyone out there can recommend something that REALLY works, I'd love to hear it.

REVISION, 1/17/2017:  Changed from 1 star to 3 stars (for customer service).  After getting the response from the Gorilla Glue company, I followed their suggestion and called their 800 number.  The woman I spoke to was very pleasant and very helpful, and said she would send me some more Gorilla Glue, this time in smaller containers than the 4 oz. bottle which, if you don't use it often, is more likely to dry out.  [RECOMMENDATION:  Buy the smaller bottle(s) unless you plan to use the whole bottle in about a year.]  ALSO NOTE:  They don't state on the bottle that the shelf life of GG is only 2 years, there is no expiration date on the bottle, and the date of manufacture is cryptic; see attached screen shot indicating "13", meaning a 2013 manufacture date, a black-font number printed vertically to the left of the gorilla on the front indicates the date of manufacture).  Had the bottle stated something like "This product is expected to last no more than two years.", along with an expiration date, I would have just lived with the problems I experienced.  The customer service rep told me that she would pass my suggestions on to management; let's hope they listen.

Nothing 'GITS 'ER DONE like Gorilla Glue! I was out on my daily hike here on the mountain last week and, down the valley at a lonely country crossroads, somebody had left a massive Tuscan-made, Della Robbia terra cotta sculpture just leaning against a tree. No kidding! The top portion of the piece had been broken-off entirely, and the much larger bottom portion was fully intact. Best of all, whomever left the pieces down at the junction had also left a plastic baggie filled with all (or most of) the chips that had broken off the sculpture. Clearly they didn't have the heart to throw this magnificent thing away, and I'm not surprised: the subject matter was probably meaningful to them (Nativity Scene) and Della Robbia sculptures of this size and quality can sell for well over $1,000.00 even after being repaired. Long story short: I hauled that 100-lb piece back up the 450-ft. hill for two hours, and then drove back down for the second piece. When I got it all home, I looked everything over in my garage workshop and said, "THIS is a job for Gorilla Glue!" and good old GG didn't let me down. After a few days of careful repair, I got it back in shape and will be able to retouch the few missing chips with ceramic paint easily enough. Easy to use as always, Gorilla Glue saved the day when it came to a truly unexpected and breathtaking "roadside discovery." AWESOME.

The fryer itself seems to work quite well.  I have used it twice with crinkle cut french fries and twice to make Korean fried chicken (wings).  It heats up the oil relatively fast and gets it hot (I measured with a thermometer at 380 deg F when set to about 190+C) and when the temperature dips when food is placed in it, it gets back to temperature fast.  However, the bar to hold the basket is a tad too high so you have to really fill it up 2/3 or 3/4 full with oil instead of the 1/2+ mentioned in the manual if you want to hang the basket off the fryer and let it cook.  Otherwise you can put the basked all the way in so it sits on top of the element, which works pretty good.  (And is what I did).  However, the handle does not stay on the basket (slips off and yes, I have it in correctly).  It does not lock in tight enough and then the bottom fingers work their way out on one side.  I can live with that inconvenience.  However, the biggest issue is that the basket is NOT made of stainless steel, as indicated in the description.  After using it the first time, I washed off the little pieces of cooked on starch from my Korean fried chicken and left it to air dry (in a dry climate so it dried quickly).  After I went to put it away I noticed the ends of the wire that makes up the wire basket had rust on them, as well as some of the "weld" junctures where the wire crosses to make the basket (don't know if there is an actual weld there or just wire crossing).  Second time I used it, I had a lot of cooked on starch from the chicken and had to soak for a while in hot soapy water to loosen it up, and there was a lot more surface rust on the basket when I pulled it out of the sink to scrub off the water loosened starch.  I touched it to my shirt by accident and there is now a big cross-hatch brown rust stain on my shirt.  The fryer works quite well but the basket rusting right off the bat ruined it.
It grinds concrete, what else can I say.
I returned the item it was to be used with.

First let me say that this is the best electric fryer I've owned, and I've owned a few. But not everything is perfect. The good points: The temperature gage is accurate. This baby will reach 375deg's for fry's. Large basket, deep removable fry tank with bottom plate that sits above the heating rods which the basket sits on when lowered. Nice long solid electric cord that's attached to the back of the unit. Not magnetic connections. Two different hanging heights for the basket. This fryer will take up the width of the counter. Every item is removable for cleaning.
Now the not so good point. Very thin sheet metal with sharp edges. No cut out for basket handle in cover. Would be nice to cover when frying. No side handles to move or position this fryer if filled and hot with oil. Sides and bottom are to hot to grab on too reposition. No side indentions in body top edge to remove oil tank. When tank is filled and you want to drain and replace with fresh oil, it is very hard to lift any side or end up from base to remove tank. Finger indentions in body top edge would help immensely. Basket handle hard to snap onto the basket. Plus the picture on instructions shows the handle going inside the basket bracket. It needs to snap around the outside of the basket bracket. I used up about 15 minutes trying to make it work going through the inside. Saw a correct picture of the basket on another web site. Now the blue thin removable plastic coating on the parts. This comes from the mill to protect the metal sheets from scratches. This is not put on by the fryer manufacture. I read some reviews complaining about this Saran Wrap covering. It's not that difficult to remove. I would have given this fryer 5 stars if not for what I stated.

Bought these nails for building a fence. Fit into my nail gun like a charm and worked fine. I think I just got the size wrong because the nail ended up going through the fence board and 2x4, but we already had the crew there and didn't have time to buy new nails so we just used them... =.= The 3 stars doesn't reflect my mistake in getting the wrong size nail. I just wanted to inform people that they should get 2" nails rather than 2-3/8". 2" will work better for a fence board and 2x4. We measured 3" with board and 2x4, but the force of the gun (even when at the lowest setting on the pressure possible to force the nail through) will jam the nail about 1/4" deep into the board itself which somehow makes the nail poke out. Anyway, the reason why I am giving it 3 stars is because after it rained, the nails started "leaking" some black streaks on our yellow cedar fence! Didn't realize until the first rain that it would do this...Hadn't seen this in any of the comments, so thought I'd share. BEWARE! May not be the best choice if you're working with cedar or a light wood. You may not see the streak on redwood if you use these nails. I also posted a photo of our nail gun model. Works really good if you guys are looking for a nail gun.

I use a lot of LocTite products.  I probably have 7 or 8 different types in my tool box as I need various strengths - and I need high temperature versions for my racing engines.

The problem with this item isn't what is inside the bottle, but the bottle itself.

I bought the larger bottle as I use 242 for lots of fasteners.

When this arrived, I snipped the tip of the dispenser, and used it.

Today I went to use it again, and nothing would come out of the bottle.

It seems there is some sort of indirect passageway for the fluid to come out of the bottle, I guess to help avoid exposure of the contents to the air, and the entire bottle thickening.

Evidently a bit of it did thicken up, and it blocked this passageway.

Tried everything I could think of to clear the openings, and could not get the product to dispense.

I finally took a very small drill and drilled a hole on the center of the bottom side of the dispensing tip.

Very annoying, and now I'm half expecting the product to solidify prematurely.

The stop collars are laughingly marked in .1mm increments but the screw nuts are so oversized that the slides will 'unwind' while in use. Especially bad was the Y slide - it had 1/8 turn slop in it with the stop collar adjusted as tight as it could get. This was helped somewhat buy putting a nylon washer between he collar and the nut.  The gibs don't take long to get out of adjustment. The whole base unit is light duty and without re-work is herky-jerky in movement.
  The best part is the vise. It's slop is controllable, the .625" Acme screw provides plenty of clamping power. Why they couldn't have made the slide screws with as close tolerance is anybody's guess. Would have added a star or two to the rating. Otherwise it's only slightly more useful than a plain old drill vise. Do not buy this thinking you can do any sort of precision work.

I first picked this up at a local store. I thought the price was cheap, and I needed the extra tooth whitening power. I also wanted fast results, so when I saw this package, I was excited at the opportunity to have whiter teeth in two hours.

I got home, and I opened the box. I read the instructions, and they were easy enough. I formed my tooth impressions in each tray, and I put one small tube of whitener in each tray. I put it in my mouth, and began the whitening process.

The first time, I was able to hold the tray in for the whole twenty minutes. I rinsed, and waited ten minutes, and then I repeated the cycle. The second time, I noticed that my gums were very sensitive. I made it to about fifteen minutes. The third time, I got to about ten minutes, and I was in a great deal of pain. My gums were sore, sensitive, and the parts near my gum line were white. The last time I only made it to ten minutes, and I was in a lot of pain. My teeth hurt very badly. I put some ice in my mouth after I had rinsed the gel out, and that helped.

The gel did work. My teeth were never horribly yellow, but I had some stains from increasing my coffee intake. This whitener works. My teeth were noticeably whiter after the use. I am sure that if I had been able to stand the pain for the whole cycles, my teeth would have been very white.

Overall, this product does work, but man, beauty sure does hurt. I would recommend this if you are going to need white teeth in a hurry, like for an event. But if you don't use the strips instead.

OK, here's the deal with Plasti-Dip. I found this on another website, and went through the colors one by one to develop the below table. Colors are identified by the digits just before the dash. So:

11601-6 = RED
11602-6 = YELLOW
11603-6 = BLACK
11604-6 = BLUE
11607-6 = WHITE
11609-6 = CLEAR

It took a little while to figure out the pattern. These part numbers are for the 14.5 fl oz dip, but the other types use the same two digit code (01-09) for the colors, and the other numbers change for the type (aerosol, etceteras).
Be cautious you are ordering the properbags for your vac!

I'm writing from the perspective of a cabinetmaker.  This glue may work for your particular projects, but here's why it's no good for cabinetmaking:

1) It foams.  It foams a LOT!

2) The foam stains the wood.  Wiping it off sort of helps, until you apply stain/varnish a week later and the stain appears a radically different color wherever you let the glue/foam touch the wood.

3) It's not as strong as alphatic resin (wood glue).  Some will argue with this statement, but glue together four pieces of wood, two with alphatic resin, two with this stuff.  Now smash them both.  This stuff fails on the glue joint, whereas the alphatic resin will take a signifficant portion of the wood with it.

4) It's three times as expensive as wood glue.

5) It takes longer to use, since you have to moisten (with water) the two workpieces to be joined.

6) It requires a longer clamp time than wood glue.

Some will say that with practice these concerns can all be mitigated, but I've got enough trouble just training employees not to cut their fingers off in the table saw - Now I've got to "train" someone how to use glue?  No Thanks.

The tape I got sticks to the dispenser too well and if I can get the tape on the package it will stick there too.  The difficulty is getting it on the package.  I've used packaging tape for years in a standard big handheld dispenser and never had so much trouble applying the tape as I have with this type.  I find it very hard to get it to stick to the package when I first put it down there in order to pull the dispenser back and thus dispense the tape.  It seems the tape gets too strongly attached to the dispenser part to release.  If I can use two hands to get it going, it usually then releases with a whirl and I get a mile of tape which then tends to wrinkle at the cutting blade and won't cut.  It's so wrinkled and stuck to itself by then, it isn't suitable for the package. The frustration finally got to me so I bought the Duck brand tape which works much better for me.

I had several rolls of this stuff left though so I purchased that very heavy desktop dispenser that also holds standard tape and a few pens.  Voila, this tape does really well in that dispenser.  I can pull it out easily and cut just the amount I need.  Of course that isn't going to work for large boxes, but to cover a mailing label for extra protection or add extra security to a post office mailing envelope or for a small box, it works fine.  The heavy duty quality of this tape seems overkill for those purposes, but I'm just happy I've found a use for it.  For my big handheld dispenser I far prefer the Duck brand.

i just ran across this on the GE site
"The silicone will not cure. What should I do?
Check the Use By date on the bottom of the cartridge or the top of the squeeze tube.<> If the product is older than the Use By date printed on the product, safely dispose of the product. It is too old and will not cure. If the product is within the Use By date printed on the product, simply call the GE Sealants & Adhesives Customer Service number, 1-866-ASK-GESA, for a complete refund. Why would the sealant not dry or harden?
Not hardening (not curing) is frequently due to aged product in which the chemical that makes the silicone harden is no longer active. Silicone generally should cure within 24 hours. If it has been over 24 hours, you should determine what the silicone "use before" date is. If the product was used prior to that date, contact the GE Answer Center, 1-866-ASK-GESA, with the following information found on the tube:

Stock Number, (the stock number is most easily found as the last 4 digits of the UPC. It is located on the cartridges at the very bottom line of text, to the right of the UPC.)
Batch Code  ink jet printed on the bottom of the cartridge, or stamped into the top of the squeeze tube.
Description of the type of silicone
"

We owned the original Sonicare for years and we loved it.  When we bought this model, we expected the same good performance we had from the original.  We were sorely disappointed by the fact that the screw on brush heads were flimsy and didn't screw down on the base unit securely.  We found the transfer of the ultra-sonic vibrations were dampened by the fact that the brush heads didn't remain tightly connected to the base unit.  After using this model for a year, we were receiving negative feedback from our dental hygienist.  We ended up buying another brand of electronic toothbrush but still weren't getting the results we expected.  Finally bought the Sonicare Flexcare model with snap on style heads.  This model works beautifully.  I would recommend you NOT buy Sonicare products with screw on style brush heads as they continuously loosen themselves from the base unit which degrades their performance.  The snap on style heads available on some Sonicare models remain securely attached to the base unit and therefore, transfer the ultrasonic vibrations to the brush head and your teeth more effectively.

UPDATE, 2016/07/28. I have to say that we have used this cleaner now four times, and a part broke, a plastic part.  And its not any part, but one you really, really have to have, the right hand lock for the discharge tank.  Two weeks ago I contacted Hoover and was told they would ship the part right out.  Two weeks later, the part box appeared, with the wrong side locking handle.  And because of the design, the two handles are NOT interchangable.  And, becuase the part is out of stock, Hoover cannot back order it, I have to keep checking back every two weeks.  As a result of this hassle, I have dropped my rating of this carpet cleaner from a three, to a one.  Count me not happy.

The star rating that I have given this item should tell you that I neither loved or hated this Hoover carpet cleaner.  But I was expecting something a little more substantial.  Does it clean carpets?  Yes.  Does it do what it says it will do? Yes.  It's built to commercial standards? No.

Right out of the box, this item had me questioning if it was really meant for commercial use, or if "commercial" was a euphemism for "basic".  The unit is made of plastic - very inexpensive plastic.  The solution tank and the wastewater tank are light, but again, they don't feel substantial.  Neither does the handle.  Cheap.

Assembly was easy UNTIL it came to the point where you are support to *snap* the cord into a channel clip on the body.  That was ten minutes of frustration right there because neither the channel clips or the cord will yield to the other.  In fact the plastic body part gouged the cord.  We were finally able to get the cord in the channel but it shouldn't have taken as much effort as it did.

The washer fluid tank comes with a built in measurer, its built into the cap, which is handy.  I never got a secure feeling that the tank was in the right place when installed into the machine - there's little feed back from the parts as they connect.  Foot pedals control the power and the handle drop.

As for cleaning, it does lay down solution, and it does suck it back up into the retention bin.  And yes, what it gets out is gross.

And while it says its a "steam cleaner" there are no controls for a heater unit, there is no indicator light to show that anything is up to temperature.  And in use, there is no steam to be had, leading me to think that they used a part with the word "steam" on it.

IMPORTANT: read the directions!!!  Do small areas as directed.  I have seen too many people make messes with carpet cleaners thinking that they are just vacuums that squirt clean and suck it back up.  And you have to wait until its completely dry, vacuum it well, and your results are not bad.  But if try to rush it, you will have uneven results.

Will it holds up over time?  I have no idea until "time" passes.  (See the update, above)

So my bottom line is that this is a basic cleaner marketed as a commercial unit.  It is no fills.  No steam.  No water heating unit.  No upholstery tools.  And if appliances can be "sexy", as in amazing design, this is defiantly unsexy in its looks and features.

It is not that it doesn't attach well to itself, it is that it doesn't attach well to the sub-straight.  I own a boat with a light tower above the cockpit that leaks.  When it rains the water runs down the wood tower to a stainless steel U shaped angle iron that attached the tower to the cockpit.  I wrapped the tape tightly around the angle iron at the base and in one piece I was able to go from the base up past the angle iron and well up onto the wooden light tower.  The product was not able to stop the rain water from getting behind the tape and running into the electrical wire port that lead to the inside of the boat.  Being that this product doesn't adhere to the sub-straight I don't believe it would do well with electrical wire connections if there is water involved.  I would not recommend this product for boat or outdoor applications.

I carefully read dozens of reviews about this product before I used it, especially because it was the first time I'd ever tried any sort of tooth whitening. I'll admit I was pretty skeptical when I saw more negative than positive reviews, but it was on sale so I went for it.
The instructions were pretty easy to follow and I started the first 20 min. application.
Almost right away I could tell I was a little sensitive, but it was NOTHING like other reviews said- completely tolerable, hardly enough to call uncomfortable. I took ibuprofen right before just in case, though. By the time the first 20 minutes were up, I noticed that it did sting a bit when the gel got on my upper gums too much, and my back molars are EXTREMELY sensitive as is so it didn't feel great if any got on them. But anyway, as I was saying, when I rinsed after the first 20 minutes I didn't see any difference, and was admittedly a bit dismayed. But persevere I would, kept going.
After rinsing for the last time 2 hours later, my mouth was definitely hurting a little bit in the areas the gel touched, but it wasn't terrible. I noticed my teeth were SLIGHTLY whiter, but it was barely noticeable. So I guess it all depends on each individual's pain tolerance and works differently for everyone. I was happy I used it because I really wanted to whiten at least a little, which it did. I'd probably try something else in the future; spend a little more to get better quality.

I purchased this product by recommendation of a trusted hardware store owner to bond a loose plastic rain guard over the window of my GMC Sierra Z71 to the metal door frame.  For six months I have tested the glue on various applications including wood, plastic steel, and aluminum in both land and marine environments.
This is a non-tacky liquid that requires only two things to make it work well using common sense methods to apply.  Clamp/form where necessary and use water as a catylyst and bonding agent per instructions.  I prefer giving the surfaces a light, fine spray of water with a good spray bottle.
A little goes a very long way.  This is the most fascinating material since "aerogel".  A little Gorilla will grow overnight, expanding, say, 399-400% at full cure into a final hard mass of structural air cells.  Excess can be shaved or cut off and sanded, if required.
Other that the superb holding characteristics, the great wonder of this fluid polyurethane is its expansion capability to allow it to be used, also, as a filler/bonding material.  I have a 12 ft. wide overhead garage door on my boathouse by-the-sea.  On one horizontal section, where the glazing is stiled and railed, the wood around many of the hinge hardware has rotted.  After removing the dust and fragments of the dead wood fibers, substantial areas of irregular shape remained void of any material.  This poor condition makes it difficult to install new hardware and to find a surface to paint.
The solution is to clean and prep the area, spray the elements with water, with a glue brush the obscured interior areas and perimeter walls with some Gorilla.  Next, cut a section of clear heavy platic sheeting, say, from a packaging bag from some item you recently bought, or a Zip-loc, of size with sufficient overlap.  Then, solidly reinforce the damaged ares with a rigid, nailable sheeting to create a form, say, Luan underlayment, or equal, and tack this form to the tackable areas of the good wood.  Create a fill/vent hole at the highest point on one side of the voided-to-fill area.  Using the squeezable Gorilla bottle force the glue through the hole to fill, say, 1/3 of the voided volume. Sorry, but the exact amount is not known since the coefficent of expansion remains an unknown to this date, and may vary according to other elements of physics and science.  But, this is pretty much a dummy-proof method.  Let the project sit overnight.  If you don't see an excess of Gorilla that has forced its way out the vent hole, then give another light spray shot of water through the hole and inject some more Gorilla through the hole, sit and let cure.  Upon completion, cut access off, strip the form, sand, drill, if needed, and paint to finish. The extent of the area and conditions that this method of application can be used is unknown.  Also, the expected shelf-life is unknown, so I bought the 8 oz. bottle. The integrity of the glue is still good after six months.  Explore, test and share your results with others.  This is a worthwhile product that works as I never expected.
If you have a lot of broken stuff, never leave home without your Gorilla!

Regrettably, I found this can's rigid spout nearly impossible to use to put gas into a car. A Gates Cogged Hi-Power belt runs about 1/4 of the price of these and produces the same amount of vibration.  In addition to this at the same tension (ie not stressing the motor) the link belt was more prone to slippage when the tool was loaded down than the Hi-Power.

Plastic Dip Intl. 11603-6 Plasti-Dip I ordered two cans of Plastic Dip, one red and one yellow, from AF Lock and Hardware in Brooklyn NY. I received one red and one black. The products were immediately shipped out and received within a week. I already had a can of Plastic Dip, black, that I purchased locally; it works great, so good that I ordered two more colors. Now here's the rub. There is virtually no way to determine what color you are ordering, save for a few which are listed. When I called to enquire how to order a can of yellow the guy at customer service did look up the stock number for me. When I tried to order a can, he told me to order it on-line, even though one of the options when I called the company was 'sales'. He offered no apology for my troubles, no offer to exchange the miss-sent can, and no offer of free postage for the newly ordered can. I can only hope that the can that I ordered was the correct color; oh and to make matters worse, the stock number that he gave me did not correlate with any of the numbers shown on Amazon. My advice is to look locally for your Plastic Dip. Unfortunately the only color that my local Lowes store carried was black.

I splurged the big bucks, hoping for the big results! Let me break down how much of a train-wreck this is:

-Saliva. I'll start with the worst because time is short. There's a warning not to swallow the bleaching gel. There's also a warning not to let saliva mix with said gel. Well, unless you're the "No-Saliva Superhero," it's impossible. I tried everything. I ended up putting paper towel bits in my upper/lower lips and a big wad in my mouth. I changed the paper towel every thirty seconds or so for the whole /20 minutes/ you have to sit (X4). If you're like me, you might puncture your trays with your teeth while you're trying to get them to form and stick on. This leads to the second problem...

-Stomach problems. Even with said crazed effort above, my stomach feels like I've swallowed acid. I'm trying to keep dinner down as we speak.

-Trays. Unfortunately, the idea of personalized trays should've stayed in the dentist's office. Great idea! Awful to execute. The first tray I tried, I had to dunk and form to my teeth seven times. Seven! It still never fully formed and kept sliding off. Thankfully, the bottom one worked on the first try, but both ended up with holes from me trying to form them to my teeth. Very tricky.
This is the worst and most expensive OTC whitener I've tried. Crest strips work the best so far. Next time, I'm trying a natural baking soda...

If you need a strong joint, but don't have the time or tools to make a completely tight fit, this glue works wonders.  I've used it to make strong joints between plywood edges and hardwood for a table top, for dowel  joints, and for screwed joints.  The glue expands by about three times and  will fill gaps up to about 1/32" with close to full strength, and  larger gaps with less strength.  One caution, as it dries, the glue foams  up and you have to plan on chiselling off or power-sanding off the squeeze  out.  Also, you need to keep the joint under pressure for one to four hours  before removing clamps.  This is not a glue to use when  you need the joint  to set-up quickly, or when you will not be able to sand off the squeeze  out.  With that said, this glue makes strong joints with much less  preparation than conventional glues.  I use it whenever strength is  critical.

It takes a little practice to get used to these, and I kind of feel like it's a case of "controlled chaos" working with them. There's a lot of things that can go wrong, so they are potentially very dangerous. I didn't realize the first time I used them when you get to the very top of the lift, the weight of the jacks themselves will tend to push the wall over. I was trying to stop the wall from moving, and both of the jacks in  unison were fighting against me. I was very lucky that one edge of the top plate caught against an adjacent wall long enough for me to pull the jack out of place. I would have lost the wall otherwise.

After that first little adventure I started to tie rope to the wall, but this is also a case of controlled chaos. If your ropes are too long, they can stretch, and the bottom of the wall can kick in and go over too. I find it best to get the walls within about 3 inches of plumb, brace the wall and get rid of the jacks. Then, and only then, push the wall into plumb.

These are very handy, but I would advise anyone using them to start with small walls (10') or so before approaching anything much heavier.  I can also say it takes about 45 min. to set everything up vs. about 15 min. with a helper. Of course if you have no helper, these are gold. I have been using this with my DeWalt sanders for years. Why pay a fortune for individual sheets from Lowes or Home Depot? This sandpaper lasts considerably longer, is much, much stronger and you simply cut it to size, stick one layer on the pad of your sander as a base, then add another layer,  clip them in and away you go. Not only that, it makes your pads last 10X longer as well. When it's worn out, remove it (I find it helps to let a few layers of sandpaper build up on the pad). This will save you a fortune in throw away single sheets and OK, it doesn't have any holes in it so you won't be collecting much dust - but then do you really anyway? Saves time, works better and saves a fortune in the long run. Does a much better job too and if you ever need a small piece for hand sanding, simply cut a sheet to the desired size, fold it over and stick it to itself and again, it won't slip, you won't be tearing it or cursing at it, you'll be able to get into those tight corners and the job will be done so much better in half the time! I think this glue is best used for porous surfaces like stone, wood, drywall, foam, rug material, cloth and brickwork. It dries brittle, with practically no elasticity, so I don't recommend it for automotive applications where there is a lot of mechanical vibration. It also takes longer than 24 hours to dry, and it foams and leaves a lot of run-off. So if you have holes or voids to fill, this glue is perfect. I consider Gorilla Glue to be the new improved, waterproof version of white glue. The manufacturer claims this is the world's strongest glue, but I don't think so. And it's not an all-purpose glue like Household Goop, or The Welder.

This toothbrush did a great job and I loved how my teeth felt after cleaning, but after just 1 week of use the vibrations loosened the screw in my dental implant.  At the time I'd only had the implant for 7 weeks and the dentist had just put in the permanent filling to cover the screw the same day I started using the toothbrush.  I was panicked that the implant had failed, but I did some googling and found some information that the vibrations from the toothbrush can loosen dental implant screws.  I don't want to take the chance that this will happen again, I don't want the screw to become stripped.  So I will not be using this toothbrush, or any electric toothbrush for that matter.  Luckily, my spouse can continue to use it.

Little did I know the joys and wonders yet to come as my gums turned bright red with horrifyingly white spots scattered about, followed by the delightful effect of the gum tissue starting to die and fall off over the next couple days.

I bought this for woodworking, primarily for setting up my jointer and adjusting the jointer knife height.

It came in a thick plastic case, which is more than I expected. It could've been padded, but since I didn't expect a case at all I can't fault it too much.

Assembly was easy and the instructions were very clear and not Engrish-y at all, unlike most stuff like this. The instructions were clear, to the point, printed on thick stock and included lots of pictures. Way better than what you usually get here.

The machining on the base is clean and pretty much flawless. Smooth surfaces are smooth as glass. *Very* heavy. Feels like quality, more than the cost would suggest.

When placed on my cast iron jointer bed, the magnet holds solid as a freaking rock. Almost impossible to move.

I tested the accuracy with feeler gauges (zeroed out on a table, then slid the gauge under the measurement rod). The measurement was so close to the value on the feeler gauge that it was probably due to human error while zeroing it out to the table's height and not error in the tool. Even so it was (by my eye) no more than 1/10,000 of an inch off, and more like 1/50,000 to 1/100,000 of an inch. Accuracy is not a problem here, I think.

There are lots of adjustments, included one I *love* and didn't expect. The middle of the horizontal rod has a micro adjustment screw. As you loosen and tighten it, the dial moves up and down by tiny amounts. It lets you insanely close to the surface of an object. The action is smooth and easy.

So, if the unit is so great why is it three stars. Well, three stars isn't a horrible score, but there's a severe quality control issue. The unit I got has one serious flaw. The dial came WAY off of 0. By default the gauge reads around -10 thousandths. It is impossible to adjust the measurement rod to zero it out on the zero mark, but you can adjust the actual measurement markings - so I brought the zero to the needle instead of vice versa. This isn't a perfect solution - you can't zero out the "hundredths" gauge (the one in the middle), and the whole face is tilted over since 0 is in the top left instead of at the top.

It seems like you could insert a washer between the top of the rod and the body of the gauge, and if you used the right size washer you could adjust the needle back to 0. It already includes one thin metal washer and a rubber o-ring. I don't have a tiny diameter, super thin washer to use for this, and I shouldn't have to. It really should have come calibrated to 0. I contacted Grizzly support to see if there's a secret way to adjust the needle but haven't gotten an answer yet.

If it turns out that the unit is easy to fix, or if they can make it right otherwise, then this is a 4 star unit, maybe more like 4 1/2 star. I'm not really sure yet if I want to go through the hassle of a return, since it does work really well otherwise.

There's also no way to "tare" the unit beyond the hundredths place. You can rotate the measurement scale so that zero is wherever you want, but that only works for a single rotation of the needle. You can't zero the center "hundredths" dial. This isn't a big deal since I got this to deal with thousandths of an inch, and zero'ing out is just a shortcut so you don't have to do subtraction. Still, it is something to think about.

I am building a garage.  This tool was fantastic.  I lifted a 24 ft fully sheathed 2x6 studded 10.5 foot tall wall using two of these jacks (buy two jacks for longer walls.  you won't be sorry).

This wall was framed on top of a 18" stem wall, so in reality the wall was 12 foot high.  The limit for these jacks is a 10.5 foot wall.  There is chart in the directions that tell you the correct length of 2x4 for the size of the wall.  I had 16 foot 2x4 studs to attach the jacks to and it was not long enough.  The jack ran out of wood to ratchet up.  Luckily we had anchored the bottom of the wall and were able to straighten it to be upright using other means.  For the second wall I used 20 foot 2x4s and it was fine, but I would not recommend this because it exceeds the maximum for the jack.

Remember the jack will not go backwards.  Once you start, you are committed to complete the task.  One smart thing we did was to do a miniature practice run with a make believe wall and a short stud.  This dry run prepared us for how the jack would function and react.

EDIT UPDATE:  In addition to lifting the fully sheathed walls, we used the jacks to lift the 18 foot 6x12 garage header into place.  I have been thinking about how to use these jacks to get the plywood sheathing onto the roof.  I will update if I am successful.

All in all I give The Boss 1934 By Eureka Ten Stars and will most likely order another machine just to have on hand, I know that the machine is reliable and will last many years to come, so a big Thanks goes out to Amazon and Eureka for number carring this machine and still making a machine that is so powerful but not expsensive.

My experience with Gorilla Glue has been abysmal. I have much better success with forms of epoxy such as JB Weld. The only purported advantage of GG is faster curing time than epoxy, but even when left to dry overnight, I have hand bonds fail immediately when put under stress.

The label claims that it can bond numerous materials including metal, wood, plastic, glass, etc. For example, I glued a metal conduit bracket and a glass mason jar to a plastic plate to make a bird feeder. This worked great with JB Weld, but when attempted with GG the assembly immediately fell apart when the weight of the birdseed was added. (resulting in a pile of birdseed with glass shards on the floor)

I don't know how the makers of this product can sleep at night. When I picked up the pieces of my project, I was able to pull the glue off the metal piece with my bare hands. "incredibly strong"? really?

The glue has the density of styrofoam when it cures. Worthless! Take a little more time and use epoxy. Even the 2-hr epoxy will work better than this garbage.
I'm not really handy when it comes to using this stuff. Give me a can of spray foam than solidifies in time and I'm good to go.

We had a unit just like this for about three years and we liked it and used it frequently. The thermostat finally failed on it so we ordered this replacement. It came in damaged but we were able to straighten it out. It was packed well but the box took a big hit on one corner during shipping. The label on the unit and the information on the product page state that the wattage is 2500 but as with our old unit we checked the current draw and it reads 13 amps. That comes out to about 1500 watts. It works well. takes about 10 to 15 minutes to heat to 350F. The old unit had a oil level mark but this one does not. We transferred the oil to the new one and marked it with a scratch on the pan. We measured the oil volume and it came out to 5 liters. Here are two things Phillips will not tell you about their Sonicare toothbrushes and heads.

1) The collar that holds the toothbrush to the handle will disintegrate in a couple of months. That's what prompted this review, because they would not replace mine after it fell apart two weeks after purchasing a replacement.

They manufacturer these things to disintegrate so you will continue to buy replacements - planned obsolescence. However, I suspect their China supplier is skimping on the plastic specifications and they fall apart in weeks instead of months. (Do you think China would really do that?)

2) UNPLUG your base until you need to charge the toothbrush.  If you charge it up overnight, then unplug the base, the toothbrush will work for four brushings per day for about a month.  Then, when it signals or stops, plug the base in to charge it.

This method will allow your toothbrush to work for five years or longer. If you keep the base plugged in all the time, these NiCad batteries develop memory and will stop functioning after 18 to 24 months.

A bonus, if you travel a lot as I do, you don't have to pack the charger.  Just make sure it's topped off and you're good for a month's vacation.
