In every case where sold, Fluke uses the same picture that implies these are rigid probes. I called several sources and asked the question, "are these extensions rigid ? Will they allow me to extend my probe where hands cannot go? "  I specifically said I need to reach behind a motor in a furnace, will these probes allow me to do that. Every source told me the probes "will do what you want" .

Not true !  This is nothing more than a set of floppy extensions that will make your existing probe reach further without moving the meter. They are NOT rigid and will NOT allow you to reach in small places where hands cannot go.

Nothing against Fluke, they are a fine company with excellent products but in this case, Fluke could have been a little more specific about their product.

So I actually got a free sample of this (a starter kit box) when I left my dentist after a  routine cleaning.  I thought it was neat and convenient, and still do for the most part.  I take the mouth spray with me to work and use it every now and then when my mouth is feeling dry, or if I just want the tastes of mint in my mouth.  It also comes handy when I break open a bag of sour cream and onion potato chips.  But when I had the inclination to buy a new set of bottles I was surprised to find out anyone would ever charge more than $5 a bottle.

Let's be honest, the 8 mL bottle is only sufficient for about 30 sprays at best.  That's maybe a week's worth.  It's also a watered down version of the tounge sprayer, another product by Breath Rx that costs 4x more than I would have expected and comes in a bottle nearly half the size as the breath sprayer.

I wouldn't rate this product in terms of efficiency over 2 or 3 tic tacs, and at the same price, I could buy enough tic tacs to start my own mariachi band. If you really want to use a breath sprayer, you fraction Listerine (or any general mouth cleanser) into one of these or similar water bottles and simply reduce the concentration with filtered water.  No more, no less, and you'll be set for ages.

I doubt that these would be stable holding up the 150 lb limit when fully extended, because the 2nd section (from the bottom) can move horizontally so there not entirely straight.  They max out at a height of only 102 inches (perhaps a little more), without extending the last section which has a much smaller diameter.  The top/bottom feet don't look to be made of particularly durable material, given the weight of the poles.  Heavier feet would be useful (Larger ones are available).  I'm thinking of returning them and probably will if I can find something more to my liking, i.e., something similar that could allow greater pressure to be applied. Incidentally, they came in a hastily re-taped (original) box and, as received, were slightly scuffed up in places and specs of what looked like bits of orange Great Stuff filler on them. Very good quality, good case, seems tight, no complaints there.  I'm realizing that I should've looked more closely before ordering.

Number one: I wish the fractions were on the inside edge and decimal on the outside.  If I'm looking at 1/64in on the outside, that is 0.0156in. The inside is incremented  at 0.01in.  The larger and easier one to read should be on the inside.
Number two: the decimal only reads to 0.01in.  Most dial calipers will read to 0.001in.  And in the description it is listed both ways...
Number three: I like the fractional measurement (I work with welders who use to fractional tape measures) and it serves as a fantastic cross reference (I bought it because it had the fractional measurement). But I wouldn't have minded the graduations going to 1/128in instead of just 1/64in.  In reality a good tape measure reads in 1/32in and you can estimate a 1/64in if you need to.  So the advantage of this over a tape measure is not huge.

Long story short; its a very nice calipers and the price is good (especially for dial which is what I wanted), it's just not the precision I was hoping for.

I picked up this 6-pack of this tape at local store. It costs twice as much as I would have guessed, but I figured I would be getting more length for the extra money. It says on the package, "meets US postal regulations" and I needed tape for shipping so I figured this was the right choice. What I really was getting was getting tape that was twice the normal thickness and half the length of the general purpose version of this product. Because the tape is so thick and strong it hard to deal with it in a tape dispenser on small packages (e.g., priority mail boxes is what I mostly ship) because it doesn't cut easily from the dispenser and I have a good commercial quality dispenser. If you need a strong tape, then this is the right packing tape for you and you would rate 5 stars. If you are looking for something for just mailing standard boxes I think this tape is an overkill and you will be disappointed in how fast you seem to go through rolls if you do a lot of shipping.

I had some damage to woodwork in my home done by a couple of Gorillas delivering furniture. They actually broke chunks out of my custom made woodworking. I used this to repair it and it did a reasonable job. I have to tell you that you should use it as thinly as possible as it does tend to swell and foam. It did a good job but it is a big bottle and what you don't use will age and not be very good the next time you get out the bottle. The glue isn't clear and it looks yellow after it cures.

My suggestion is to use the right glue for the job. There are better wood glues out there that are easier to use and to clean up. I also like epoxy glues for many jobs as they are stronger and they dry harder. The gel versions can also be used to fill in gaps and it quickly hardens.

This glue seems to have a limited shelf life and you wind up throwing away a lot more than you will use. I have the 4 ounce bottle and most of it went to waste. I rate it as a 3 star item. I probably will not buy it again.
Not as easy as I thought it would be to use but it does hold super well on everything I used it on. U have to apply pressure for at least 2 hours so a clamp would be helpful.

I have used the Oral-B Sonicare system for years.  I decided to order this since it was less expensive than ordering replacement heads.  Well, as my Momma use to say, sometimes you just gotta pay a little more.

I have used this for a few weeks now and I am just waiting for one of two things

1.  The it dies and I can throw it out
2.  I beat up the heads so bad, that I can throw it out

In case you can't tell, I want to toss it out.....It virtually stops if you put too much pressure on it (against your teeth) and the battery life is next to nothing--about 2 days.  Even with less expensive battery powered spin brushes, I get a better clean than I do with this thing.  My suggestion for you is save your money.

Very good vacuum, just like the one my mother had for years. Picks up everything and uses a paper bag making emptying easy and sanitary. Very happy with this vacuum. Thank you Amazon, for having this wonderful vacuum on your web site. Arrived earlier than expected, and at a very good price. Amazon you are the BEST!

This caulking is really easy to work with. Dries quickly, but not too quick to where you can't manipulate it after applying. Used it to caulk around baseboards and windows and notice a difference in energy savings.

I read the negative reviews for this tape but since they were several months old, and the 3M company representative had responded to them, I took a leap of faith and hoped that Amazon's stock had been replaced and the problem resolved.
Not so. I purchased four rolls of this tape, and so far one has absolutely NO adhesion, and the other I would rate as barely sticky. I got these for a little over two dollars a roll which was a great price, but I would have been fuming if I paid the $6-$7 these cost in retail stores and had the same problems.
For a company like 3M, which generally sells some of the best products, to have such a lapse in QC and allow this type of inferior product to hit the market is sad. I will not be purchasing this tape again, or any 3M brand packaging tapes for a while, in the hopes that they correct this problem.

This product was purchased based on the hope of the "name" and high cost paying off in terms of quality.
I opened the first tube to try it.
I had left the tube cap end up since the night before (not planned, just landed that way) and as I squeezed all I got was air for 50% of the capacity of the tube.
Hoping my two other tubes were better off I opened them up - the second tube was exactly the same - lots of air, little paste.
The third tube was a surprise, about 3$ worth of toothpaste shot out immediately due to compressed air in the tube!
I am at sea level so I don't know why this kind of thing would happen except that the tube was filled incorrectly by the tube filling machine, somehow compressing the air in behind the paste.
Given the incredibly small amount of actual toothpaste that these three very expensive tubes will yield the actual long term whitening quality will never be known by me.
Sorry - at this cost the tube is to be completely full of toothpaste that dispenses in an easily controlled fashion.
Whatever you do, do not drop the big money on this.

I bought the original Sonicare when it first came out -- 20 years ago? I don't remember. The technology clearly works. My dentist reports a significant improvement in plaque. I have never used any of the other "sonic" toothbrushes. I imagine they work as well. My original Sonicare just started acting up. It still works, but I think the battery is dying. So I bought the e7300. First impressions are that Philips went for glitz over quality and has added all kinds of marginally useful or even useless "features" so they can engage in marketing hype and jack up the price. It looks to be more cheaply made. I would be surprised if this unit lasts even a fraction of the 20 years of the original unit. It looks to me like it was designed to fail. I was annoyed by the very first page of the manual. It tells me to make sure the handle is properly seated in the base, because if it is put in wrong, the charging light may still come on, but it won't charge. What kind of engineering is this? If it's not charging, don't turn the light on. Don't they have engineers smart enough to figure that out? So I tested it. Sure enough, you can put the handle in any which way and the charging light comes on. This is just lazy or careless design work. Worse, the base is too small, too light, and too shallow. In the original unit, the handle goes well over an inch into the base and there is only one way it will fit. With this unit, the base only holds the handle by about a half inch so it's easy to put it in wrong. And sure enough, no matter how you put it in, even half falling out, the charging light lights up. Looks like it was designed by the marketing department? Then there's the idiotic 2-minute shutoff. I can see zero benefits and several disadvantages. First of all, why are they shutting it off after 2 minutes? Do they think I might leave it on or am too lazy to turn it off myself. This is a clear case of terminal helpfulness. But that's not the most annoying problem. You do NOT want to take the thing out of your mouth while it is running or you will spray toothpaste and spit everywhere. After a few uses, I am operating on autopilot. When I finish brushing, I click the on/off button to turn it off and remove it from my mouth in one simultaneous motion. If you happen to finish brushing just as the thing shuts off (after 2 minutes), clicking the on/off button will actually turn it back on as you are removing it from your mouth. Now you will have a nice little task of cleaning the mirror, the sink, your shirt, the wall, the floor... Nice. #@$%#$@!!! I have done this a few times. Not good. Personally, I find the "timer signal" every 30 seconds annoying, too. I just want a simple on/off button. It's a toothbrush, not the control panel for a heart-lung machine. KISS. Actually, I have no problem with this "feature" if some people are unable to figure out how to brush without a built-in timer as long as the company provides a way to turn the infernal thing off. But clearly they think they know what I need better than I do. In the original model, I could at least turn off the 30-second reminders by holding the on/off button for a few seconds -- simple. With this "improved" model, they have added a "dual speed" button, but it only works while in the charger. Now that's convenient. I have the charger at the back of the sink behind the radio and out of the way. Now I have to move the charger to where I can actually see it. My guess is that they are again protecting me from myself so I won't accidentally change the settings while I am using the unit. Did they test this on morons? Did they test it at all? The ultimate insult to injury is in the instructions on recycling the battery. I am told to first deplete the battery. I am to do this by removing the unit from the charger, turning it on, and letting it run until it stops. But it stops every 2 minutes! Since they brag that the unit can be used for 2 weeks (twice a day) on a full charge, they are really asking me to stand there for an hour (2x2x14 minutes) and restart the unit 28 times. Like that is going to happen. On the bright side, it comes with a very nice travel case. I used to toss my old one in my dopp kit, which is probably why it broke and I bought this piece of junk. Summary: The technology works. This unit was designed to fail early so that you would buy a new one. I give it 3 stars for cleaning teeth and 0 stars for arrogant, cheap design and being overpriced. 07/30/10 I have since junked this thing and bought an Oral B Sonic Complete. (Oral B S-320 Sonic Complete Rechargeable Power Toothbrush) What a difference. The Oral B is well designed (with one minor annoyance) and it cleans better. I have a mouth guard. I clean it every morning. It had become yellowed over the years. After a few days with the Oral B, it has lost most of the yellowing. I am downgrading the Sonicare to a 1 in comparison to the Oral B. Check it out.

I am a professional contractor. We got these to transport 10' and 12' sheets of of 5/8ths rock. The downward pressure these things created was unbelievable. I ended up pulling/tearing ligaments in my right wrist and forearm. The standing position you must have while using these is very 'off' compared to the conventional way of transporting ply/rock. I tweeked all sorts of muscles in my left shoulder and hip areas. I feel like I may have re-pinched a nerve in my neck. I can't count how many tens of thousands of lbs of drywall I've carried throughout my career without having any problem. I can easily carry two sheets of 5/8ths plywood by myself. I'm definitely no light weight and am very experienced with handling sheet goods.

 I could see it working for DIY homeowners who are carrying single sheets of 8' goods. It may have some advantage when you need to carry ply or drywall through a low doorway, as the handle enables you to hold the sheets lower than the way you would normally carry. I still would not recommend using this item if you have to make 20-50 trips with it. I believe the traditional way is much safer when moving a large amount of wood/drywall. Please keep in mind; I made about 60 trips with these things. I'm sure they're alright for a few trips, but for professional use I don't recommend them.

I had tried the Listerine Strips and didn't like them, and I had used the Crest Strips before, but to be honest, I was trying to spend as little as possible to get the results I was looking for.  When it came time for a wedding I had to attend, and there was no time left to do a two-week program, I decided to try this product because a friend said it worked well for her.
I was a little hesitant at first because my teeth are already a little sensitive to hot and cold, but I was desperate for something, so I tried it anyway.  By the end of the first 20 minutes, my teeth hurt a little.  By the start of the last 20 minutes it was almost too painful to keep them in, but I managed.  I didn't notice that much of a difference in color right away, but this morning - a day later - I can definitely tell it worked pretty well.  Like another reviewer said, my teeth aren't glowing white like some celebrities, but they are definitely better than they were before.
As for the pain, my teeth started hurting halfway through the process, but stubborn me, I kept going with it.  I had shooting pains all through my face all night (I used the product yesterday between 2:30-4:30pm).  I did not get any white spots or streaks on my teeth or gums.  However, my gums did blister, but not until later in the evening.  It took about 5-6 hours after I finished the process for the real pain to show up.
This morning, my teeth hurt much less than yesterday, but my lower gums hurt WAY more.  I think I have a huge blister on the inside of my lower lip, and a small one on the inside gumline behind the teeth where the tongue touches.  I feel like I got punched in the jaw, and I can't smile or drink or anything without severe pain.  In fact, it hurts even when I'm not making any facial expression at all.
I don't know if I'll ever use the product again.  I might, but next time I definitely won't do all four sessions back to back.  I just wish I'd known about the pain first.  #I'm pretty sure I'm stubborn enough that if I had read the reviews here I'd have thought I wouldn't end up with these blisters like other people.)
I gave it three stars because it worked, but I'm not sure it was worth the pain.

UPDATE:  I wrote this review too soon.  The sensitivity in the teeth only took about 24 hours to go away, but I ended up with blisters and pain like I have never had in my life in the area where the lower lip meets the gums.  The full extent of the pain did not show up until about 24 hours after the treatment, when the blisters finally broke.  It took about a week for them to fully heal, and there's still some pain once in a while.  I would still recommend the product and use it again because it worked quite well, but next time I would be VERY VERY careful.

After looking at many different fryers I took the chance on this one. It doesn't have a big name brand, but looks just as sturdy as any other fryer and they all come from China anyway. That being said, here's the rundown of pros and cons: Pros: Heats up fast. Holds a lot of oil. Large basket for cooking. Easy to clean. Sturdy design. Cons: Metal edges are not de-burred (easy fix, see below). Basket handle is a pain to assemble. Another reviewer said it takes a long time to heat up. It actually takes about as long as other fryers, but it's heating a larger capacity oil tank, so it evens out. It also heats up fast when new food is placed in the tank. The metal edges are sharp, but not knife blade sharp. It's really only a big issue on a metal plate that sits below the basket and protects the heating element. I used a Dremel to remove the sharpness on it and the oil tank which took about 5 minutes (another reviewer used a nail file). Overall a great buy. I should probably give it 4 stars because of the sharp edges, but it was an easy fix and I love the fryer so much I just can't see dinging it for that.

I have owned my Elite model for about 6 months now.  Previous to that, I was the owner of the "original" Sonicare toothbrush for about 7 years, which used the standard heads rather than the angled "elite" brush heads.  I replaced it only because the non-user-replaceable battery finally gave up the ghost.

In general, all the sonicare models do an outstanding job of keeping teeth cleaned, if used properly.  I like the sonic action better than rotary or slower-speed mechanical motion.  The sonicare keeps my teeth feeling polished.  The timer also forces me to brush for a full 2 minutes - 30 seconds for each quadrant of my mouth.

As such, I am not going to spend a lot of time commenting on the effectiveness of the sonicare approach in general (which I think is excellent) or in comparing it to other brands.  Instead, I'm going to focus here strictly on comparing the new Elite model to the previous model which used so-called "standard" sonicare brush heads rather than "elite" brush heads.

First, let's talk about the relatively few things I like about the new model:

* battery indicator - shows when charging (which old one had) and shows how much charge remains (which old one did not have)

* styling - mine is blue/white and looks attractive with its rubberized side grips.  However, I have a sneaking suspicion the rubber is going to fade and look old more quickly than my older model which was entirely white plastic except for a single small on/off button.

* charger - the new charger has open sides, unlike the old model which was a sealed "well" that would trap water and give rise to gunk build up.  The new design seems like it will stay cleaner and inhibit model or mildew...at least on the charger base itself

* angled brush head - the angle of the "elite" design makes it easier to clean behind your teeth and is used even in most non-electric toothbrushes today.

Unfortuately, that is about it in terms of improvements.  The big black mark (and I do mean black literally) is that there is a significant problem with mold build-up on this design.

* BLACK MOLD - On my old model, I never had a mold problem - ever.  Also, the mold problem is not a factor of my environment.  I live in Nevada.  Humidity is the least of our worries and my house runs conistently drier than normal, particularly in the winter when it is cold and there is very little moisture in the air and the forced-air furnace is running.  Many people have to use humidifiers (I don't use one) to keep the house comfortable.

On my old model, I never removed the brush heads except to change them and perhaps once a month to clean the built-up toothpaste that accumulated around the collar that secured the head to the handle.  I can honestly say that in 6+ years, there was never a hint of a mold problem.

On the new model, however, I began to see the appearance of black mold within 2-4 weeks of purchase.  I think it may actually have to do with a rubber seal that is now placed around the base of the brush stem.  Water can seep in and remain trapped more easily than on the old model which had no opening at that location.  A sanitizer won't help, either, because the location where the mold is growing is not likely to be exposed to the UV light in the charger.  It focuses on the brush stem and bristles, while the mold is in a sort of "cavern" that the light won't reach.  In my opinion, the new model is a poor design and the company is going to have a significant problem until they redesign the brush heads and eliminate this rubber seal entirely, reverting back to a completely encapsulated design.

* Handle - my old handle was constructed entirely of plastic, with no rubberized sides.  Admittedly, the new sides make it easier to grip.  However, I don't ever recall dropping my old handle because it was overly slippery and my old handle sayed nice and clean because it was entirely of smooth plastic.  After 6+ years the white had discolored to an unattractive dull yellow, but it had the important advantage of being able to keep clean.  Any white plastic is bound to discolor over time.

The new design looks attractive now, with its accenting blue rubber sides; however, that rubber is very likely going to fade and discolor relatively quickly, unlike the previous model which took a very long time before it started to look shabby.  Also, toothpaste sticks to the rubber more readily than to the smooth plastic of the old model, making it slightly more difficult to keep clean.  Not a big deal, but worth noting.

* Handle seal - the handle's cover has a very small gap around the circumference, right below the threads where the brush head attaches.  This is an obvious location for moisture ingression, since when you stand the toothbrush upright, water will drip down to the little "ledge" formed in this location and pool there.  The gap isn't large, but is visible to the naked eye.  If I can see it, so can water molecules.  In time, I suspect this will spell a problem for the internals.

All in all, the new model is more attractive, has a battery indicator, and the angled brush head is slightly easier to use.  However, I'm afraid these modest improvements do not eclipse the serious problem noted above; namely, mold growth.

I never used to have to take my brush head off, except when toothpaste built up and actually started to inhibit the sonic vibration of the brush head.  Now, I've taken to removing the brush head after every use to allow everything to air dry properly.  It's a bigger hassle and I'm not confident it will alleviate the mold growth.  After all, I think most people are like me and want to focus on maintaining their TEETH - not their toothbrush.

And, I'm not real keen about having black mold 3 inches from my mouth, even if it is trapped inside the "guts" of the brush head and not on the brushes/stem itself.

My old Eureka vacuum cleaner, which I loved, finally gave up after 14 years.  It was built like a tank, had great suction, and no plastic bells and whistles.  I replaced it with the new model.  It is still simple, no bells or whistles, and seems to work well, so far.  But it is made with much more plastic and is lighter than the old one.  For some, I suppose lighter is better.  I prefer the weight of the old warhorse.

I purchased this because of the rave reviews for such an inexpensive vacuum. I received a 1934B Boss Upright instead of the 1934A that I had ordered here. After contacting the seller, I was told that the B model has replaced the A model and there are no differences between the two. According to the 1934A picture on this site, the 1934B is a different color (grey bag and dark grey base) with different logos. Based on my browse today, the seller I purchased this from is no longer selling this item so hopefully you won't have the same issue. Long and short of it - this review is for the 1934B.

Pros:
1. It has great suction and is very lightweight.

Cons:
1. The handle doesn't fit securely in the base and it tends to move ever so slightly while base is stationary.
The chord is short.
2. I would pay an extra few bucks to have the upper hook that the chord wraps around for storage pivot for quick chord release.
3. The horseshoe-shaped deal attached to the plug end of the chord that is supposed to allow you to secure the plug end of the chord to the rest of the stowed chord is too small. Instead of a tidy, tightly wrapped chord after I'm done vacuuming, I have a loose end hanging on the floor ready to be stomped on by my little ones.

Would I purchase this product again? It's better than the 25 year-old Kenmore I was using before, but I think any vacuum would be. I find myself frustrated by the chord quirks every time I use it, so I'm going to say no, I wouldn't purchase it again.

I love how our previous bag-less vacuum claims it "Never loses suction."  Ha!  Yeah right, unless you don't clean the filters every 3 weeks.  Most of you know how cleaning those little suckers is such a messy, nasty chore.  My wife and I both love this vacuum.  The 2 issues we have with it are: the short cord and the fact it sucks up kitchen rugs a little too easily.  But it cleans very well, is super lightweight and easy to maneuver.  The best part is kissing those filters goodbye forever.  Well that, and the price.

Edit: A few years ago, I gave this 5 stars.  Now it's 3 stars.  The roller brush froze up once and now requires me to remove it and grease up the end caps to keep it spinning smoothly.  I have to do this every 3-6 months.  If I don't, it freezes up and the belt burns up.  That's a nasty smell.  I've never had a vacuum require me to lube the roller brush, so for this reason I'm knocking some stars off.  The vacuum still works well otherwise.  And we still use it frequently some 3 years after purchase.

I LOVE the way my teeth feel after using this toothbrush. But I've had it for over 6 months and the handle/base is disgusting. There are [unnecessary?] crevices in the handle where the brush head attaches and it's a haven for bacteria and mold. Yep, mold is growing in the handle of my toothbrush. I've tried using rubbing alcohol and a cotton swab to clean it, but it's still disgusting because nothing will fit into those tiny crevices. I've read other people's complaints about this on the internet but I see no good cleaning methods suggested, and the Sonicare website makes it sound like it's a breeze to clean once a week: "Wipe away any residue you find, including the area covered by the cuff, with a soft cloth or paper towel. To clean your handle, run a damp cloth around the recessed area once a week." If it were only that easy.

On the other hand, every time I brush this toothbrush makes my teeth feel like I just came from the dentist. And I just had my first dentist appointment since using the Sonicare and cleaning my teeth was a breeze for the hygenist...barely any plaque to scrape off at all. (The prior appointment was an excrutiating 45 minutes of scraping and sore gums for days after.)

Please note that if you're not used to using a powerful electric toothbrush, it will take you about 2 weeks to get fully used to this toothbrush. The first time will be a shock and you'll wonder how brushing your teeth with that toothbrush could ever be pleasurable. But try it for 2 weeks before making a final decision.

Problem 1: There is a small plastic bracket that attaches the bottom foot to the steel pole.  This bracket was damaged during shipping on both poles.  On the one it had shattered in 10 pieces.

Solution: I just used epoxy to glue the brackets into the pole.

Problem 2: The little spring-loaded nubs that lock the pole open are way too stiff.  It actually makes it difficult to adjust the length of the pole, especially when it is in the shortest position and there isn't a good handhold on one end.

Solution:  I removed the nubs.  They were easy to pop out the bottom of the pole (due to the conveniently damaged bottom foot brackets).  There is a tension-screw that can also be used to lock the pole open and it works just fine.  If you were planning on putting a heavy load on the pole, it would probably be a good idea to put a small bolt through the nub holes, just to make sure the pole doesn't slide closed.

Once I got past these problems, the poles actually work really well.  They are long, sturdy and easy to adjust.  The pole body is steel, so my magnetic laser level will clip right to it.  The top foot has a pump mechanism that makes it easy to lock the pole into place between floor and ceiling.  The bottom foot has a threaded rod that you can use to easily micro-adjust the height, for hanging cabinets or such.

If the pole feet were made out of better materials, this product would easily be a 5-star.  The plastic brackets and fittings are very brittle, though, and I doubt that they would survive any serious abuse.

I've read the reviews on the Shark.  While it's not in the same class as the Vapor 2000, I think the Shark is getting a bit of a bad rap.  Oh sure, it's a toy when compared to the might of the 2000.  But the Shark is less expensive.  My sister has a Shark and it does okay on small jobs, like cleaning around sink faucets.  I don't believe the Shark was designed for heavier cleaning than that.  And I don't think it will hold up to every-day use.  So if durability and muscle are what you're looking for, go for the 2000.  But you'll have to spend more than 100 bucks.  I was willing to do that because I wanted power and a steamer that will last.  But for those who don't have extra cash sitting around, the Shark is worth a look.  Just don't be surprised if you have to send it back for repairs every now and then.  The Shark is a frail cleaning machine more suited to occasional cleaning than every-day cleaning.

UPDATE: What I said above has been tested now.
Part 1:  I built a 200# 4ft. X 8ft. plywood work table and installed 6 of these assemblies to make it light and easy to roll.  Loaded it is about 250 to 300# max.  The wheels can't handle it well at all.  The problem is not the wheel itself, it is the chincy metal materials they used.  Soft, flexible, and bends rather than turn on the rollers, even on a flat new cement floor.  Sad. Data: 300# by 6 rollers = ~ 50 # each loading.... pretty over rated huh?!
Part 2:  I made a small cabinet for the Sander I bought on Amazon, and I used 4 rollers to ease the locating of the tool in my shop.  Weighs total about 100# with the sander: works perfectly.  DATA: 100# by 4 wheels = 25# per wheel.  Obviously, typical China Junk.... very overrated.  Listed to handle 220# loads each, and at 50# each they begin to fail.

Derate them by about 400% and you are just about right.  If you must have 50# or more on them the metal is just tooooo soft & cheap.  Otherwise, just great.

I have owned and used steamers for several years.  I purchased this to replace my older Delonghi Steam Clean Plus and here and overall found the unit produced consistent steam but lacking in pressure somewhat compared to my older model.  I actually purchased the steam cleaner from a warehouse club and it had a very nice selection of accessories including an extension rod hanger that allows you to steam garments on a hanger extending from the top of the extension rod.  Basically the steamer is the same as this model 275 in terms of boiler, wattage, basic design.

The unit did warm up fairly quickly and I was impressed with the quality of the accessories, using thick plastic, good quality rubber seals etc.  This model I think would work well as doing primary duty as a clothes steamer but its lack of pressure make it not the best choice for blasting nooks and crannies, where a really good steamer excels as a cleaning maching no other device can touch.

Let me explain.  I compared this steamer with the Saeco Piccolo steamer and with a high quality thermometer recorded the Saeco at about 190 degrees and the steamFast at about 170-180 degrees.  Secondly I put a paper cup on the floor and with both machines heated up with a full tank of water, I pointed the nozzle at the opening of the cup to see which model would blow the cup the farthest.  The SteamFast product blew the cup about five feet.  The Piccolo blew the cup 15 feet and probably would have kept going if it was not for the wall stopping it.  Not even remotely close.

Next I took both steamers out on my deck and pointed the nozzles at a hose that "overwintered" on my deck....complete with black moldy stains hiding the normally greeen hose.  The SteamFast product blew steam at the hose but it did not really eliminate the moldy stains.

Next tried the Piccolo...WOW....this sucker blasted those stains down to fresh green hose.

Test over.  Note: I also tried the same test with a Euro-Pro Shark Steam Blaster Ultra with similar results to the Chinese made SteamFast product.

I will add some more details in my review of the Saeco Piccolo. Needless to say, I returned the SteamMax.

Let me say, I think the overall positive results for this product are not surprising to me considering most users have not probably used an Italian made steam cleaner which seem to have hotter steam vapor, far more pressure, a longer track record of using similar technology in espresso machine manufacturing, etc.  The downside of the Italian products is that it might be a bit harder to find parts and service for since they are not produced for the mass market like the steamFast and shark products.  It's too bad as I really wanted the SteamFast or Shark to perform better.

Honestly if you don't make the comparison between the Piccolo or similar italian made steamer and the SteamFast, you may think you are getting a great product as it will produce consistent steam...but you won't be aware of HOW MUCH MORE YOU COULD DO with the serious pressure levels of the Italian steam cleaners.  I hope some other people do some comparisons.

All the reviews you may have read pointing out the sharp edges are exactly correct. Here's the deal: This thing is an excellent example of the stereotypical "cheap Chinese carp" that everyone complains about. The sheet metal used in the manufacture of this fryer is WAY too thin. And, it seems to have been made in a garage by someone using sub-standard sheet metal gear that needs to be tightened. Both of those things contribute to the sharp edges. Plan on doing a little filing or if you have a tool handy you can probably just burnish the edges. Also, due to the extreme thinness of the metal, the cover is very flimsy and gets very hot. And the knob by which one must lift it is quite small. It is clear to me that no American company would put their name on this item, and apparently neither would a Chinese company as there doesn't seem to be any sort of trade name on it anywhere. Or, maybe it's in Chinese and I just don't recognize it. Also pay attention to the remarks about NOT having a "fill to" line. I think I may have overfilled. Yes, the oil pan is also too flimsy for my taste. And yes, the fry basket is apparently NOT actually stainless steel and DOES seem to have a tendency to rust. Poor job of chrome plating or really poor steel?  Who knows? As for the temperature control and indicator, so it's in Celsius - so what? Get out your old oil/candy thermometer. It probably has both F and C scales so you can figure it out. Or, get a paint pen and make your own marks. All this being said, the machine DOES work. I have not yet been able to get a meter on it to see if it does use the wattage indicated, but I can't notice that it heats a whole lot faster than my previous one. This may be due to larger capacity/overfilling. Given the really cheap sheet metal work, I have serious reservations about the heating elements and controls - but after a few uses it still seems OK. I guess my advice is to be governed by the old adage, "you get what you pay for." Didn't pay much, didn't get much, but it works.

We live in Northern Michigan and get a late and early killing frost every single year.. This year I put a hoop house up over the garden using PVC, Wood and this plastic.. The hoop house is 15' long, 16' wide and 8' tall.. It has a peaked roof line. This plastic fit perfectly. We had poly windows to use around the bottom of the hoophouse so we cut off part of the plastic to make the doors, but the point is, it was big enough for this size greenhouse/hoophouse. It seems sturdy enough.. We had another hoophouse with greenhouse plastic that lasted 4 years. It collapsed this past winter, so we removed the plastic. That plastic was actually still in pretty good shape.. We aren't sure if this plastic is going to last that long or not, (kind of doubt it) but since it cost 1/4 of what we paid for the greenhouse plastic, we decided it was worth the try. Will know by the end of the summer how well it holds up to the sun and hot temps, but for now, it's doing what we wanted it to do.. It's 100 degrees  with very moist air in the hoophouse today with the doors open.. The plants seem to love it.

UPDATE: Product didn't make it through the winter.. It started ripping loose around the edges despite the fact that the snow slid right off it. One entire side is ripped loose and flapping in the wind.. It'll need to be replaced. Although it was very easy to work with and a great size, in the long run, greenhouse plastic is the better choice for hoop house/green house use.. But it was worth the try, although the price has increased by $10 since we bought it.. I wouldn't buy it again for the hoophouse..

The hole punch on my set was dull and worse yet, oversize. When compared against the grommet barrel, it is more than 1/16th too large. It is really good to get a tight fit between the fabric and the grommet barrel in order to keep stress off of the hole. This hole punch being large, will not do that properly. If you need to use it anyhow, the solution is simple. Put the hole punch in a drill. Run it for a few seconds against some sandpaper at a sharp angle (you will be able to see if the punch is polished all the way to the end.) Then leave it in the drill and "drill" through your fabric against a piece of scrap wood (no real pressure needed.) This makes a very clean hole.

It seems now days that everything has to be a Swiss Army Knife.  Very few products do just one thing well.  This is such a product.  It cleans floors, bare or carpeted.  I am an engineer and I love the way this vacuum cleaner is designed.  Air flow is straight through to a very large bag.  Don't get fooled by the 5 amp motor when the big heavy machines have 12 amps.  Because of the straight air flow  it isn't using power to get the air around corners. through small hoses, and out limited bag area.  I have a 12 amp Hover and this Eureka cleans better.  The 5 amp motor is also quieter and much lighter.  This vacuum weighs only 11 pounds and is very maneuverable.  The large area bags do a good job of filtering the air so you get no dust odor.  The foot controls on the base for the handle and power are convenient and easy to operate.  I guess because this is an old design that has been around a long time, Eureka doesn't advertise it and it is hard to find in stores.  Believe me, it is worth looking for.

We live in a three level townhome with 75% carpet and a 65lb dog that loves to shed. Our current vacuum is the BISSELL 5770 Healthy Home Bagless Upright Vacuum which does an admirable job keeping our house clean. However, we've only cleaned our carpeted areas once right when we moved in which was years ago. Therefore we've been in the market for a carpet cleaner we could use to clean up the carpet. Enter the Hoover Commercial C3820 Spotter and Carpet Cleaner with 3 Brush Roll Speeds. Here are my thoughts; Pros + Removable brushes make for easier cleaning. + Thorough cleaning with multiple spinning brushes. + Both tanks are removable and washable. + Cleans up small and medium stains/spills quite quickly. + Easy to use and assemble. + Long power cord of 35'. Cons - Quite heavy at around 30lbs. Be careful of tip overs when doing stairs. - Plastic components feel cheaply made and I worry about the seals holding. - Large size make storage a problem for those with little room. - Pricey for what you're getting. - 1 year warranty only. The Hoover Commercial C3820 Spotter and Carpet Cleaner with 3 Brush Roll Speeds is a very basic cleaner which does its job well enough. It had no problems getting basic strains, dirt and grime out of our carpet. However, I would really only recommend this vacuum for homes with more minimal amounts of carpet. It says "commercial" use but honestly I don't see that as a viable option. Also, The 7.9 amp motor feels a bit weak for a carpet cleaner. Unfortunately, this isn't the perfect cleaner for multiple pet household with a lot of carpet. Overall, while I found this cleaner capable I'm not sure I'd recommend it anyone based on our testing. However, if you're in the market for a very basic carpet cleaner this should fit the bill. I would recommend this vacuum to people living in carpeted apartments or smaller sized condos or homes but nothing larger, especially those with multiple pets, especially at the $260-$300 price point.

I buy sandpaper by the box, and have burned through many boxes. But only recently did a friend mention this adhesive-backed paper, and I'm glad he did. Durability-wise, it performs considerably better than regular sand paper, but what makes it so useful is the adhesive back. Here a few random points:
1. Less waste - you adhere a piece to the face of your sanding block, and don't have to wrap any paper around the sides. Result - you use 100% of the paper for sanding
2. For precise sanding, stick a piece of this paper at the very edge/corner/whatever of a sanding block, and you use the straight edge to get into tight corners, etc.
3. Need a third hand? Stick a piece of the paper to a piece of wood and clamp that wood to your workbench. Then, for small pieces, use both hands to slide the piece back and forth over the flat (and immobile) sandpaper. Hint: cut a piece or two of the paper and adhere to the "top side" of the piece you are sanding. This gives you great grip on the top as you slide the piece back and forth over the horizontal paper. Update: I found an old sample floor tile - it was very smooth and now serves as a great flat sanding surface with adhesive sandpaper (plus I can clean off residual adhesive easily with lacquer thinner)

Eventually the "stickyness" gives out on the paper - especially for the "gripping" pieces mentioned above, after you swap them a few times. The grit is still good, but the pieces won't stick. I use them like regular paper then.

I bought several different grits, and use both sides of several boards to stick on successive grits.

I don't hear any complaints about it.  This caulk is also versatile - it really makes me look like I know what I'm doing.  If you really paid attention you could easily see that I'm not very good at my "domestic responsibilities", but this caulk more than makes up for it.

What I don't like about it is it takes a long time to set up.  I would prefer a glue to be a FAST setting adhesive.  If speed of setting matters to you, this is not your glue... if you can wait for a glue to set, it is a good buy.
No complaints

These are high quality grommets, but they have a tendency to bind on the tool shaft when assembling them.  I've tried lubicating the tool first, but it still happens, and sometimes the lube stains the fabric, so I tried graphite with no better results.  The finished product is fine, but t's frustrating to continually have to pry the finished grommet off of the tool.  Perhaps a nylon insert might be the ticket.  Not bad for the price though.

Bought this as a replacement for my Fantom CV242H/Euro-Pro Shark canister vacuum. It is a standard size, so it fits perfectly. Bristles are just the right balance of soft and stiff, and they do not break off and they keep their shape under rigorous use. I have been using this for over a year, and it has stood up to the abuse. I definitely recommend.

Update: With a 20% solution it held up for several months, but the pump died.

I bought this Shop-vac 906-15-19 1 1/4" round brush accessory to replace the one that came with my shop-vac because the bristles were curling up and matted at the edges, which makes picking up the dust and debris around edges and corners impossible. The problems with the new one are: The old one has a hard plastic column that extends down the center of the brush so that there is better suction, the new one doesn't have the plastic column.  And there are noticeably fewer bristles on the brush - very flimsy,  which effects the strength of the suction.  If I use the new brush on my 3.0 HP the suction is half as good, if I use the new brush on my 2.5 HP it does not pick up anything. I am really getting tired of companies cutting corners to save themselves money and in doing so, making an inferior product. I'm going to look for a brush from another manufacture that will fit my machines and that will work the way it is suppose to. Shop-vac has lost my business as a future consumer.

So, I order this kit.  Based on the other reviews, I was either expecting my mouth to be burned off or to have a great set of white chomppers.  So the day they arrived came (I'm in Iraq by the way), and the whole day I was pumping myself up for what I considered the inevetible agony I was going to go through, as discussed by many people on here.
Got back to my room and got ready for battle.  Taking the advice of some on here, I only used half a vile on the top and bottom trays, want to wean myself onto the pain.... So... I put the trays in my mouth.  Closed my eyes and waited for the pain to start seering through my body and the foul taste of the gel (also reported) to make me throw up.  I also had a drool rag ready to go because it was also stated you would droll on yourself....... So I waited... and waited...
And waited.  I then realized I wasn't feeling a thing!  I was kinda dissapointed in a way, but I figured, hey, great, lets get it on!  So, after cooling the other viles of gel (they had liquified due to the heat) back into a gel state, I set off to give me some perally whites!  I used a whole vile in the top and bottom tray and again, braced myself.  And again, NOTHING happened.  There wansn't even a tingling sensation.  It didn't taste bad either, nor did I drool.  Not at all.  I have no idea what those people were doing, but everyone is different.
I went through 4.5 iterations for 20 minutes, with the 10 minute break in between.  The only semi-uncomfort, was when I was washing my mouth out, the inside of your lips will feel like they are overly chapped.  Not painful, just kinda icky.  But that goes away right quick.
After the last bout, I slowly walked to the mirror, expecting white nasty spots all over my teeth that were mentioned here.  And again... nothing.  Not even a color change.  At this point I am wondering if I got a bum deal, but then I remembered a few people menionted that they look like nothing is different, and then in an hour or two it comes out.  So I went to sleep, thinking.. Sweet, tomorrow its on!
My alarm woke me up at 0330 as it always does, went to the mirror... and yeah.. no noticable difference.  Boooo to this I said.
I give this a 2.  It didn't work, but it also didn't make me pass out from the pain.  I don't totally blame the product though.  It did say if the gel is melted to mail it back.  But being here, it coming melted is something I can't avoid and I don't have the time to mail it back.  That might have done something to it, you never know.  But yeah, I have some stips on the way from a friend and we'll see how thoes work.
No pain, no gain, no nothing!!  If you are feeling pain consider yourself lucky.  At least you know its doing something.
Fast delivery & product as described

I bought the Powertwist Plus V-Belt to replace the auto belt that came with my Jet Contractor Saw.  I have owned the saw for a year, but had just seen this product a few weeks ago.  I had just upgraded to a Forrest blade and was disappointed in the blades performance as far as getting a smooth glue line rip that all the reviewers were raving about.  I though my saw was a bit loud and vibrated a lot and it was recommended to me to try this V-Belt.  I thought $6 a foot was a bit high for a V-Belt, but if it worked it would be worth it.  It took me less than five minutes to take the old auto belt off, adjust the Powertwist V-Belt to length and install it.  When I first turned on the machine I just started laughing with joy.  Literally NO VIBRATION!!!  I could not believe it(Now, keep in mind my tablesaw in all other aspects is leveled just under perfection using Incra guaranteed squares and Stabila levels).  I ran some wood through and now I have a smooth glue line rip.  I now understand why people rave about Forrest blades and the PowerTwist V-Belt so much.  They really do work!!!!

Buyer  beware.  You cannot return this item to Amazon (due to product restrictions), and in California (our lovely state with the beyond-the-absurd personal safety laws) the tank will not fill due to the "special" nozzle gas-emission prevention controls that restrict the gasoline flow into the can because the spout is not compatible. My solution is to try to find an old plastic gas can that I can fill at the gas station even with the newfangled station safety nozzle, and then manually transfer the gas to these tanks for longer term storage using a good old fashioned plastic spout.

While the cans are nicely fabricated, I would NOT have purchased these expensive tanks if I had known they could not be filled directly at the gas station. Right now they sit empty in my garage as large metal doorstops.

I bought this vacuum because I was sick of canister vacuums. In my experience they are clunky, messy and clog easily.  I wanted something very simple, lightweight, and easy to store.  I think this is as close as I could ask for.

It took about 15 minutes or less to build. It is very light and glides very easily.  I don 't think the motor is super super strong, but it definitely gets the job done.  The suction was enough to get pet fur off the carpets, but not so strong that it sucked up my kitchen rug's edges when I went over it (which is really great because that can be so irritating to have to pull out).  Like most vacuums its not going to suck up your spare change and rubber-bands on the floor.

Please note it does not come with attachments, but there is an attachment kit that you can order if you care to.

An unexpected plus is that it is surprisingly quiet for a vacuum.  I think I could've been able to watch tv and vacuum without turning it up.  My cats didn't even seem phased.

 I can't forget to mention that I love that the design has not changed for what seems like decades.  It looks like it came straight out of the 50's.  Why change a good thing?

Manual brushing can't achieve so many strokes/minute like the sonic type brushes. The result is they really work better than manual (just my experimental observation) - teeth are cleaner yet not as clean and smooth as after dental cleaning despite the marketing claims. Don't delude yourself - sonic brushes can't clean between the teeth despite the fantastic marketing claims about the 'ultrasonic technology' lol. You will need flosing, interdental brushes or better water jet for that. Sonic vibrating brushes are gentler on the gums compared to the rotating brushes.

After using the sonicare brush for a month, I've replaced it with the CVS sonic brush which to my opinion cleans better - bigger brush and better contact with teeth. The only 'advantages' of sonicare is that its timer beeps every 30 seconds while the CVS timer just turns off the brush after 2 minutes of brushing (you can start it again to continue brushing) and sonicare has a charge indicator while CVS hasn't. The biggest advantage of CVS is the significantly lower price for the unit, which includes the charger, a UV sanitizer and 3 brush heads. The replacement CVS brush heads are way cheaper than the sonicare ones which appparently are made of gold, otherwise I can't understand why I am expected to pay $25-$35 for two plastic brush heads LOL

The thing I don't like about both sonicare and CVS brushes is that they don't use regular rechargable batteries so when their battery dies in a few years you will have to throw away the whole unit and get a new one.

If you want to vacuum dust only, then go ahead, but even that is debatable. I like ShopVac, and have bought two, of which I was very satisfied; one for my wife to vacuum the house (10 gal. 4.0HP) and one for me which I use on my model rc airplanes to keep the dust to a minimum (5 gal 2.5HP). This new 4.5HP unit which I bought for my woodworking shop is a total waste of my money. The unit cannot even suck-up small chips of wood, I tried to suck-up one small pebble, 1/8" in size at max. and it could not do it. I was very disappointed as I liked the fact that it can be hung on a wall yet was mobile if I wanted to move it around. I was unable to take up anything but the saw-dust and that even was a chore as I had to move the hose end with the attachment very slow. I tried using a 2.5" hose thinking it was the small 1.25" hose diameter, but that made it worst. The little 2.5HP unit I have for my models works better than this 4.5HP. I would love to get rid of it pronto. Do NOT buy this unit, you will be sorry you did. I do not know how some people gave this a 5 star rating even a 3 is too much. I had to give it 1 star because I am comparing it to other ShopVac units which I have in use, and I am extremely disappointed in it, especially since the HP rating is 4.5 and it is no were near the 4.0 my wife has, heck, even my 2.5 unit has more sucking power than this vacuum. Please, do not buy this machine. ShopVac has very good machines but not this one. Do not even look at it in the store, just pass it by and look at something else.

The product came in a plain cardboard box with no indication anywhere who the manufacturer is even though the Amazon website says B & C Eagle. The box did have a prominent warning on the outside stating that the unnamed manufacturer would not warranty the galavanize coating against deterioration for any period of time.

The nails themselves seemed to have a very thin zinc coating and were not aligned especially well in the strip. (they weren't all parallel to each other) I didn't use any so I can't say if the misalignment would have caused any jams but I'd rather see better quality control.

I recommend that you don't use this product for any serious outdoor structural project that will need to be inspected, especially ACQ treated lumber. Your inspector may want to know that you used quality fasteners. You  could find yourself tearing them out and starting over with nails from a known reputable manufacturer.

Keep 'em if you're making a dog house or fence, but don't risk it for anything important. I sent mine back.

Pathetically cheap and this is supposed to be the most premium tape on the market. So goes another top US company that has cheapened their goods. The last two orders were the same--just pure junk.  The tape barely sticks to a cardboard box (new cardboard). We tape up boxes waiting for UPS pickup and by the time UPS picks up next day the tape is already unfastened from the boxes. This stuff up until a couple of months ago was the very best. Do yourself a favor and now buy Duck tape Yes, that used to be a joke tape, but it far superior.  If this were the first batch that was bad, I would not write the review. But now this is continuous. If the 3M CEO reads this, thank you for taking what used to be the best in class product and move it to the bottom. They even changed the leader tape on the roll which is now almost impossible to get started. WHY 3M?  The great iconic consumer/business product scotch tape company makes their product comparable to cheap eastern imports. Scotch tape that doesn't stick! Great idea.

I have shipped a lot of products in my time, both commercially and at home. When I saw that there was a "super-strong" packing tape available I decided to give it a got and see if it was in fact superior to plain old packing tape. So is it? Well...kinda...

I used the tape to wrap several packages, and it tore in the center just like regular packing tape. I thought there was no improvement at all.

And then on the 23rd of April 2011 I moved to a new apartment and used this tape to tape up moving boxes. The tape greatly improves in strength as you get farther down the roll apparently, because the tearing in the middle of the tape stopped. That said, on the other hand it does not seem quite as sticky as I would like, detaching from the boxes a bit too easily.

As such, when I mail packages I simply use more of this tape than normal to ensure that it doesn't pop off the package. Not bad. Definitely good tape for moving due to strength and ease of use, less recommended for shipping due to less than normal stickiness in my experience.

I used...
Conair Interplak (9 months. Bought at Target)

I now use...
Oral-B Vitality Precision Clean (2 months and counting. Bought on Amazon).

Comparison...
1) Batteries: Both are rechargeable (no need to fuss with buying and replacing batteries). Interplak recommends you run the batteries down every 6 months and then do a full recharge before use again. Oral-B encourages you to keep the toothbrush on the charger all the time, as they claim "there is no such thing as over-charging". Interplak has a light that turns on to let you know it's charging, Oral-B does not. Interplak's charger is bulkier, but that's only because it has two ports for you to stick extra/replacement brushes on.
2) Power: Interplak has decent power, but Oral-B is definitely more powerful, and very feisty.
3) Replacement Brushes: To get the best cleaning quality from your electric toothbrush, you should replace the heads around every 3 months. Oral-B brush heads are a bit smaller, which is better for navigating around your mouth and "precision cleaning". Department stores are more likely to carry Oral-B replacements, but both are readily available online, and they go for around $5 to $10, depending.
4) Function and use: Dentists recommend at least two minutes of brush time. Oral-B has a two-minute timer, signaled NOT by sound (like I thought), but by short, intermittent bursts, to let you know two minutes are up. This feature is on all the time and cannot be disabled. Interplak does not have this feature. Oral-B has a simple on/off toggle button. Interplak has two buttons - one for on, one for off.

Conclusion...
Personally, I recommend Oral-B over Conair. It was like, NOW I feel like my teeth are clean! Happy shopping~

This product is supposed to be a commercial product which, to me, means that someone would be utilizing this on a regular basis, more than once a month -- if this works for you right away great but then you have to deal with the mess of the fluid after using it, creating more of a mess to clean up. I was very interested in finding a good glue that I could use in a snap that would make for a strong and durable joint. Well, I sort of found one. This glue does make for a strong joint ( the durability seems to be there - time will tell ), but the "use in a snap" part was disappointing ( 20 minute working time and 90 minute dry time, humidity dependent and 1-4 hours under clamp ). I will compare this glue to expanding  foam. Once it dries, spray foam is the closest thing to it. It never really totally scrapes off, so sanding is necessary, and it is near impossible to figure out just how much to use and exactly where to apply because of the foaming process. I will not use this glue for fine and exposed jointery, I am pretty certain it works well and as advetised, but the "ooze" is something that I am not pleased with - sure it gets into tight places and fills voids, but by the time I scrape, sand and dig it out and off of everyting around it - it has taken me three times longer than with other products and my details do not seem as nice by then. So 3 because it works well- just watch where you use it !

Besides my sanders foam pads had to be replace because this stuff stick very well bringing the foam off with it, this is a great bargain I had very big jobs requiring lot of sand paper and as we all know that the box store charge a lot for the sticky back paper.  So replacing the soft pad on my sanders is a small pay off for using this product.

I heard about these belts from some articles that I had read in some woodworking magazines.  I thought, maybe someday, but not right now.  After my last project, out of frustration with my machine, I decided to buy one.  I have a Grizzly contractors grade table saw.  Nice machine, just shook a bunch.  I didn't even read the instructions for sizing the belt.  It took less than 2 minutes to remove the old one, size the powertwist to length and install it.  It was that easy.  I stood both a nickel and a penny on edge and threw the switch.  I just stared in amazement as they both just stood right where I placed them.  Don't wait to buy this belt, or you'll be asking yourself "Why did I wait so long?".

I used this product hoping it would be an improvement over the messy whitening strips. The instructions call for putting an ampule of product (or a little less) into a tray that you mold to your teeth and keeping it on your teeth for 20 minutes, followed by a 10 minute rest. You are supposed to repeat this 30 minute ritual 3 more times for a total of 2 hours to get whiter teeth. Right now I am wishing I never touched the things. My teeth are no more white than when I started and my gums hurt so bad I can't eat or sleep, even after taking migraine medicine. I'm in the market for a new steam cleaner.  Like many other reviewers I bought my Europro from HSN a few years ago.  They marketed it on TV as the "Mercedes" of their steamer line. With two sloppy teenage boys, and a huge Newfoundland dog, messes rule my house.  It was a chore, though, to use this steamer since it was a slow cleaning process, but it was just so thorough and everything came out looking new, but sometimes I just didn't want to drag it out, search for the funnel, fill it up,  wait for it to heat up, then spend an hour cleaning one or maybe two rooms depending on how gross the job was.  But I really miss it and need another one badly.  But not Euro Pro this time.  I probably will go with the McCulloch since it's left than half what I paid and none of the reviewers have said that it sh*t the bed yet like most of the reviewers here!

The heavy-duty tape itself is quite thick and sturdy, but not especially sticky, so I don't find that it's more "heavy duty"  than regular packing tape, since the strength of the tape depends on both the thickness ("mil") of the tape, as well as the strength of the adhesive.

After using up the included roll of tape, I refilled the dispenser with a lighter-weight tape, as my purpose for buying the item was for the reusable dispenser. Unfortunately, after about 2 or 3 rolls of tape, the metal blade fell off. I was able to reattach it with superglue, but I would definitely not call it "reusable" if its lifespan only covers a few rolls of tape. Having used a similar Scotch dispenser for a few years before it wore out, it was a disappointment and I had expected more from this brand.
Although it was smaller sized than I expected, I like the product.  It is easy to put together and take apart.  It is great and I have no regrets on the purchase.

I just moved into an apartment with a new synthetic carpet that sheds like a pack of afghan hounds; it choked my bagless vacuum in under a minute.  I needed a sturdy, no-frills, bagged vacuum like the Montgomery Ward upright I used for over 20 years before it died.

This model was almost identical, and now that I've had it for a few weeks, I'm happy as a clam.  It has an old-fashioned rotating brush/beater roller, 5 carpet height adjustments, great suction for 5 amps, and comes pre-fitted with a humongous disposable liner bag (type F&G), plus a spare belt for the roller.  Some parts that used to be steel have been replaced with thick plastic, but it seems plenty sturdy, and it's much lighter to maneuver and carry than my old all-steel model.  The on/off button and lock/unlock for the handle are both on the base, so they're foot controls; carpet height is adjusted by a dial on the front of the base.  The long cord (20 feet or so) doesn't retract, you just wind it over hooks on the handle.  The spring-attached fabric bag has a full-length zipper, inside which the disposable bag (which fills the cover from end to end) slides on with another spring.  Quick, simple.

One pass with this puppy picked up enough carpet fluff missed by the bagless to knit a throw rug, but there's still plenty of room left for future dirt.  It's also a lot less noisy than my smaller bagless.  The only qualm I had in buying this was the lack of attachments for cleaning upholstery & suchlike, but I found an inexpensive accessory kit made for it (crevice tool, round dust brush, upholstery brush, extension tubes, looooong flexible hose) right here on Amazon:  the "Electrolux Home Care 60E 6-Piece Deluxe Tool Set,"  so my joy is complete.

Though the image on this page looks rather green, the vacuum is actually jet black, and the bag is a black-white-red random print.  It comes in a flat box, minor assembly required.  Highly recommended for those who remember how good the old vacuums were, don't want to spend a fortune just to clean their carpets, or are into retro styling.

Look these are Fluke leads and that should count for something.  Safety and build quality are top notch.  The safety rating on these leads is 1000V CAT III / 600V CAT IV.  That's pretty much top of the market, but not unique.  The probes themselves are a reasonable length with probe tips that are sharp.  The banana plugs have good shrouds and fit well.  So these will suit most any application and serve you well.  However what I don't like is the jackets.  These probes (TL75) hover around the $20 mark and the Fluke TL71's hover around the $25.  And yet when you unwind these out of the box, they retain that crinckle from being twist tied.  The TL71s do not due to being made of silicone rubber.  I find this to be very irritaing because it just promotes tangling and frustration especially in colder temperatures.  Which is bad when working on something that could kill you.  For $5 more you don't have this problem and get something of much higher quality.  To be honest even I would say I'm being too critical here if it wasn't for the fact that for around $7 I picked up a set of Sinometer knock-off of the TL71s that are almost as good as them!  And the key feature is they pretty well hang straight.  I was shocked!  I don't know what their made of but it's darn near tangle free.  Frankly put, I prefer them to the TL75s that came with my Fluke meters for usability.  But I will admit, that I trust the safety rating and quality of the TL75s more.  If these are ever changed to be made of the same silcone rubber as the TL71s, then these are 5 star leads in my opinion.  But as it stands, $20 for these is just too much.

Note I've inlcuded a hanging comparison with the Sinometer's, the TL75s, and the TL71s on the main product page.

I had two Sonicare Elite 7300 toothbrushes over the last 4 years.  Sonicare works great and cleans your teeth well.  It is a bit bulky, noisy and vibrates a lot but you get used to that.  If you don't remove the brush head from the base after each use to clean the interior mold starts to build.  Not good.

Besides, both Sonicare units I owned had the same problem.  After around 18 months the battery took less and less of a charge until after around 26 months I could only brush my teeth 4 to 5 times per charge.  Big problem if you travel a lot or when several people use the same base.  I called Sonicare about it and was told the base should last for up to 5 years.  Whatever, the warranty is only two years.

So I looked at other products and found the Oral B S-320 Sonic Complete system.  The base is made by Braun in Germany.  I have owned 4 Braun electric shavers over the past 24 years.  The last one still worked fine when I replaced it 5 years ago but I wanted to upgrade to the new Activator.  So my experience with Braun products "made in Germany" and their reliability had been very good.

The Oral B S-320 Sonic Complete is lighter than the Sonicare Elite.  The Oral B toothbrush head is designed a bit different than the Sonicare.  After using the Oral B now for about 2 month I have the feeling that the Oral B cleans my teeth better and I think it is due to the difference in toothbrush design.

The Oral B sits essentially on a vibrating stick vs. the screw cap method used by Sonicare.  The vibrating stick seems better from a hygiene standpoint and creates a similar amount of vibration.

Another big difference between both systems is the cost of the brush heads.  3 replacement heads for Oral B Sonic Complete are $18 on Amazon; 2 brush heads for the Sonicare system are between $23 and $28 on Amazon.  Since the price for the base systems is similar the savings from the toothbrushes for the Oral B is quite substantial, especially if several people are using the system.

Overall, I am very pleased with the Oral B system and even my dentist thinks there is no difference in terms of effectiveness between both systems.  Based on my experience with the Braun shavers I am hopeful the Oral B will last longer than the Sonicare.

I had to drill the holes from the top-down and incorrectly assumed that I could just turn the vise over (so the flanges would be flush with the bench-top while drilling). Because the holes are in slightly different places, none of the bolts I was using through the bench lined up with the vice's holes.

Some dowel and wood-glue to fill the misplaced holes, and I was able to install it correctly. Haven't really used it yet, but I guess it seems sturdy enough for the money.

My father had picked up a couple of these calipers thinking they were a good deal.  I checked one using a 1" micrometer standard. I found the calipers were both off.  One was off by .021 (21 thousandths) and the other was off by .007 (7 thousandths) when measuring an exact inch.  I did not have a two inch standard available, but it stands to reason that at 2 inches they could be off by as much as 42 and 14 thousandths respectively.  These inexpensive calipers might be suitable for rough work but I would not count on them for fine machining, ammunition reloading, or any job where precise and accurate measurements are critical.

When it comes to storing gasoline you do not want to take any chances. This can is painted red which usually means gasoline. I like the fact that it stores the gasoline for my generator safely, but there is one thing I don't like. To be honest, when filled with gasoline it is pretty heavy and not that easier to maneuver. I know it is made out of metal so it doesn't leak like plastic containers sometimes do it however is a safe way to store highly flammable gasoline even if it does get a little cumbersome.

I buy this stuff from Walmart for 2 dollars a tube.  It makes great cheap painters caulk.  It tools well and dries fast.  I don't use it on problem cracks or in areas that it won't be painted over.  If I anticipate that a crack will expand or have any movement in the future I use a better latex caulk like Alex Ultra 230, Dynoflex 230, or Sashco Big Stretch.  If the joint needs to be water proof, never fail and I don't need too pretty of a bead I use Lexel.  It's a pain to use and clean up though.

In summary Alex Plus is the best deal for cheap caulk.  Anything cheaper isn't worth the tube it's in and will crack in the future.  Any caulk that's better cost over twice as much and in some cases over 5 times as much.

I bought the "old" style Gorilla Glue a while back and had it for about 2 years. I used it a lot, and generally was happy with it. However, this is not a miracle adhesive and does have some limitations, which I'll go into later.

This is a polyurethane-based glue, the active ingredients are diphenylmethane diisocyanate and some other reactants, and are very similar to those in expanding polyurethane foam, or 2-part polyurethane used to make molds or rigid polyurethane foam for insulation. Like wood glue, it reacts with moisture in the air, and just like poly foam, it expands when curing. It doesn't contain any aromatic hydrocarbons or suspended solvents like toluene, heptane, or acetone, or alcohols, so it's non-flammable and relatively safe as it doesn't produce strong and dangerous fumes. It does have a funk to it though, but not obnoxious.

It works pretty good, but that largely depends on a couple factors. One is the surface it's being applied to, and the other is the type of application. Gorilla Glue by nature doesn't have good tensile strength and isn't very strong in shearing-type loads. When it cures, it gets frothy and expands to 3x's it's original volume, so that can cause problems with joints that shift when it dries. The surface prep is important, like any adhesive. It doesn't work good on bright, shiny surfaces like steel or plastic, and works best on porous things like wood, concrete, fabric or unglazed ceramics. If using it on steel or plastic, you need to sand the surface to rough it up to get the best bond.

I used this to secure the little nobbles that go on the bottom of the toilet seat, and they came off within a couple weeks. I used it to glue the stock back on my stepson's wood and metal replica rifle, and it broke in a month. So I was pretty disappointed with it. It worked great on wood and some pottery, but didn't work when I glued the handle back on a mug that broke off. The trick is to firmly clamp the bonded items together or the glue will expand and compromise the joint. The frothy glue isn't resistant to shearing loads, unlike something like a hard epoxy (JB Weld, etc.), but works good when used to bond items with good surface area contact. The less surface area bonded, the weaker the bond. If you have a small surface to bond to, it's better to get hard epoxy.

It's pretty easy to use, just apply a small amount of glue (a little goes a long ways) and clamp or compress the surfaces being bonded together. It helps to moisten the surfaces being bonded. You need to be cautious and clamps are important as the glue will expand and try to push the pieces apart. When the glue dries, it expands and will leak out everywhere if you use too much of it, so be cautious and not liberal in applying it. There may be some extrusion from the joints, but that's normal. You can scrape it off with a knife blade or sand it off. It is messy, sticky, and won't clean off with soap and water. Acetone, paint thinner, or alcohol are the only cleaners that will work.

Pros

Strong bonds when used correctly
Doesn't contain toxic chemicals
Non flammable
Waterproof

Cons

Needs meticulous surface prep on nonporous mediums
Low tensile strength
Expands when curing
Requires solvents for clean up

So Gorilla Glue is a good product. Perfect for wood and pottery and stone, but requires extra attention on steel and plastic. Overall, I'd prefer a 2-part epoxy over this just because it doesn't expand and makes a stronger bond and resists lateral loads better.

This is a great idea, but as a guy who is currently in the middle of residing his house with Hardie planks, I can see a flaw inherent in this product. Although the hardie planks are a manufactured products, all hardie planks of the same width, are not actually the same width. In fact of the 280 planks I bought that are all supposed to be 6-1/4 wide (to get the 5-inch reveal) some are 6-1/4, some are more like 6-1/8, and some are more like 6-3/8. So if you measure the 1-1/4 down from the top as these guages do, you are not always going to get a 5-inch reveal. James Hardie, What's up with that? This is a demonstratable truth. To get an equal 5-inch reveal, you really need to measure 5 inches up from the bottom of each plank. You may not really care if some of your planks have a 4-7/8 reveal, and others have a 5-1/4 reveal, and others get the 5-inch. You may in fact be using these planks on a spec house in the burbs that you can't see from your house. I can see my siding from my house, and I do want to get a 5-inch reveal on all my siding.

I realize James Hardie says you MUST have a 1-1/4 overlap on all boards, but James ought to make a more consistant product. He probably has several different molds being used for manufacturing and they aren't checked for being out of whack often enough.
