I bought this product with absolutely no expectations. It was a good price and I had never tried whitening products before. The first issue I encountered was shaping the trays. Using hot tap water doesn't really work. You have to heat it in the microwave for a little bit for it to really shape the trays. Two hours doesn't really sound like a long time, but with trays in your mouth and saliva building up, it gets rather uncomfortable. I tried lying on the couch on my back to stop the saliva from building up in my mouth; bad idea. It worked on session fine, but I tried it again and some of the gel dripped down my throat. It makes you sick to your stomach and gave me really intense heartburn a few hours later. My best results were with just spitting in the sink every 7-10 minutes. I didn't have issues with tooth sensitivity, but it really does burn your gums. I didn't start feeling it until the end of my third tray. I have a pretty high pain tolerance, and I did finish the last tray, but it literally felt like someone had taken coarse sand paper to my gums. The next day brushing my teeth, even while being careful about my gums, they started to bleed. I tried using less gel, but there's not really any way to prevent it from dripping out of the trays and onto your bottom gums. As for the effectiveness, it did work, but it wasn't drastic. For the amount of discomfort you have to endure, I'm not sure if the results justify it. But it does work, so if you're willing to tough it out for noticeable but minimal results, go for it.

I liked this can at first because it's very solid, sturdy and well made. However, I have stopped using it and will take it to the hazmat disposal site. Here's why: First: The can is VERY hard to hold while pouring. It would require three hands to do it right, and I only have two. The plastic lid-opening handle is too far forward to reach with the fingertips of the hand that's holding the can by its welded-on steel handle. You have to pull the lid handle back with one hand first, with the can on the ground, and then, with the lid open, slip the thumb of your other hand under the steel handle and grab the lid handle with your fingertips. Although that's extremely awkward, it's sort of a necessary safety feature with this potentially dangerous can. It requires you to release pressure in the can before lifting it. If you don't open the lid until the can is tilted, you can get a forceful spray of gasoline over the top of the funnel onto whatever is in front of you, like a hot mower engine. But pouring the gasoline is very cumbersome anyway, because there's nothing to grip with the other hand to tilt the can except for the thin bottom edge. You're trying to pour and watch for overflows with one hand doing two tasks and the other trying to tilt the heavy can full of gasoline without a secure way to do it. It's just way more trouble and dangerous than it's worth. Second: It's IMPOSSIBLE to empty the can with the funnel in place. The can has to be tilted so far forward that you're pouring over, not onto, the far edge of the funnel. Unless you take off the funnel, you'll never get out the last half gallon or so of gas. This design looks smart, but the open but attached funnel is very hard to use and could easily be very dangerous. I went back to using my four-year-old No-Spill can, which is a hundred times easier to use and very much safer.

I honestly can't remember what I had in mind when I bought this, but I do remember what I ended up using it on. I replaced the battery in my smartphone (droid mini) and the battery needs to be glued in place. I used this since it was the only glue I had on hand, but it was definitely the wrong choice. This glue cures almost instantly, so it doesn't give you time to position whatever you are gluing down. A couple months later I went to change the battery again, and the glue had become hard as a rock. I basically had to chip away at it.

So anyways this glue is not good for everything, but I am sure it is good for some things. It is very strong and will fill gaps. It is hard and rigid when it cures, not soft. I believe other cyanoacrylate glues are similar, so these properties are not why I rated it less than 5. I gave it 3 stars because months later, my phone still smelled like vinegar. I don't have experience with other cyano glues, but I don't think the smell is supposed to last so long. If I am wrong about that, tell Bob I'm sorry for the poor rating

I had a new 8" jointer that was relatively smooth.  However, at times, and only while pushing wood across the jointer, I'd feel a little rocking motion.  I'd tried these belts before, on a drill press, and knew they'd made a big difference there.  So, I bought a set of these from Amazon and put them on my jointer, and voila!  The vibration is gone.
They're easy to put on and resize, too.
It's truly hard to conceive that some of the vibrations felt on certain pieces of equipment are coming from the belts.  In the case of my drill press, for instance, it was a last resort... I'd tried everything else first (measuring for runout, etc.).  Yet, the problem what apparently the joint in my old black nylon belts.  Do yourself a favor and try these belts BEFORE you spend a lot of time looking for the problem elsewhere.  They're an upgrade in almost every case!  They're not cheap, but if they solve your problem and improve your machine, they're worth it!

The American Southwest is a vicious beast when it comes to vacuums. The ever present grains of sand eventually turn these machines into sputtering heaps. After relinquishing my overpriced Dyson to the neighborhood tinkerer, I sought to go back to what works.

I had a flashback to the days of my Grandma Nan and her sonorous Reagan era Eureka. It was a bagged behemoth that churned over carpet nap like no other. Seeking something similar, I settled on the Boss. Unlike bagless vacuums, the Boss does not cough up dust at every start. The suction on this thing has yet to diminish. Quite frankly, I'm not sure why I kept buying bagless vacuum after bagless vacuum.

I found this belt has virtually eliminated all the Vibratiom from the New Powermatic 64A I just purchased. First, I was very disappointed that the new saw had vibration, but thru research, found that this was very common in the 64A. I also found that they (those with the same problem) all switched the belts out for this one as a remedy.  The make-up of the V Belt is rather simple but ingeniouis, lending itself to be easily shortened (I had to remove two links to keep it from touching the belt guard support on my saw). Here is the real rub (sorry) , if you do a search for these belts, to find the best price, you will find a huge spread in the pricing. I found mine for 24 dollars thru an online auction, about 50 to 75 percent cheaper than the online stores. The bottom line is this belt does make a huge difference in reducing vibration. My saw now runs vibration free.

I have used Crest white strips in the past without irritation and decent results. I even had my teeth professionally whitened 14 years ago and though it did cause sensitivity, it was bearable the the results at least 6 shades lighter.

 Since I drink coffee daily I needed a touch up and bought the Rembrandt 2 hour system thinking it would be similar, but stronger than the Crest product.  Well, similar no, stronger, COMPLETELY!  To the point that it put blisters on my gums that lasted 2 days.

I followed directions but the solution migrates onto the gum line slightly even if you are careful . I put in the trays for the first 20 minute session.  I felt my teeth were getting a bit sensitive and the manufacturer states is a normal side effect.  15 minutes following into the second 20 minute session, a  burning sensation started at the gumline and was too uncomfortable for me to continue.  After rinsing my mouth out I saw how red my gums were, and my teeth hurt terribly.  I noticed the little blisters forming within minutes after that and called the company because I thought it was a severe reaction for a home use product.
Please use with caution if you want to try this home bleaching system, but consider the other alternative products out there that are safer. They may take longer to achieve the level of whiteness you desire, but it's better than going through a painful experience like I did.

If you get a working set, these are excellent probes. However, I had to return them twice to get a working set. The original set (and its first replacement) had at least one bad connection where the wire connects inside the probe handle. This caused very different readings depending on the orientation of the wire. I finally got a good set and they're working great, but for the price I should have gotten a working set the first time.

I use these at work with a Fluke 87V DMM, they see medium usage and I take very good care of them. The supposed "working set" I had, have started to read higher resistance (15 ohms), so they are on their way out after only about 2 months of use. Luckily work paid for them, because I'd be pretty angry if I spent $50 on these and couldn't even get a set that lasted. I understand that Fluke could have had a bad batch of probes, but I seriously question buying these again in the future. The standard-issue 25-cent garbage probes my work provides last much longer.

I bought this vacuum cleaner to supplement my vacuuming with a full size canister vacuum with all the attachments.  I wanted it for quick vacuuming jobs in between.  It was extremely important to have the 6 levels of height for the frieze carpet I have (Mohawk SmartStrand Silk). My older canister vac has 4 settings but this is even better.  The only thing I had to get used to is moving it back and forth.  The first time I vacuumed, on pulling it back towards me, the front was dipping a little bit low and the vacuum is so great that the carpet actually visibly raised up.  I think I have it down now after just a few vacuums.  Because of allergies, I also purchased HEPA filter bags along with this Eureka.  I am happy that it was simple to assemble, easy  to use, won't beat up my carpet (now that I have the knack for forward/back motion) and will definitely keep my rug cleaner because I am more apt to vacuum more often because of it's ease vs. hauling out the canister vac and dragging it around.

I used the Sonicare Elite for several years, buying the hype that it was cleaning my teeth better than I could.  But then my dental hygienist pointed out that it was also brushing away the base of my gums with its back-and-forth action--she showed me the linear ridges it has made in my gums.  I don't apply alot of pressure when brushing, so this was upsetting, especially since the damage is permanent.  She'd been trying to get me to switch to the Oral B for ages, so when my sister-in-law (also a hygienist) recommended the Oral B, I went out and got one.  The circular action doesn't wear away the gum line, and my teeth are significantly cleaner.  Even though I floss every day, I still had plaque build-up behind my bottom front teeth with the Sonicare.  With the Oral B, it's gone.  And with the variety of brushing styles that automatically switch when you change a brush head (several options are included!), it's a lot more bang for your buck.

Everyone in my family has the Sonicare. We purchased 4 after our dental hygienist recommended the technology.
This was 3 years ago. What have we experienced in those 3 years?
1. Once you use this technology a normal / manual toothbrush will make your mouth seem dirty after brushing
2. The automated timing and beeps, if followed properly, will 'remind' you to brush thoroughly
3. The gums DO NOT RECEDE because of the Sonicare: you still need to floss and remove plaque build up (but less thereoff); this point is made since some people seem to blame this technology for dental issues on here. Ask your dentist!
4. The have ONE SERIOUSLY DISGUSTING DESIGN FLAW: saliva, toothpaste etc. flows into the opening of the screw on brush heads and you will find a stinking slimy residue in there unless you take the head off every 2 days for a serious boiling. This is the one reason we removed stars.
5. We upgraded to the new FLEXCARE RS980 versions with the UV sanitizer and the design flaw has been corrected (plus replacement brush heads are half the price).
If I could give this product a ZERO, I would. Followed directions exactly and the next morning I have very painful blisters inside my mouth where the product burned.  Will never use again.

Notes:  1) I purposely left it in the sun, and it  developed gas smells around spout (would have been very surprised if it did not).  2) As noted in other reviews, it can develop pressure inside the can, so open the spout while the can is flat first before positing it to pour  again, this is expected with the high level of spout seal.  3) Although rated for 5 gal. I do not think anything more than 4.5 gal is safe.  4.5 gal fills to the bottom of the spout (see pressure note).

Bad:  Attached plastic pour spout needs to be removed to fill with gas.  The plastic spout leaks horribly around where it attaches to the gas can, drooling gas down the side of the can in every pouring position from careful to fast.  I now detach the pour spout and use it like a funnel, but that is not possible with about half of my needs  not long before the now non-attached spout is lost.  Pouring from the can directly to a gas tank was very messy and wasteful sloshing gas all over.  If the gas can metal spout itself was a few inches longer, it would fill 95% of my needs.

Very Very Bad (for my needs):  I was looking for a gas can I could take in a float plane and then transfer to a backwoods fishing boat.  The spout cover is held down only by a spring.  This is a terribly dangerous can, because that seal does not lock, so I can open the seal by just pushing it with my finger or it tips and hits something.  Seeing it tipped over and dumping its entire contents was very very scary.  Admittedly, this is rare, but my old smelly drippy plastic cans NEVER failed like that.  If the seal on this gas can would lock like a REAL NATO can, it would be great.  My gas can search for this need continues.

Bottom line:  This gas can is good, but an improved spout and positive locking cap would be huge improvements.  Great smell improvement for caring it in a trunk (dont overfill).  Other than that, I don't see where it is any safer than the stupid new plastic cans for most users needs.  The high price reduces buying it just to try it to see if it is a fit.

While the slots for each size seem accurate enough to their corresponding decimal thickness (use a caliper if you really need something reliable), it is important to understand gauge sizes.  This is based on the 1893 US Standard which is out of date unless you are only looking at stainless steel sheets.  You can do your own research on their origins and differences (link below), but most manufacturers, welding machines, etc use the Manufacturers Standard Gauge in their references.  Therefore, while this handy little tool will say that 16ga is 0.0625" (per US Standard), your Miller welding machine and Miller's pocket thickness gauge will use 0.0598" for 16ga.  Admittedly, this is literally about the width of a hair but if you are measuring something, you should at least know why there is a difference.  Just keep in mind that if using the gauge numbers alone the US Standard is slightly thicker than the Manufacturers Standard for the same gauge.  This is why ASTM A480-10a contains the statement, "The use of gage number is discouraged as being an archaic term of limited usefulness not having general agreement on meaning."

With all that said, it would be nice if General Tools would offer a gauge that contained the more common Manufacturer's Standard.

Interesting short article about the difference between US and Manufacturer's Standards
https://answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20070306163511AAPyeYU

This is an excellent product and this applies to the 80 grit and 120 grit versions purchased 07/2017. At first I was concerned about filling but I clean the abrasive with just a shop vac as I'm working on the material, rust, paint, most everything comes off the paper easily.  There is no waxed paper backer on the adhesive which surprised me but it sticks vigorously to the glass plate I have.  Very economical to use with long wear and low fill I'm sure I'll find other uses for this.

The one detractor and why 4 stars is that the adhesive. It is so strong I found it difficult to remove from the glass.  I use a heat gun now to peal the paper then follow with paint thinner or similar mild solvent and a razor scraper to remove the residue.  Most or all of the adhesive comes off the paper in my case and it is messy to clean up.  It is very infrequent in my case to need to change the paper.  I'd offer 5 stars if there was a paper back and a slightly less aggressive adhesive.

I highly recommend this product regardless.

The Cepco floor jack is a fantastic tool if you are installing hardwood flooring and want really tight joints in those areas next to a wall where you cannot get a flooring nailer. Instead of using screwdrivers, chisels, or wedges to force the flooring together, the floor jack simply presses it into place with no bother and no fuss.
I recommend using a 2x4 or 2x6 at least 36" long against the wall that you are going to press against to keep from damaging the wall or pushing a single stud out of place. The wall jack can generate a lot of force and in the hands of a careless installer it could dislocate a wall or partition.
While this tool is designed primarily for installing hardwood flooring, creative carpenters will undoubtedly find many was to use this tool to precisely move framing members. It is worth every penny that I paid for it.

I purchased this cross slide vise by Shop Fox for use on my Ridgid drill press.  The vise is fine for holding a piece to simply drill a hole.  You are assured the hole is vertical and straight. However, if you want to drill a series of holes in line by using the cross slide travel, I find the holes will not be in line when I finish.

The reason for this is the vise portion is not at a perfect 90 degrees to the transverse travel portion.  Worse yet, there is no adjustment to correct the vise to a perpendicular position.

I also wanted to use the vise to make slots and mortises by using a center cutting end mill in the drill press.  However, with the vise not being perpendicular, the slot will be out of line by almost a 1/16" after about 8" of travel.

My opinion is if you only want to drill a hole or two, this is a good economical vise.  If you want quality and precision, spend the money to buy a really good cross slide vise.

Like the Elenco ST74 ST74 AC Line Splitter, this product has a X1 and X10 current loop transformer and a line / neutral banana jack for measuring voltage. You can read my review on the ST74 for the advantage of having a X10 loop to use with your meter, but this design lacks some desirable features found on the ST74. I should point out that both products insist on hanging from the outlet supplying power. This is fine for a new, high quality outlet, but often problems happen with old, worn out jacks that barely grip a heavy cord. Remember that the outlet must support both these devices and the weight of your amp clamp. The missing features here are: 1 - there is no banana jack for "EARTH/GROUND". Since outlets can be miswired, or have an open earth connection, this is an important line to be able to probe safely. The ST74 has this jack 2 - the output jack to your appliance is ONLY for the US standard. This is fine most of the time, but on the rare chance you need to test a foreign plug, the "UNIVERSAL" jack on the ST74 will let you plug almost any power cord into it. 3 - Finally the ST-74 costs a little less. I do think this is better built than the ST-74, but that's just from "feel" of the product. Both products "hang" off the power outlet you put them into and lack a 6" or 12" power cord, which would be nice to accommodate inconveniently located outlets or outlets that won't support the extra weight of a current transformer + amp clamp. I would give this 4 stars if it had a power cord and 5 stars if it had a ground jack as well as the line and neutral. I've seen too many worn out power outlets that won't hold onto an adapter plus an amp clamp. If you don't care to measure ground impedance, don't think you'll ever work on foreign power cord devices, and have some more money, then its fine for you. But the ST-74 still does more for less and is a better value.

Propylene Glycol (PG) present in some toothpastes, and mouthwashes, is a chemical that your Toyota recognizes. It is an antifreeze, and you probably know that  antifreeze (used in countries that experience winter) has killed many cats and dogs that have lapped it up.

PG is used as a wetting agent in toothpaste and mouthwash, but it is so readily absorbed into the skin that the EPA requires anyone working around it to wear goggles and protective clothing. The Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) warns against skin contact because PG has systemic consequences, such as brain, kidney, and liver abnormalities.

However, no such warning is required on underarm deodorants, toothpastes, or other products containing PG. Does the use of PG in toothpaste, for use in an area where its readily absorbed, seem logical to you?

In high concentration, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), an extremely alkaline substance, destroys protein instantly. In the mouth, it dissolves oral soft tissues, imparting a sick feeling. Dissolving off the protein with NaOH is not the way I want my patients to get clean teeth yet many dentists use these products to clean their patients teeth.

Polyethylene glycol (PEG) is used in cleansers to dissolve oil and grease and in personal products as a thickener. PEG is a potential carcinogenic substance that, when used on the skin, alters its natural moisture factor, leaving the skin vulnerable to aging and invasion by harmful bacteria, PEG has no logical therapeutic benefit in toothpastes, but it is in quite a number of them.

A design that has stood the test of time....The Eureka 1934B works very well because of it's design.  The design of this vacuum has been around since the 60's & for good reason.  The air path is simple, it does not have a lot of complicated bends & turns like most of todays "clean air" uprights.  This vacuum only uses 5 amps of power.  More than enough to get carpet clean.  The brushroll has one row of brushes & one row of beater bars.  Again because of this, it gently but effectively grooms the carpet & removes sand & dirt.  I was amazed at how much dust & dirt was in the bag after vacuuming.  The bags are simple & easy to change.  Suction & airflow are very good with this vacuum.  It is lightweight & easy to move.  It is a bit quieter than most of todays vacuums because of the 5 amp motor vs 12 amps on most vacuums today.  Most of the sound volume comes from the motor fan.  Much like a hand drill has. This vacuum is best suited for use on carpets only, not hard floors or tool use.  I have a canister vacuum I use for above floor cleaning.  A duo that works well for me.  Belts & bags are very easy to find for this vacuum.  I use the F & G Filteraire bags to help keep allergens in check.  Take some time each month to check this vacuum over & change bags & it will take care of you for many years like mine has.  I just bought another one for use downstairs. A very good vacuum worthy of your consideration.
These are a great value.  No jams yet.  Much better than the Duo-Fast.  Highly recommended for carpet pad installation.  Buy the Bostitch Power slam hammer stapler!  You won't regret it.

The Oral-B toothbrushes are great. The vibrating action really does clean your teeth and gums better, with less abrasion and bleeding. My dentist got me onto them, and once you use them going back to regular toothbrushes just doesn't feel right again.
With that said, there is no reason to buy the battery powered brushes instead of the rechargable 3Ds. The price difference is neglible if you take into the account the cost of batteries, and if you shop around the toothbrushes may be available at a discout elsewhere for much less *coughCostcocough* There isn't even a reason to buy it as a travel toothbrush. I regularly spend 2 month deployments and only bring the toothbrush and a travel case, and it hasn't run out of battery power yet. Yes, this is with daily brushing.
Anyways, buy the 3D, forget the battery powered toothbrush unless you spend more than 2 months away from the charger.

So I think it's good to invest in a separate charger and extra battery if you can spare the bucks. Small capacity particle bin so needs frequent emptying. Needs a fairly clean room to begin with. Surprising how much it can pick up in a supposedly clean room. Best on hard floors, but can handle short-nap rugs but not fringe. Doesn't get stuck as much as I thought it would. Overall it does the job and I like it.

Nicholson files are a great value and the handy file is especially useful. I tie one file to each of my tools that need constant sharpening (scythe, machete, hedge shears, weed cutter, etc.) using the handy hole drilled in the handle.  That way when the tool is in the field, the means to sharpen is always right there.  Also, sew a simple slip sleeve for each file out of leather or fabric, coat it with a corrosion protector...that keeps the file from rusting and transfers a little of the rust preventer to the cutting edge of the tool.  CorrosionX works great.

Very little adhesive will remain on the glass- which cleans up with a swipe of alcohol. Peel slowly and you'll have nearly all of the adhesive and torn bits of paper to clean off before laying a new sheet! Good quality abrasives here, worth the purchase.

I agree with Gina from Florida - this is a dangerous machine.  I bought the Euro-Pro Shark SC505 today, and I'll be returning it tomorrow.

I was using it to clean my tile floors, and it seemed to be doing an acceptable although messy job. Suddenly, the darn thing just went crazy - hissing, spitting and then a huge blast of steam came out of it. My puppy was close by, thankfully just out of reach of the steam or it would have gotten him full in the face.  As it is, my arm got slightly scalded.

Thinking this might have been a fluke, or that I did something wrong, I let the machine cool down then refilled it and waited to try again.  It started to leak water everywhere while steam started to come out of the handle and hose.  No steam, however, from the nozzle where it is supposed to come from.

This machine is a waste of time, in addition to being dangerous.  Don't buy it.

The first workbench top that Grizzly sent to me arrived with a complete crack down the center.  This crack was clearly caused by mishandling by Saia Motor Freight, the shipper. There were other major problems in Saia MF's delivery to my house (details of which are not worth elaborating on here). Under no circumstances should you allow Grizzly to ship your top by Saia MF.

Grizzly handled the replacement of the top very gratiously, and they shipped the replacement by Fed Ex Freight.  It arrived in fine condition: very nice finish and smooth.

BUT: as others have experienced, the workbench top was not flat across the narrow dimension. In my case it was crowned in the middle by nearly 3/16". After debating to myself what to do (use it anway? go through the hassle of returning it?), I finally took it to a local cabinet shop that has a 36" drum sander. For $30 they sanded it flat, and now (after I added a finish) it's a very usable workbench top (although it's now only 1-9/16" thick).

I haven't owned a file before but I've seen some pretty "fancy" files. I know there are some files on the market with wooden handles and all that extra stuff (adding the to cost of the item). This file is one piece of steel. The handle is not very long but it's only an 8 inch file to begin with. Most of the length is the working area. Some reviewers have whined about wanting a better handle or wrapping stuff around the handle to make it all soft and comfy for them. Honestly, this file is so light (and only 8 inches long) that you don't need any special grip or padding. So light you don't even really need to use 2 hands to work it, I've been able to use it with only one hand.

When I first got it out of the package, I grabbed a dull hatchet I had in the garage. This file is very sharp. I was able to sharpen that hatchet back to a working edge in only 12 strokes. I use the hatchet for wood. I'm not a fantasy-land Viking, Templar Knight, or Barbarian...I'm not concerned with slicing paper with my hatchet or throwing it into a wall. It literally took me about 12 strokes to get a hatchet that couldn't make kindling from a dry log back to having a sharp working edge.

Sharp enough to get the work done quickly (e.g. only 12 strokes on a blade), light weight, small and easy to store. Good price. What's not to like? Well, ok, there may be one thing not to like--the finishing. When this file arrives, you should brush it down with a wire brush or rub it with another file or some sandpaper. I got 2 metal slivers in my hand from the handle. So be careful and wear gloves and/or get the burrs off this file before you use it.

This is ideal for putting a sharp working edge on your heavy working hand tools like lawn mower blades, axes/hatchets, machetes, pretty much anything made for chopping as well as other metal items such as steel pipes, etc. If this were lost or stolen, I'd buy another one in a heartbeat.

This is a fine product, and far cheaper than the manufacturer (Jet) wanted for the optional caster it sells with the drum sander I just purchased ($44 for four versus $160).  The only difficulties are (a) the stud on this caster is METRIC (12MM) and (b) Nowhere in the description is the size and thread pitch given.  Fortunately, my local auto parts stores let me tear open three 12mm lug nuts until I found the proper thread.  For the record, it's 12mm x 1.75.

If you're going to sell a metric-sized item in the United States which requires a nut for use, the decent thing to do would be to throw in the five cent part along with the caster.  I know we live in an age where cheaper is always better, but this is pennywise and pound foolish.

Excellent glues but not quite as magical as presented.  First, there are no instructions of any significance. They provide these stopper needles (if that is what they are) but no indication of how or why they should be used or even that they are stopper units (maybe they aren't!) The spray unit is provided with a plastic cover but, if used, will not fit back into the case!  Since this stuff is somewhat dangerous (as they say) and expensive, I would not want to leave the plastic cover off and taking the spray unit on and off would be messy and dangerous.  As glue, I have had several cases where the glued parts came apart where maybe the pieces weren't completely clean, were exposed to heat, or I didn't use the right thickness maybe.  This caused me to lose trust in the glue.  Lastly, like all glues of this type (super glues), you have to be extremely careful not to get an on your hands, especially since the activator runs easily.  Summary, excellent product in the right circumstances but you have to guess what they are.

Dap seems to have improved something in this, because I remember it being very difficult to work with a few years ago, and I stopped using it for another product, and found myself trying this again.  It's definitely more workable right out of the container.  Window glazing is a learned skill, and a lot of the Youtube videos show this being done without doing some of the vital prep work that is vital.  I've re-glazed most all of my 100-year old wooden windows with Dap 33 several years ago and everything is holding together well.  It's not as easy as simply applying new putty over the old dried putty, if you do that, it won't last.

Tools are as important as the prep.  If you can get the sash out of the window frame and take it to a workbench, your job will be much easier.  For a lot of cases, that just isn't feasible.  I like to use the Hyde bent putty knife for applying and tooling the putty.  However, any 2-in-1 window glazing tool with the straight blade on one end and the V-shaped blade on the other works just as well.  The key is having a bend, it helps.  A regular straight 1.5" semi-flex knife helps apply the bedding.  The "window repair knife" by Warner Tools is a semi flex knife with an angled edge, it works fantastic at removing old putty.  I personally prefer the #2 triangular glaziers points, and they require the Fletcher point driver.  But, if you're just a DIYer replacing one or two panes, you can get the #7 points that can be pushed in with a 2-in-1 tool.

The first thing to do is scoop everything out of the container and knead and roll it around in your hands to mix everything and warm it up.  Do that for at least 5 minutes.  For prep, a heat gun and scraper makes getting the old putty out of the sash.  When the sash rabbet is cleaned out and the glass is removed, primer it with any oil-based primer.  This is important not only because it gives the putty something to stick to, but it will be the barrier between the wood and the putty.  Put some furniture oil on an old piece of wood.  See how quickly it absorbs it?  That's what will happen to the putty if you skip this step!  You don't want the wood to absorb the oil out of the putty, or it will fail very quickly.  Once the sash is primed, set a thin bead of putty on the front part of the rabbet.  This forms a pillow to cushion the glass.  Then set your glass in.  Use your points to hold it in the frame.  Now its time to apply the putty.  When all is said and done, I've had it take 1-2 weeks to skin over enough to be painted.  This curing time seems to be about on par with Glazol and the other readily available products.

So my long-time lemur buddy Dave and I were on a normal walkabout down by Big Lick creek when all of a sudden a chunk of interplanetary space debris about the size of your average house cat blazed through the noon sky and fell into our path. Well in his haste to avoid being pulverized into crispy little lemur bits, Davey boy attempted a maneuver that only a gibbon should try. Let's face it, Dave is no gibbon, thus he got his tail stuck between a rock and a hard place breaking it almost clean in two. While I fashioned a make-shift splint from young poplars and kudzu vines, I assured him everything would be alright since I always keep a bottle of Gorilla glue in my truck.

Once back at the truck I quickly made work of setting Dave's tail back in place. I wet both ends of his tail per the directions on the bottle. I then stuck the ends together and wrapped his makeshift splint back in place to allow time for the glue to bond. Maybe it was the kudzu, but 24 hours later the glue still had not bonded! I was so upset and so was Dave. We just couldn't understand why it didn't work, since he even helped me use the Gorilla glue to replace a torn ear for Steve, a really good bonobo friend of his. We had great success with Steve's ear, so my conclusion is that the Gorilla glue is fine for Hominidae, but not so good for Prosimians. Thanks for reading.

Gorilla Glue eight ounce size.
Most of us have been in a home repair situation that just keeps getting worse the more you get into it. When that happens worse means more cash to fix the problem. There are those who say just "do it right" or don't do it at all. You know who you are. I can agree with them, when there is money to use, but when there are no funds there is..... Gorilla Glue. Well here is my story.

I had a small problem that quickly spiraled into a carpenters truck payments. I had a loose toilet. Not a big deal right. Tried to usual tighter down the loose bolts. No help they just kept turning, which means the terrible and dreaded WOOOOOD ROTTTTTT.
Yes Houston we have a problem. The tiolet flange that holds it in place was rotten from some sneaky water leak somewhere not visible. This insidious leak had taken its toll and caused great damage under the bathroom tile.

In comes repair guy 1 then second opinion guy. Remedy; You gotta take that toilet out, bust out all that floor tile, cut out the sub floor, put in new sub floor, put in new tile, new toilet flange, and re set toilet then grout everything. Estimate to "Do It Right" nearly two grand. Since you have a carpenter, then a tile guy, then a plumber guy. My heart sank as I knew how much cash I had at the time.

My thoughts. The floor seemed good everywhere but around the flange. The toilet while it would turn and lift on one side was still holding fair on one side. If only I could just shoer this thing up where it would be stable. I wish I could just shoot something in there that would fix everything and not go in debt.

How about Gorilla Glue. No that would just make a bigger mess. No here me out this might work. No it won't Gorilla Glue expands and will screw up everything. All this was the conversation i was having with myself in my head.

Ok lets do this but how to get it under the toilet. I took the bottle of glue and went to the hose department at home depot and found some clear plastic hose that would fit on the end.

The process. I lifted up one side of the toilet to inspect wood damage and condition. The rot was in the past and little moisture was present so the leak may have been partly condensation gone wild. Good news. Gorilla Glue activates with moisture. Didn't know that, so the conditions here are perfect. What the glue was now to do is to bond with the bad wood becoming super strong, water resistant, and hard as stone. it will make a bridge so to speak with the bad wood and the good wood, and Gorilla will bond with porcelain like grout does but stronger bond.

The attack. Hose on bottle, one side of toilet is lifted, hose inserted, squeezing and not much is happening as this glue is thick. Plan B, set glue bottle on floor use foot pressure. Eureka we have glue flow. Pumped about two ounces all around the toilet. Luckily the high pressure from my foot did not make the hose come off and get all over my shoes and the outside of the toilet.

Ok ok you knew it was going to happen. Yes the hose did come off and glue spewed all over my shoes and toilet. Cleaned it off and we are done almost. Remember the glue does expand while it dries filling up gaps as it forms it bonds. I was ready with a box cutter coming back in every ten minutes to inspect and trim.

All in all it worked. Solid as a rock. No leaks. Used some white silicone caulk around the base. The choice was either eight bucks for the glue, or nearly two grand that could better be used for other things like beer, new flat screen tv, taking the wife out to dinner sixty times, or other electronic man toys.

This glue saved me. In life you come across small things that work their way your heart for how well they help you or serve a purpose. Your uses and millage of course may vary. Good luck always.

Overall, I've been somewhat happy with this vacuum, but the hose has a somewhat severe flaw in that the inner diameter of the hose abruptly decreases significantly at the connection between the hose and the canister.  This is exactly where your garbage will clog.  Any job I do seems to involve several unclogging breaks, especially if the debris is on the large size.

The corrugated hose has a fitting that plugs *into* the hose, which decreases the inner diameter.  All the junk that was able to traverse the entire length of the substantial hose now comes to an abrupt halt in the last inch of the hose.  A better design would have had the fitting *around* the hose so the inner diameter wouldn't change.  Seems like it would have been easy to do, since the fitting is under negative pressure and therefor unlikely to pop off in any circumstance.

The advertisement shows a guy vacuuming sawdust -- the perfect application for this; sawdust is too small to clog anything.  Try to vacuum up a few leaves, however, and they will shoot through 20 feet of hose only to get stuck *just* before they get to the canister.  It's quite irritating to see a great vacuum hurt by this one simple-to-fix flaw.

Last year, I purchased a #2-plain General grommet-repair kit from Amazon to compare it with the equivalent Lord & Hodge kits.  The contrast was remarkable!  The Lord & Hodge sets were domestically-manufactured and met all of my expectations.  The General set, in contrast, was cobbled together in India and was garbage.  A couple of the grommets were pitted on the margins, and one of the male components was bent.  Two more set imperfectly and had to be removed, a problem which I haven't encountered elsewhere.  I finally got around to weighing the respective grommets and found the General submission to be roughly 30% underweight.  Brass foil.  Although the first commentaries could be considered somewhat subjective, the weight differential isn't.  Additionally, I strongly suspect the setting tools are inferior to L&H's, a rough brinell test having indicated that the anvil material is softer.

This shop vac could be decent, unfortunately there is no appropriate bag designed for this vacuum. The problem is that any bag that actually fits this unit is designed for low-rise vacuums, not this tall type. The result is those wrap-around bags cant expand because the motor is in the center preventing any degree of expansion to retain debris. The other problem is that there is no bag actually designed to reach the bottom of the vacuum, so that as the bag fills up, it ends up hanging on the inlet causing pressure on the paper and eventually ripping open blowing all the debris\dust all over the place. Those disposable wrap around paper filters that go over the foam sleeve clog up way too fast. Another problem is that housing just below the motor that is supposed to hold the foam sleeve directly interferes with the inlet leaving no room even if there was a tall bag that could reach the bottom of the vacuum offering support as debris collects and not putting pressure on the bag opening. Very poor design. To me, this was a waste of money.

We are puzzled why it's such a chore for Shop-vac or anyone else to come up with a decent round brush replacement. This is the second one we've tried (the other one was a different model by a different mfg) and we are ending up sending both of them back. In a nutshell, this is what is wrong with this brush: The bristles are too long and when you vacuum with it they have a tendency to clump together in the center. This restricts the suction space and amount of suction. If you have pet hair it balls up and doesn't even reach inside the brush so it can go up into the hose and into the vacuum because the bristles of the brush block it and lots of other things you try to vacuum up. I guess the lesson here is to go to a store and find the right one for your needs because shopping for them online has been frustrating.

All in all, steamer did produce some good steam, but could not completely clean the grout because I had let it go for so long.  Yes, I would recommend this machine for lesser challenging cleaning jobs.

"Gorilla Glue" has become one of the most used "tools" in our house. We have used it to repair wooden chairs, fix a wooden medicine chest, glue soles back on to sneekers, fill cracks in a wall, and at least half a dozen other fixes in the past month.

Here are my observations:

* You must read the directions!
* Surface needs to be damp for the glue to work
* Use clamps when possible
* It expands a *LOT*, use with caution or you might accidently glue your project to the table as it expands overnight! This happend to me :-)
* This is strong glue and hard to get off once it is on a surface

Highly recommended!

In a nutshell:

PROS:
1) Actually whitens teeth well.

CONS:
1) Too abrasive. Erodes mouth tissue.

Now the details:

I bought this product after reading so many good reviews about it. One problems others have noted already is the lack of a measuring cup to know how much 10mL really is. Nevertheless, I used the product exactly as the directions instructed, gargling the mouthwash for a minute, once in the morning and once in the night after brushing my teeth, and not eating or drinking anything for the following 30 minutes. I followed this regimen for a little after a week, and already began to notice the whitening effect. During the next few days, however, my mouth began to hurt, and I started spitting out bits of what I thought was food during the 30 minutes after I gargled the mouthwash. I was actually spitting out bits of my gum. I immediately stopped using the mouthwash, but different parts of my mouth was already raw as top layers of my gum were stripped off, and it took more than week for it to finally heal. I might just be a lot more sensitive to the chemicals in the Rembrandt mouthwash than most other people are, but Rembrandt products are known to be a LOT more abrasive than others. For me, this cons heavily outweighs the pros. I would go for a safer mouthwash, even if the whitening effects may take longer to kick in.

Several of my friends have asked me for recommendations for a cheap vacuum. When they have mostly rugs and carpets, this is the one I recommend. It's a tried-and-true design, pretty much a cheaper version of the commercial Sanitaire uprights, and like those, it'll keep on working long after the new, whizzy Dirt Devils, Bissels and Dysons have been consigned to the dustbin. It does a bang-up job on carpets with its direct-air design (like a Kirby) and very good agitation.

Now for the bad: no included attachments, and the kits that are available are cumbersome and don't work extremely well. Also, it uses F&G bags, which are getting harder to come by and are annoying to install. That said, these are minor problems, slight blemishes on an otherwise time-tested and excellent design. To get anything nearly as good in a more modern design, you'll have to pay at least five times as much for a Riccar/Simplicity, Sebo or Miele.

Background you can skip
I am experienced in laying laminate floors as I always chose to go that route with our past homes. Our current home, however, had a partial hardwood floor installed... and the rest was carpet of the brand 'Nasty'. So that had to go. Ripping out the 700 sq ft of Bruce Hardwood flooring would be a nightmare given that it was stapled and and I also felt it would be capital destruction as it is valuable and pretty.
So I opted to buy another 2000+ sq ft of hardwood and finish what the previous owners started.

Once I started witht he diningroom I noticed something that I never really experienced with Laminate... it was a pain to keep the boards tight and then once you had them tight you had to KEEP them tight while hammering. I tried all the online suggestions: using planks, boards, wedges, scalpels and what have you to create leverage to get the board together but , although it does work, I could not believe the job would be finished quickly and professionally. I needed something better and I assumed that someone MUST HAVE thought of a solution.

Anyways, I am a quick learner and a search on Amazon put me in touch with this baby, the QuikJack.

About this item
Amazon got it to me overnight (i heart Prime Membership) and I lost little time.
The item is pretty big and sturdy. It is a specially designed Jack that leaves your hands free to operate your cleat nailer (I bought a pneumatic one, LOOOOVE IT!!).
As you can see from the pictures: you can create lots of easy configs and floorpositions for this jack. I did not nail it in but used a stud that was offset against the wall for leverage. Worked SUPERFAST. I think I went 10x faster than the manual solution. This was truly worth every penny I spent on it.

Pros
0 Heavy duty, will last forever
0 Well designed by pros so that you really can see it is for everyday use
0 Spoiler alert: spoils the user so that you can no longer do without!!

Cons
0 Little pricey compared to tighthening clamps

Conclusion
I agree with other reviewers: this is a MUST HAVE tool. Not a nice to have. I cannot imagine having to put a floor in without this combined wiht my pneumatic nailer. You might need more than 1 to be even more efficient, but 1 is sufficient if need be. Pro installers that do this for a living probably use more than 1.

LOVE IT.

Ah... the search to find a gas can that pours without making a mess.  Unfortunately, this one isn't it. At least it wasn't for me.

It is sturdy and I like the positive, spring-loaded, rubber-gasketed lid but filling is awkward (why not have a way to hold the lid open?). Most importantly, I couldn't pour without spilling some gas no matter how I tried.

The funnel is nearly useless, unless you don't mind gas dribbling down the side of the can and onto your machinery or the ground. The problem is that the funnel doesn't seal around the spout and even with careful pouring to try to keep the flow of gas beyond the funnel-spout connection, some fuel finds its way there and seeps through the "seal" and down along the side of the can.  I tried taking the funnel off, using it in the traditional way, but still some fuel inevitably would spill down the spout aand the side of the can.  The spout is just too short and wide to allow spill-less pouring, especially with a big, awkward can like this.

Addendum to the review of 2-27-12:
I realize that this can has received many very favorable reviews and therefore maybe the leaking I experienced was due to a defective  funnel or can.  It may be that I just didn't have the funnel snapped in place fully-I don't know I don't own it anymore to check. Maybe some others tolerate a bit of dribble down the can-I don't want any leaking.

 I might, actually be inclined to try this can again.  I wanted to like it.  I'm now using a plastic Blitz that works without leaking unless it's turned completely upside down-then it leaks a tiny bit-so I've learned to avoid this) but it's very slow to pour, swells or shrinks alarmingly with temperature variations, emits fuel odors, and has a whiz-bang safety lever/nozzle that looks very fragile and is a real pain to use.

12-12-14:
I finally bought a  5 gallon plastic Tuff Jug when I got tired of the slow pour and leaking of the Blitz can with the complex and fragile safety spout.  I like the Tuff Jug with its simple spring loaded shutoff that is opened when the nozzle edge is pushed against the edge of an opening. It pours very fast and is easy enough to use, though you do have to tip the can nearly completely upside down for filling an upright opening. This takes some muscle for a near 40# can of fuel. I have an adapter extension for use in my particular equipment and the can does leak very slightly by the end of the pour.  I think this is because the adapter is a snap-on hard plastic product and may not seal completely. However the leakage is very slight and tolerable for me.  I suspect that the can wouldn't leak without the extra nozzle attachment (not needed by most). Like all plastic cans, the Tuff Jug shrinks and swells with temperature changes, though not as much as the typical thin walled cans. Metal cans have the advantage in this regard.

The Tuff Jug is constructed of very sturdy looking plastic and is kind of expensive but probably priced fairly for its ruggedness. I've not had the Tuff Jug long enough, however,  to judge the durability.

I've also used No Spill cans with good results. They pour fast (not as fast as the Tuff Jug), and seem to be well made and get great reviews.

Great sandpaper. Much nicer (and cheaper) than the Diablo sandpaper I was buying for my orbital sander. The 80 grit was able to hog off a good amount of material. I was using it to remove a top-layer of paint on some small pieces, and the paint did clog up the paper, but I think paint is going to clog up any sandpaper you use. If I were to use this on a plain piece of wood I doubt it would clog at all.

When the paint was removed I was able to use other grits to finish sanding the pieces (also by Porter Cable, and bought on Amazon), and the finer grits were able to easily remove any marks left by the rougher 80 grit.

Overall, I like this paper and will definitely buy some more when I run out.

With thirty-five nearly all positive reviews I was wondering what I could say that would add to them.  Well, this is what I came up with:  The biggest most positive thing I can think of (that no one else has yet mentioned) is that this belt will not "flat spot" if allowed to sit unused for a period of time. Add to that the other attributes that other reviewers HAVE mentioned and you have one really neat little piece of engineering here.

My neighbor has a Delta table saw and the first time I helped him use it the weather was cold.  Add to that, his saw sits more often than not.  When he turned it on after weeks of not being used it vibrated terribly.  He said that it would settle down "after a while, after it warmed up." Well it did... and it didn't.

To make a long story short, after assembling my Jet I put the factory belt on and ran the saw a few times.  It had a vibration too with it's brand NEW belt!  After it sat for a few days unused (hey, it was Christmas time) the vibration got worse.  Since I had always intended to try the Power Twist on it it seemed as if there were no time like the present, so I ordered one before I'd had to do ANY important cuts with the saw.

First of all it was cold when I tried to size the belt and so it wasn't that easy.  On the other hand it wasn't that difficult either, but I did need to use pliers.  And, you have to get your bearings straight.  This is a different animal than your standard v-belt... I liken it to those link belts we all made at summer camp or in some craft class somewhere. Mine came with no intructions at all. 'A disappointment for sure, but I was able to download them.

My other complaint is that the directional arrows printed on the links are very hard to see.  A "Sharpie" helped out a lot. Anyway, after some trial and error I was able to size the belt correctly and install it.  As others have said, my saw will EASILY pass the nickel test, and my neighbor can't figure out why my cheap Jet runs so much smoother than his much more expensive Delta.  Don't worry,  he's a Buddy and I'll clue him in soon enough.  But for now, I just want to enjoy his frustration and confusion. I know, I'm bad, but it feels so good to know that just 30 bucks can make such a difference!!

If they offered these in the narrower, "O/3L" cross section, I would have one on my cheapy, Made in China drill press too. Don't judge me too harshly about this one. I'm on a budget!! (edit: They do!!  After much time spent researching I found out from the manufacturer, Fenner Drives that McMaster Carr carries them, though the price a bit higher than Amazon, but worth it.)

As I said in another review (of my saw) Don't ASK, just BUY ONE!! You WON'T be sorry... unless of course you put in on backward or something dumb like that.  It IS a "directional" belt.

As usual, I hope you find this review helpful, and Good Luck with your own dreams.

This is a good bet for a generic drugstore whitener, although I am sure you could do better with higher end kits online. I've used it for a long time and I've experienced good effects, enough for me to keep buying them from time to time when they go on sale or before some big event. I like the fact that it's 2 hour, since you can have faster results.

One of the reasons I'm docking stars is that this product has gotten more and more ridiculous to use over the years. Initially this product came with two large syringes, whose design allowed you to use every bit of the gel. Now there are a bunch of ridiculous little capsule things, which are nearly impossible to get all the gel out of. It's as if this new design is forcing you to waste product (and allow them to give you less). Just leaves kind of a bad feeling that a company would purposely make something worse like that.

I think I stick with it more that I've had history with it than anything else, since I've never had any sensitivity or irritation. Next time I will buy a higher strength whitening kit online. But if you're at a drugstore and that's the only thing you have with 2 hours before a nice event, go for it.

I suppose there were so many grand reviews that I ignored the not-so-great ones, but this doesn't have the magical powers everyone says is does. Well, not for me, anyway. I purchased this to bind a ceramic serving spoon that broke. The package indicated boldly that it would work on china, but it turns out not so much. After holding the two pieces together for a minute, it didn't seem to have any impact, so I added glue and held it for five. it seemed to hold, so I arranged a way to leave it overnight. It seemed fine the next morning, and fairly sturdy, but to be safe, I left it for one more day. Of course, I woke up to the two pieces having come apart again. Admittedly, I'm giving it another go, at the moment, and coated the outside of the cracked parts heavily. If it works, I'll update this review.

That said, on another broken plastic item, it seems to have worked just fine (so far). I'm guessing this is really just no good for porous materials, which it turns out, China is. So do keep that in mind. I mean, it's cheap, but I would rather have paid more for something guaranteed to work. Not too jazzed by my futile efforts. Lesson learned.

I bought 4 of these cans in March 2007.  They are so bad, I have to throw them away and buy something that works.

The problem with these cans is with the plastic funnel.  First it's very difficult to install because the clearance between the spring loaded cap and the funnel is too small to allow the funnel to fit.  And it's so fat, that you can't empty more than about 1/3 the can into a vehicle's gas tank.  The funnel doesn't fit very well, so it ends up leaking gas on the floor under the can, and getting it all over you in the process.  The only way to get gas into a vehicle is to buy a gooseneck funnel to stick in the filler pipe, and then pour the gas from these horribly designed cans into the funnel.

We're so stupid now, that we can't even design a gas can that works.  This so called "certified safety can" leaks gas all over the area where it's being used, and takes two people to use.

DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT !!!!!!!!!!!

I have used Crest White Strips in the past and never had a problem. I used this product hoping the 2 hour process would give me the results I was looking for. One, they did not help very much. Two, it left me with horrible burns on my lower gums and inside my lower lip. Please don't assume that I did something wrong. I followed the directions exactly. I only applied a thin line on the front side of the trays. I left it in for 20 minutes each time and rinsed well between treatments. It did not hurt badly while I had the trays in or else I would have stopped. Only in the last treatment did it begin to hurt. However, the next day morning the pain was excruciating! It has now been 48 hours and it still hurts to eat, drink, or even talk at some times! The area is bright red and covered in white blistered spots. It really looks like the chemicals ate away at my gums. It hurts terribly! I would never use this product again and I would not recommend that anyone put themselves at risk of such pain by using it themselves!

I have a dryer vent on the third floor of my home whose exit through the wall to the exterior clapboards is surrounded by a bird-proof plastic "cage" that keeps the birds out but also keeps a lot of the lint inside the cage. If the cage isn't cleaned often, lint backs up into the dryer hose, making it both less efficient and ultimately increasing the risk of a dryer fire. Until now, that meant handing whoever was doing some other kind of work on the house (cleaning gutters, repairs, window washing, painting, etc.) with a long enough ladder a twenty and asking them to remove the cage, clean it out, and reattach it to the siding.

With these extenders, I can now reach it from a balcony one flight below the vent, using my shop vac to remove not only the lint caught in the cage, but also pulling more out of the dryer hose inside the wall itself because the suction of the shop vac is quite powerful. This keeps the dryer working at maximal efficiency and reduces the fire risk while saving money, allowing me to clean it from the outside whenever it's convenient to do so, and reducing the number of times I have to pull the dryer (it's a stacked unit, and the two appliances, the dryer atop the washer, are both heavy and difficult to maneuver as I get older) away from the wall to clean behind both and replace the dryer vent hose because it's become clogged with lint.

The only minor problem I find is that it just reaches the exterior vent cage and another set, even if I only use one of the two extensions, will allow me more flexibility when cleaning out the vent. I'll order them in the spring when the weather is better as it only needs to be done every four months or so to keep the vent exit reasonably clean and free from lint.

I bought this self-adhesive foam tape to block the draft under the door. I applied it to a clean not greasy surface (painted wooden door) as directed.
At first it worked perfectly, but after a few days it fell off even though it was not in contact with anything. There is a gap between the floor and the bottom of the door where I attached the tape, so the tape did not grab on to the floor or anything else. I had to use a glue to put it back in place.
Since then I have used it on several other surfaces like glass, wooden furniture and it fell off again after a few days without being touched by anyone or anything.

Overall, it is a good tape, but do not count on it sticking to things. You will probably need a glue.

I bought this caliper for measuring bicycle seat posts, stems, etc. Not very exacting work. Well, forget it. It's only accurate to 1mm. The dial only measures in .01" or 1/64th", not mm. When the dial shows exactly 1 inch, the scale shows 25 mm, not 25.4mm. Measuring a marked 22.2mm stem, it shows 21.5mm. The only way to make this device work is to measure in inches and convert to mm.
If you never measure anything metric, you might be ok, but even if you argue that the mm scale is provided as a convenience this level of accuracy falls short of any reasonable expectation.

I have tried three different types of Gorilla glue and this one is the best, although still VERY average. I cannot recommend it as it is not truly "general purpose". While it works decently, if you don't mind the excess foaming on paper to wood, wood to wood or cardboard to plastic, it totally fails on plastic to metal or brick. It is WORTHLESS on brick to brick (yes they are bare, unpainted bricks), and don't even think about using it to stick anything to concrete blocks. Their Product Description is all hype and I found to be totally untrue. "Gorilla Glue is the finest all purpose premium polyurethane wood glue available today." * I have found several better products, including Elmer's Ultimate Glue - P9417 16Oz Ultimate Poly Glue and Elmer's E9416 All Purpose Glue-All Max, 8 Ounces just to name two. "Gorilla Glue is environmentally friendly, incredibly strong, 100 waterproof, will not freeze, requires no mixing, does not become brittle with age and will not expand or contract in the glue joint." * It is NOT incredibly strong!! I first tried to glue a plastic wheel barrow what has a 6 in split in it with this this product. After TWO days of drying (and scraping a lot of foaming residue) I dumped a load of dirt and it immediately split on first load. Okay, maybe not enough surface area to make a good bond. I took a strip of flexible plastic and roughed up both original surfaces and the new reinforcement strip and surface that would be in contact with it with 80 grit sandpaper, AND I also CLAMPED the reinforcement strip firmly, but not tightly, in 3 locations. Again, after 3 or 4 days (home owner, don't have to use wheel barrow every day luckily) of setting time I went to use wheelbarrow. Put shovel in wheelbarrow and let handle drop to side. Guess what? Yup, you guessed it, crack split again faster than cheerleaders doing splits at end of their routine! So much for strong. * It has become brittle on two or three projects for me, mostly ones exposed to intense sunlight or freezing temperatures. And then FAILED. As to water proof & requires no mixing, I guess these are correct, but so are almost all other resin and polyurethane adhesives; environmentally friendly -- what about it is enviro friendly? More hype to get tree huggers and green freaks to buy a product I suppose. * * Plus this stuff foams up worse than a dog that has just tried to eat a toad and is very messy to clean up and it surface even when capped tightly in bottle tends to become rock hard and requires coat hanger to break up to get to adhesive. I have relegated what I have left to NON critical small insignificant wood/paper bonding and will NOT be purchasing again.

I bought this vacuum cleaner for because I am a fan of the power, simplicity (and aesthetics) of the traditional F&G style vacuum cleaners. For this particular product, I would say you get what you pay for, but almost not even that.
* Note: The vacuum pictured is not the Eureka 1934B. The Eureka 1934B is different in that the bag and hood are both solid Grey, and instead of the Eureka logo being on the bag, "TheBoss" logo is on the bag.

The Eureka is lightweight @10.4 pounds, it has a rather short 20' power cord, a 5 amp motor, and nearly all plastic construction. It comes with one 11 quart dust bag and an extra belt. It has a 12" wooden brush-roll with one line of bristles and a plastic agitator and 6 height settings.

Pros:
 It's quiet, operating at ~89db
 Effective against pet hair
 Lightweight at 10.4 pounds
 Like most vacuums of this style, it pulls up the carpet, making it appear newer

Cons:
 The motor is rather weak
 The power cord is only 20', which may seem like a lot, until you realize you can't plug it in in one room and reach the next.
 The construction is all plastic, with the exception of the fan chamber cover and the springs/screws used to hold the vacuum together.
 The metal bottom plate seems to be sized slightly wrong; will be explained later.
 The actual vacuum is not as displayed. This vacuum is the 1934B, the one displayed is the original 1934. [...]
 The filtration is bar none; only the bag filters

The main problem I have with this vacuum is the 5 amp motor. If you have an already relatively clean and small house, with only light things, such as dust, hair, paper, and light plastic to pick up, then this vacuum will do well for you. If you vacuum anything more than that, this vacuum is not. I tested this vacuum cleaner on the house I just moved out of. After all my furniture was moved, things on the floor lingered like small splinters of wood, tiny nails, small pieces of plastic, staples and other dense but not unreasonable things like that. This vacuum could not handle them. It wasn't that it was going to break the machine, but it all rattled around in the chamber for minutes until I turned off the vacuum and fished them out. The suction from the 5 amp motor was not powerful enough to suck them into the fan chamber *or* to propel them into the dust bag.

As far as the metal plate on the bottom, all vacuums have a plate in front of the brush-roll that keeps the brush-roll in place. As it curves in under the vacuum, a lot of dirt collects there. This means that when the vacuum is tilted, or when the plate is taken off, all the dirt falls out.

For my own uses, I am in need of something heavier and more powerful. I feel that this vacuum will not last me very long. I would suggest spending the extra 100 dollars and just buying the Sanitaire SC886, which comes with a 7 amp motor, a 50' power cord, and nearly all metal construction.

If you need a vacuum for light use and pick up, I would suggest this one.

I ordered the SX5035-12 which is a 7/32" Crown x 1/2" Leg staple. However, when I received the package from Amazon the label stated that it was a 5/8" leg but had the same model number as the 1/2." I received this toothbrush as a Christmas gift, but hadn't opened until recently.  (My dentist had recommended that I switch to a electric brush instead of using a manual one.)  One of first things I didn't like was the small brush head. However, I was willing to overlook that.  When I actually starting using the brush, I found that it wasn't very effective at cleaning my teeth, at least not as effective as it could have been.  I would have to follow up with my manual toothbrush to get the plaque film that the Oral-B had missed or not removed.  My teeth just didn't feel as clean after as they did with the manual toothbrush.

Recently I have switched to a Sonicare toothbrush, and it's great.  I don't have to expend as much effort as with the Oral-B, and my teeth and gums always feel refreshed afterward.
My recommendation is that if you are planning to buy an electric toothbrush, buy a Sonicare brush.  It will be much more worth it.

I put the belt on the motor pully first then around the brush and insert the left side in the slot and then the right side slides into the slot easily.  The belt is a tight fit.  Eureka should include a small tool, pry bar, to stretch the belt over the motor pulley.

Update 3/17/2016
I changed the belt today and it was nearly imposable to get the new belt on.  You have to remove the brush to get the old belt off and the new belt on.  It took me a half hour to get the brush to slide back into the groove even without the belt on it.  The brush has rubber grommets on each end and they just don't slide into the groove in the housing.
Update 4/21/2016
Today the brush froze up and wouldn't turn causing the vacuum to be useless..  This thing is only 10 months old and it is already wore out.  I don't recommend this vacuum to anybody.

This type of Gorilla Glue is a reasonable glue for crude jobs where you wish to fill small cracks.  It is not a good glue for situations  you want to sand over wide cracks to get a smooth surface.

Gorilla Glue 50008 is a urethane glue, so it resembles honey.  It is sticky and messy.  The cap on this particular product can be conveniently left attached to the bottle by a plastic strip so you won't loose it,  but if you leave it attached  you'll find the cap inconveniently springing back in front of the spout as you are squeezing out glue.

The fact that urethane glue is messy  is significant because it sticks well to skin and won't completely wash off even before it hardens.  On your skin it quickly picks up dirt and becomes a dark crusty patch.  You end up with hands that look lilke a mechanic's but you can't wash them like a mechanic - not with  Lava Soap, mechanic's hand cleaner, acetone, or  brake fluid cleaner.  Gorilla glue has never irritated my skin.  It's just a cosmetic problem.  You have to let it wear off, which takes about 4 days.  There is no practical way to clean Gorilla Glue out of fabrics.  If you want to keep your hands clean, put lotion on them and use rubber gloves.  Expect drips of glue to fall on the work table and on the floor and remain sticky for hours.

Like honey, Gorilla glue becomes viscous in cold weather.  When the glue gets cold,  seconds tick by before you can begin to squeeze glue out of a half empty bottle because you must wait for it to flow down to the spout.  So it's best to store the glue indoors.

With its cap on, Gorilla Glue stores well for months.  Getting the cap off may require a gentle twist with pliers, but the spout and cap are a durable plastic and they can take it.  The dried sheet of glue on them comes off cleanly.  (For this reason, I don't recommend trying to glue such plastic with Gorilla glue.)

The scenario for a good glue job with an old fashioned hide glues is well known.  The things to be glued are supposed to fit together "naturally" and tightly.  There aren't supposed to be cracks.  The pieces should have "clean dry" surfaces.  You apply glue to both surfaces.  You spread the glue out o a even film on both surfaces, not simply squirt a squiggly bead of glue.  The surfaces are clamped together with the "appropriate pressure".  This means they aren't clamped so tightly that it builds up stresses that will spring apart when the clamps are released.  You can wipe excess old fashioned glue off when it is wet.  Some say it is easier to wait until the glue is leathery but not hard and peel it off with a chisel.

Some of the old fashioned scenario doesn't apply to urethane glue.  It's best that pieces  fit together naturally and tightly.  Gorilla glue tolerates moisture and, in fact, the directions say that the surfaces should not be too dry.  Ideally one would spread the glue evenly on the surfaces, but this is a messy job.  Since Gorilla glue foams as it dries, it somewhat spreads itself out.  It doesn't spread to a miraculous extent.  If you pull apart surfaces that were glued with squiggly beads of glue, you will find patches that are bare.

After you clamp pieces together you can wipe off excess Gorilla glue and this somewhat helps in the final cleanup.  However, more glue will ooze out as you wait for the glue to harden and that  takes overnight.

As well as flowing for a long time, urethane glues foam.  Gorilla glue foams slightly more than Elmer's "Ultimate" urethane glue.  (Urethane glues don't foam to the extent of urethane foam sealants that you buy in spray cans.)  You have to clamp things together securely or the foaming action will push them apart.

You cannot wait till Gorilla Glue is leathery hard and peel the excess off because after a blob gets a hard surface the inside remains tacky for a long time.

The hardened foam of excess glue is dense.  It's tougher than styrofoam.  A belt sander makes quick work of sanding it off if you sand it all off. (If you only sand the top off the foam, you'll just expose the insides of thousands of glue bubbles.)  In places you can't reach with a sander, excess glue can be chiseled off., but it leaves a fuzzy reside that must be sanded off by hand.  You can leave the excess glue if you aren't concerned  about appearance, but direct sunlight darkens it  and makes it deteriorate.

I often use Gorilla in simple carpentry projects that are held together with both screws and glue.  I trust the screws to hold things together.  The Gorilla Glue mainly serves the purpose of filling the gaps in joints that are too small to fill with wood filler.  I find it a good product for this purpose.

Gorilla Glue sticks to itself unlike glues like Titebond.  Theoretically, you can touch up a Gorilla Glue job by adding more glue.  I never do this since I'm not relying on Gorilla Glue to hold things together.

I rate Gorilla Glue 4 stars out of 5 as a filler of small cracks.

Please educate yourselves on the chemical "Triclosan" found in this product and many others. Triclosan is a known endocrine disruptor and is considered toxic. This chemical is currently being considered for ban in the U.S. and is banned in several other countries. It may work, but you have no idea what it is doing to your body and it is harmful to the environment. Some healthier alternatives would be Australian tea tree oil, grapefruit seed extract, and pine oil. For more information on triclosan, refer to the EPA website.

1) Elmers "Ultimate High Performance" is also a Polyurethane (PU) glue and (as far as I can tell) it's as good as Gorilla, but cheaper. also used the PL brand glue and can't tell any notable difference between the three. Have not used Sumo but I understand it sets up faster and as a result apparently has a much more limited shelf life (this is generally not a good thing - see item #3)

2) Gorilla Glue (In my opinion) has thought out their bottle and cap design better than the competition.  While this seems like a minor thing, it really makes a BIG difference in not being messy or wasting glue (See #4)

3) PU glues work differently - they foam up and expand in the presence of moisture and then harden.  This means you will need to think about where the glue comes out and how to keep it from making a mess.  Masking tape is your friend.

4) PU glues have a limited shelf life and you probably don't need as much as you think. Due to the expansion (see #3) you use a LOT less than other types of glue. 4 oz should be MORE than enough for most people, 8 oz is a BIG bottle. I personally buy the 2 oz bottle unless I have a major project.  PU Glues suck moisture out of the air so unless you plan on using it up within a year or two, a LOT is going to go to waste. Don't ask me how I know this.

5) PU Glue is FANTASTIC for lots of things but woodworking glues are still better for woodworking (see #7). They are stronger and you can't clean PU glues up with water the way you can even with the waterproof Titebond products. Also if you use biscuits you will have to moisten them separately to get them to swell.

6) KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN AND ANIMALS! Although the glue itself is not toxic and is food safe once cured, it can kill your pets - like antifreeze it apparently tastes good to animals and will swell and harden inside the digestive tract creating a blockage. There is NO antidote and surgery is typically the only solution. There have been MANY cases - just search Google "Dog Gorilla Glue." Wear gloves (rubber or vinyl) and use lots of wax paper and paper towels.

7) Wood glues (Like Titebond II) are still better for wood to wood bonding.  Fine Woodworking did a test (Issue #192) and found Polyurethane glues to be about half as strong in this application.  Search "HowStrongisYourGlue_FWW" for the article.  One exception is if you're gluing oily exotics where I personally still prefer Epoxy - you can dial in your set time, clean up is about the same given the PU glue outflow.
